This was all possible because they made their own graphics card. Intel has the capabilities and AMD has more experience with this. But when motherboards had a north bridge back in the day and then one day  they didnt anymore. I wondered why doesnt the motherboard need a northbridge anymore? What changed? Well it still had north bridge but it was now incorporated into the CPU die so it ran at the speed of the processor and not the 33MHZ of the motherboard. I thought "Can they do that" and if so why not incorporate the graphics card into the cpu die so it will be even faster. Whats more why not do this what the ram aswell and any other pars of the motherboard that can be on the cpu die. Thats what Apple did with there processors. So they added the graphics and the ram on the cpu giving them an incredible boost in performance. This is why the new Mac Pro looks empty inside because they dont need  to have ram and graphics cards anymore. Only problem with this is... You cant upgrade them. If you ram is now in your processor then its a fixed amount of ram and cant be upgraded. Same with the graphics card and on the X86 side its not so easy because there is nVidia and AMD and what if you like nVidia instead of AMD for your grahics. You can see how it wouldnt be so easy to do on the PC side. Amd also does this but for some reason its not prioritized and I think thats because if AMD did this then they cant sell you a graphics card in addition to a AMD Cpu. I really think this is why Apple is ahead of the game. Since they have no actual compition with the components inside the computer its not a problem for Apple to go this route. Its really given them a true edge because they dont have to rely on anyone to make the cpus anymore. Making the Mac the first true computer made by one company for the mainstream. Yes. Including now the software that runs the computer and now the cpus that run those computers.

Apple made the innovation and is on its way to souring everyone on it. For the most part ARM is known for its bottlenecks, and on phones a perfect storm with low ram, with limited futureproofing.   Apple could make it clear we can move past this era, and with the arm chip they may have, but with nearly everything else they have not.  They've continued the stupid decision to base model at 8fb of ram on a tiny SSD. Which, particularly in combination, cause bottlenecks.  For years users with reasonable use cases have been experiecing this on Apple for awhile. Now with advancement of personal assistant AI that is going to skyrocket, and for normal users too. They are finding Apple Intelligence is going to need 16gb ram on full fledged Mac OS, and most of their users don't have that by Apple's own design. Additonally while clouds are great plenty needs to be cached locally, certain things need to be run locally, so are maxing out the SSD too and in an environment that will increasingly rely on swap.  Then we have the greater software issues with an arch change. I was on Apple at the end of the G4 era and it wad a bit of a software desert. Already MS is backaway and on critical software for things like game compatibility. Even simple things like codecs have a rough time in weird places. RISC
The reality is shortened here so much that it is more like a fairytale. ARM was not the only and not the first RISC architecture; others are SPARC (SUN, Fujitsu), MIPS, PA-RISC (HP) or DEC Alpha. Even Intel had the Itanium. And these were intended for workstations and servers, including supercomputers. ARM at this time - 1980s and 1990s - was more like a toy processor. They just had the better marketing and licensed the architecture to many companies, not producing chips themselves.

Well... I wouldn't bet on the trajectory of Apple Silicon. Remember, the in the early 90s RISC beat CISC. DEC Alpha, MIPS, Power, PowerPC, all outran the 486. 10 years later x86 is about 3x faster than PowerPC and about 10x faster than ARM. By 2016 the tables are turned again. And today (Feb 2025) I see the AMD Zen5 at 40W neck-n-neck with Apple's M4 Pro at 50W. And, in case anyone is wondering, Intel years in the wilderness getting stomped by TSMC from it's 2019 decision NOT to adopt EUV lithography (they eventually did 4 years after TSMC in 2023) may very well be reverse by it's 2024 decision to adopt NA EUV while TSMC passed on it. -- All the trends aside, here's the simple and crude version of what happened. RISC had a tremendous efficiency and performance advantage over CISC in the 90s by having fixed instructional lengths execution cycles. Then CISC chips became RISC chips underneath with fancy ways to translate CISC instructions into RISC like code at the HW level. Meanwhile RISC chips like the PowerPC G5 got very wide and very deep pipelines in order to brute force additional performance. CISC won this round. Then RISC (Apple) took that all that HW level translation nonsense and put it in software like Rosetta and simplified and cleaned-up the CPU itself. RISC is back! Today, CISC is striking back with multiple core types and multiple HW acceleration modules which beat even the most efficient CPU style execution of what matters to the users. And, with the GPU portion of the equation being the power hog both are again even.
Phone will never compare to an equivalent desktop build because of the biggest factor, heat. Desktop can have water cooling while a phone typically doesn't even have a single fan.

for once coldfusion video has many factual errors maybe because i work in the semiconductors chip manufacturing businesses . in real life both intel & apple aka risc, cisc are actually micro-op based, and they have same no of instruction set, so risc aka arm is not actually "redused isc" otherwise it couldn't be 64 bit desktop runable. reason is design & node & macos, aka you can run x86 chip at equivalent 5watt (intel atom) and run arm at 110watts if you want like apple ultra glued pro chips. it is by design . x86 started at 210nm so they stick with more double watt for the last inefficient 20--400 mhz speed aka they run on purpose at 4.7ghz instead of arm running at 3.0ghz at half efficient watt. this is chip design 110% and not actually risc cisc at all  unsubbed

Graphics Cards Either Accelerate DirectX, OpenGL (Old Low Level) or Apples Metal. Software and Hardware are Tied.
Software and Hardware are Tied. Intel/Nvidea, couldn't Simply just Make their Geforce Ti cards Work on the Mac by Releasing Drivers.
Fun fact: the number of instructions in the ARMv8 architecture (incl. ASIMD) is similar to that of the Intel 64 architecture including everything up to AVX2.  It's not ‚Äúbloat‚Äù from ‚Äútoo many instructions‚Äù that makes x86 CPUs harder to scale, but rather factors such as the more complex instruction encoding, intertia from Intel having ridden out the same microarchitecture since the PPro days, differences in the memory model, and better memory latency on tightly integrated SoCs vs. systems with discrete memory and GPU.  Being able to design a whole system more or less from the ground up gave Apple the ability to sidestep many of the design constraints that hobble the existing Wintel ecosystem.
And why it doesn't matter (2024)

is this the downfall of intel? is this the beginnings of an end üò¢
What most people don't realize is that Moore's law is becoming less and less true, the nanometers in the architecture that used to signify some dimension of a transistor on a chip now mean nothing and are for marketing purposes only. There's nothing that is the size of 5nm in 5nm chips as the industry struggles to invent processors that are quicker. It might very well look like x86 might become too difficult to improve further and in order to achieve more computational power we might need to switch architecture to something else, like ARM. The big question is that if Microsoft and Intel are going to be ready for the switch or if they let themselves stagnate as they get overtaken by, for instance Linux which already works on several architectures, including ARM. The big player in the x86 game is Windows and if it doesn't incentivise manufacturers to create ARM components we might get stuck with a single company that figured it out and a bunch that are way late to the party.

You need to include the idiocy and research fraud that is the core of the Ridiculous Instruction Set Computer (RISC). "Prood by massive publication" only proves that CEOs do not read technical publications. And that popular magazines will publish articles with little or no fact-checking. The RISC fraud has cost the industry 100s of millions of dollars. Research on good architectures such as Direct Execution Stack-based designs stopped decades ago. The x86 is essentially the original von Newmann architecture with modern silicon. Look at the GreenArray GA-144 for a less obsolete design.  Also, try writing a program for "The Ultimate RISC Chip" from the ACM SIGArch. It takes about 377 instructions to do a 16-bit add. But it has an amazing clock speed. And every instruction completes in one clock cycle. RISC is about clock speeds, not actual computer performance.
Oh! Wow! Such innovation! Apple takes a standard phone chip and slightly improves the core. Then they step-and-repeating the core more times. And this is supposed to be great "engineering"? What the video got wrong is that CISC wasn't intended to give the computer more features, it was intended to minimize the "semantic gap" between human programmers and assembly back when compiler optimization was primitive and it was assumed all complex programs and OSes would be written in assembly. Now that this isn't the case, those complex instructions just take a lot of time to decode to the operations the transistors implement. RISC also needs decoding but less.
JAK
Okay, you have some serious misconceptions about CISC vs RISC.  I'm going to assume that some of that is just dumbing it down to a presentable level, but some of it is just absolutely wrong.   Firstly, all 'modern' CPUs, whether RISC or CISC have the same sort of superscalar, pipelined core.  The only real difference is that CISC designs use efficient, high-density code that the decoder splits into RISC-like micro-ops that execute at full speed in a fully pipelined manner.  Secondly, a CISC design is usually dispatching and retiring several instructions per cycle.  That old "several cycles" nonsense old data from the 1980s before CISC chips were pipelined and such.  Thirdly, it's "1 BILLION CYCLES PER SECOND", no apostrophe.  One way to think of this is to visualize a modern CISC chip as being a RISC chip with a data compression engine added in front...like a turbocharger.  The reason why pure-RISC designs infected things like smartphones is because the decoder is a heavy chunk of silicon that guzzles electricity, and 'guzzling electricity' doesn't mix well with 'tiny batteries' for what I hope are very effing obvious reasons.  The relative lack of performance isn't a hindrance there.   Well, that, and x86 was actually the second worst CISC design ever.  AMD64/x86-64 helps clear up a lot of the x86 issues, although they have gone a bit bonkers on obscure and semi-useless instructions.
I guess it is just a matter of time until the Windows-world will also have ARM-offerings. Sounds promising. And, can you even begin to imagine, how much energy might be saved, if computers only needed a few percent of the power they currently do?

The key reason is that Apple's MacBook is more closed, while Windows laptops are more open. A simple comparison shows that the molds, systems and chips of Apple's MacBook are designed by Apple itself, and the supply chain of production and manufacturing is also found by Apple itself. Apple's own design is followed from head to toe. Windows notebooks are different. The mold is made by ODM factory, the brand is adjusted according to needs, the system is made by Microsoft, and the chip is divided by Intel, AMD and NVIDIA. At least six companies need various negotiations and contacts to complete a laptop. On the one hand, "one company has the dictatorship", and on the other hand, "a bunch of companies work together". Even though the chip energy consumption ratio is higher and the system optimization is better, "authoritarian closed enterprises" are stronger than "collaborative open cooperation", and the efficiency of energy consumption optimization is not in the same dimension Objectively speaking, although the Windows notebook battery life may never catch up with Apple's MacBook, the battery life also has a "marginal effect".
That speed only happens on brand new gadgets. After 3 years, your system will eventually slow down because apple gradually makes your system obsolete every update.

This video is a little misleading in that you make it seem like x86 dominated for no reason whatsoever. Just a decade or two ago memory was SUPER expensive. CISC/x86 made more sense back then, because RAM was just so limited and expensive to not warrant using RISC.

Just to address the statement if programs not targeting a specific CPU.  This statement are at best, misleading.  Programs today are all compiled from a high level language, some may includes small portions of hand written assembly code, but the the job of targeting specific falls to the compilers optimization fases.  Hence, the targeting in the actual program is not in the source code, but in the compilers backend which are independent of programs being generated. Yes the way you code things in high level languages makes impacts on the performance of the program, but it is more a problem of fitting representation of the programs abstraction well with the languages abstraction. The compiler will generate equivalent performance instruction sequences (they do the same computation) and going from a Cisc to a risc CPU should be way easier in terms of instruction selection strategies, since all Cisc instruction can be simulated by one or more risc instructions.. as long as the compilers selection strategy are good enough it only comes down the raw performance difference in the chips..and the set of instructions are smaller than that of a cisc

Russian IC military chips can put 20 billion, 408 million, and 065,310 transistors in a single 1 square centimeter silicon chip or silicon die at 60 nanometers "for military applications" only. That's 4 billion, 408 million, and 065,310 transistors more than Apples M1 Chip. 60 nanometers is necessary for the high g forces, rapid acceleration spikes, vibrations, shocks, thermal stresses, etc encountered by our missiles and military aircrafts and military spacecrafts. By the way, they use diamonds, not silicon, as the main material and uses maskless laser guided ion beam lithography since the late 1980s and this key strategic research was quietly kept alive by the KGB-GRU FSB Russian Intelligence Security Agency all that time. Mass production of all mass production of the required number of manufacturing industrial factory facilities in small scale form. As opposed to TSMC and SAMSUNG giant factories. The Russians decided to go along the way of the Japanese style of small factories supporting each other. This way everything is mass producible and easily scalable. Because of this approach the Russians were able to place all of their parallel factories underground at a depth of 1,000 to 1,200 meters below the surface of solid rock.

ARM doesn't make chips. They only license the design.  6:20 - Gary Kildall, founder and CEO of Digital Research. The company that dropped the ball when IBM approached them to license Digital Research's CP/M operating system (OS) to run on IBMs future IBM PC. Bill Gates picked up that fumble, and the IBM PC used PC-DOS (same as MS-DOS), and that positioned Microsoft to become the giant, it is now, and Digital Research into a footnote. ARM processors are only more power efficient than X86 processors, but in all other terms they fail miserably.  A Arm processor without multi media extensions like NEON would take forever to encode a video or sound file, while a X86 processor would be able to do so in very little time. The fact of the matter remains, ARM is meant for low power uses like tablets, phones and fridges, whereas the worlds computing needs are powered by X86. Although there has been attempts to use X86 in phones (Asus Zenfone 2 with a Intel Atom Processor), not much has come from it. Although X86 enjoys a much smaller market than ARM, it is still a much better architecture than ARM since there are vastly more tool chains and programming languages available for it, and the most popular desktop operating systems (Windows and Linux) run on ARM without issues. But the one thing that ARM has that X86 will probably never have, is the ability to embed the processor and then use planned obsolesce to convince a user to replace it. X86 systems have gene rally been upgradable (with the exception of some really cheap systems) whereas almost no ARM system has ever been upgradable. The push that ARM is making, is one of replacement instead of upgrade, and this is the worst enemy humanity is facing. Technologies that are so easily replaced, often end up on land fills, destroying the environment, whereas upgradable technologies have the ability to live for decades.

All they did was create a beefy arm chip with decent amounts of cores, gpu and an honestly impressive AI backing.  They made an ARM SoC.  The video stated early on: ARM is a simpler design which is where it gets its efficiency. This simpler design comes with a lot less features and dedicated throughput of what used to be ASICs (which fits the apple motto of dongle death well) and bridges the motherboard supplied in the 90s and early 2000s.   Once you start adding those feature sets (as ARM is beginning to trend) and capabilities like 16 direct to CPU PCIe lanes allowing more than 1gb/s transfer while barely tugging the system - all its going to be is same situation different instruction set.  Basically Apple found a way to go back to the Motorola chip days where they no longer have to support a hell of the possibility of installing their divinity on the savage amd64 core

This is SO MUCH PROPAGANDA ...   Using Pixar's choice of CPU , he says "That proves that intel sucks". UM.  SPARC, SUN's last stand, didn't save SUN , did it ???? You could say that "SPARC KILLED SUN so SPARC sucks".... you just choose not to , you pick and chose your facts and slam intel with them.  But it could just be the situation, that  data crunching didn't need a server room for the mainframes... it could be done on smaller and smaller boxes.. because the RAM  size in the desktop,workstation, the same cpu could also be put into a server room box ... shrinking the cost and size  and watts per gigaflops, of a server/data cruncher. "A quick note - The A14 comparison vs Intel i9 was normalised for single core performance." ... lol .. .we all know that they had to perform better in multicore..windows of course will need a core for itself...
9:20 ... how IGNORANT are you ?  Its the efficiency of the pipelining that will vary.... In the second half of the  1990's  the pentium would do , ON AVERAGE, One instruction per cycle. and some instructions were done two to a cycle, eg a little integer increment and branch back to it loop.  (such as for timing ). The level of pipelining negates your comment about the length of the instruction.   What you are comparing are apples and oranges.   The current effect is that the    I5, I7  and so on  have cache suitable for huge datasets,  and its burning power when underutilised in a desktop or laptop... its quite capable of being a big data crunching  workstation or server....  There are many possible effects going on ... eg the power hunger CPU with a desktops cooling system, might get hot and stall , thus creating the flicker in your graphics... With the ARM, its not going to be possible to consume more power than ordinary usage does, and so the cooling system that tested fine for web browsing will  therefore be fine for the most CPU load producing data crunching.

I know of one difference in architecture between the early Motorola (used by Apple) and Intel was the Intel chip had to outsource the math function to an external chip, then wait for the answer. This was time consuming and generated extra heat.  The Motorola (Mac) chip had this function built-in. Just this one difference made the Mac graphics way better than Intel's.  I also heard that originally, IBM wanted to use the Motorola chip in their first PC release but Motorola couldn't manufacture enough chips to satisfy the order, but Intel could. Can you imagine how that would have changed history?

Hey, I know this is an old video but I just want to clear something up about ARM vs x86. You say at 1:40 that ARM can now do the thing x86 can do, and this is not true, but at the same time has always been true.   Let me explain,  ARM processors can only do very simple operations with a single instruction (RISC), where as x86 can do very complicated operations with a single instruction (CICS). as an example imagine you have to multiply 2 numbers.  on x86, you would just tell the processor to multiply those numbers, but on ARM, you would have to tell the processor to do a few additions, and a few bit shift operations.  both versions will take a similar amount of time, but x86 defines that process on a hardware level, while ARM defines that process through software.   This is where the modern day comes in. In previous years, it was more cost efficient to design those processes into the processor itself, vs defining the processes through software and requiring massive ram + HD to do the same thing, but now with the increase in storage capabilities of computers, it has begun to make sense to remove the extra hardware to do those operations, and instead define them with more complicated software. The other important thing to note about ARM is that, because of how much larger binaries are, more information needs to be quickly accessible by the cpu in order to feel snappy. This doesn't matter as much on phones, because you don't really multitask in the same way that you would on a workstation, but it becomes more apparent on PCs. Because of this, ARM needs a really large cache when compared to x86, which adds another layer of difficulty and power draw from DRAM that isn't really mentioned here. On a laptop meant for consumers, this probably isn't a huge deal, but this is a big deal on a workstation because it will require more cache to feel as fast as x86, and the power savings ARM has may not be as significant.  The other modern day advancement that is allowing ARM to compete with x86 is compilers getting much better. Before, compiling to ARM would not be very efficient especially when compared to x86, so you would get slower operations in a program, but now compilers have gotten so optimized and so powerful, that they CAN compile to the much more complicated  RISC instructions.  The other compiler limitation is the compile time. You are compiling to many more instructions, so the compilers take much longer to finish. This isn't a big deal with most open source software, but for large programs (think windows, linux, macos, autocad, fc, photoshop ect) where millions of lines of code are involved, and compile times are already going to be like 30 - 40 minutes on massive server farms, this becomes to be a problem. This has gotten better in recent years, but is still a massive barrier to RISC becoming dominant. Imagine being a programmer and having to wait 20 - 30 minutes on a partial compile every time you want to test something.  This is offset recently by compilers, again, getting more optimized, and hardware getting better, but will still be a limiting factor.   A good way to think of RISC vs CISC or ARM vs x86 is that with x86, most of the work is done on the processor, while with ARM, the work is outsourced to the cache, RAM, HD, software and software developers. This is why ARM is "faster" in theory, and why it can get away with less power consumption, but even now 2 years after this chip came out, we still see the industry moving to ARM desktops very slowly, and not rapidly.  So TLDR: ARM has always technically been able to do everything x86 can do, but only recently have compilers, ram, and storage caught up enough to enable ARM to do so, and while RISC is awesome, it is not a catch all super technology, and has it's own limitations and trade-offs.

You are, and all the people in the video, comparing apples (pun intended) with oranges. All the comparisons shown are not true comparisons. They may look like they are doing the same thing. The central ideas in the video all are in the ballpark of correct. But the explanations bounce like a pinball between the fringes of oversimplification and misinterpretation. Example for the first is 14:15: you can use more than 4 GB of RAM in a 32-bit system, but *a single process* cannot make use of more than 4 GB because that's the maximum address space with 32 bit. Example for the latter is 2:55, comparing Photoshop on x86 with whatever GPU offloading (apparently none) to Lightroom which is targeted at users sensible to UX more than image processing finesse ... Brrppf. Well! Yes, it's a fair observation, but that's not an effect of ARM vs. x86 CISC. The requirements engineers did a better job for Lightroom than for Photoshop. But that's a far more complicated story to tell, so ... **sigh** ... Carry on, I guess?

Short term answer: because it‚Äôs apple
*ARM was the SECOND Generation of RISC processors: I ws coding on RISC in the 79's, on commercial, homebrew, and SBC products.  In fact, the late comer to the industry, IBM, had a RISC machine for sale: The IBM "Junior".  The Junior failed miserably, but not because of RISC. It failed for a variety of reasons: it was poorly implemented by IBM, it was not code compatible with the popular x86 architecture, and CISC at the time was far more powerful. There were others as well, but this was the big three that caused it's loss to x86.*  *The second generation ARM chips were totally  different from prior RISC: it was a watershed moment in computing, and it rapidly became the standard for critical non-graphical applications like routers, switches, etc.  The ISP//Networking industry had literally no use for x86 in their network infrastructure, while x86 owned home computing.  The PowerPC shared some of the ARM space, and for a short while took a good share of the server space, but ARM just kept getting better and better, and now here we are with the M1.*
It's funny that the "PC fangirls" always hate on Apple and even spread the myth that their products are too expensive. Yet, the 27" iMac for example was always a fantastic bargain for what you got. I used to build PCs for a decade and got sick of them, switched to an iMac and not only was it the same price as building my own PC (not a cheap gaming PC but high end comparable PC with similar parts and a high end IPS monitor, high end keyboard, mouse, and software), the iMac had a way better monitor, better warranty, way better tech support than I could ever get with independent parts (and much better than any company like Dell, yuck).  Additionally as an example the flagship iPhones cost less now than the flagship Samsungs. And the iPads are actually bang for the buck far better than their competition (really the only direct competition are the new high end Samsungs which again are MORE expensive than the iPads and are way behind in CPU/GPU performance).

Boycott all Apple products!
I sure hope that Apple does inspire competition, ARM and the M1 chip in particular are impressive but I absolutely do not like Apple as a company.  Apart from questionable business practices, their hardware does a lot to strip away options from the customer.  It's ironic because they did the hard part of incorporating more efficient processors into their produucts but then they screw it up when it comes to easy choices they could have made to benefit the consumer.    For example, look at the Iphone.  No model that I've ever used comes with a removable battery, so you can't simply buy a replacement battery when it ages.  You have to send the whole device in for a custom and more expensive replacement for their proprietary internal battery.  So you're paying for the battery and the labor for installing the battery when it should be as simple as just snapping a new battery in yourself when you need to.     They've also decided again and again not to allow the customer to increase storage space on their phones by having the option to insert Micro-SD cards.   If you want more storage space, you're forced into either buying a new phone or using cloud storage that's dependent on having a DATA or Wifi connection.   Yet again there's a problem when it comes to simply being able to copy and paste files from Phone to PC.  I've never had an Iphone where copying music was as simple as just copying files from folder to folder.  I quit using Iphones in part due to my dislike for Itunes.  When it comes to full sized computers, most MACs don't let you upgrade the ram or graphics card yourself if you decide you need a performance boost, which is another disadvantage to Apple products.  Lastly, and this one isn't entirely Apples fault, but there's an obvious compatibility issue with a LOT of software.  Outside of mobile Apps, Currently most computer software and AAA games are programed and marketed for PCs with AMD or INTEL chips first and foremost.  For example, even if you look at console games that are released for Playstation or XBOX, the games that are ported to computer typically go to Windows based PCs and are less likely to see official releases on MacOS.    So credit where credit is due to Apple for impressive leaps in hardware technology, but at the end of the day you get far more flexibility with Android phones and far more flexibility and options on PCs when compared to Apple based computers. Personally I'd take that over the minor performance boost you get (in some situations) by using an Apple product.  I would agree though that Intel needs to start simplifying and innovating with their processors NOW.  If Apple were to resolve the issues I've mentioned, they could leave other companies in the dust.  Even Android is starting to repeat some of Apples mistakes by, for example, not having removable batteries on a lot of their newer phones.  So we'll see what happens in the future.

9:28 - "Simplified CPU's, such as ARM, generally will do one single instruction per clock cycle.  While desktop chips may use many cycles to complete one complex instruction.  This means more power consumption, less efficiency, and more heat produced."  ...No.  Both types of CPUs mostly use simple instructions that take one clock cycle.  However, desktop CPUs offer many extra instructions that the ARM does not.  For an ARM (RISC) to perform equivalent complex tasks, it must string together long sequences of instructions.  Not only that, but a desktop CPU is loaded with specialized hardware acceleration to make it's complex instructions execute even faster.  This means the RISC requires far more clock cycles for complex tasks.  RISCs are successful because those complex instructions are rarely needed.  Usually, CPUs just shovel data as fast as they can.  And in that contest, a RISC wins easily.

It seems like maybe a partial reason for the sucess of the CISC/Intel/x86 architechture, is that is is much more favorable for building in hidden native access for three-letter agencies along with other shadow groups. But that's none of my business though. Just a thought. Which would also allow for masking the extra CPU load. Where as an ARM architechture would become noticably slower with the extra load of a "hidden" user being active while the regular user is operating a particular device. So, I really don't think it was by accident that x86 maintained mainstream popularity.

This is so full of shit. The SoC is available in micro computers for a very long time, all Apple did was scale it up to their laptops size. The point you're missing is that it's impossible to expand their memory, replace parts and add storage without either buying a new one, or connecting external components. This is nothing new, and the whole reason why PC industry is not doing that is the fact that it's not scalable as a solution. You have to manufacture end product in certain quantities and sell them. SoC also has its drawbacks, and that's why it took them so long to get to release point, as they require 10x more testing than any scalable solution, due to the same reasons that any error in design or architecture can't be fixed by replacing a single part of it. Apple fanboys will always be fanboys - always missing the bigger picture. Now try to repair broken laptop with M1 - this is exactly what Apple was aiming at - you just can't ! I will never support Apple.

ARM CHIPS changed the INDUSTRY - NOT APPLE!
So many things wrong with the video...the analysis is about 2" deep. Clearly CF doesnt understand the internals of a CPU. 1) there haven't been internal CISC x86 chips for around 20+ years. The argument of CISC vs RISC is moot - its all RISC, just in x86 there is a decoder block that takes about 3-5% of the CPU power (hence the loss in efficiency) 2) x86 architectures goal is peak performance / ARM is efficiency - we still see that x86 outperforms ARM in this aspect hence Mac Pro's use Intel Xeon (server grade) chipsets 3) PassMark Intel vs AMD CPU Benchmarks - High End - > find Apple M1, it is middling performance looking at comparable CPUs 4) About your friends Hackintosh...I made one way back, and they have serious deficiencies based on the fact your using hacked OS w/ hardware that isnt optimized for the OS. I would never compare performance of software on a hackintosh to a legit mac, makes no sense, not to mention the fact he was comparing a 2019 3950X to a 2020/21 Apple M1 Pro - which btw, the 3950X still outperforms the M1 by a factor of nearly 2 in aggregate scores. 5) The greatest tech advancement in the last decade is all SSD related - in the last 5 years, we went from 6GB/S top end SSDs to now 300+GB/S SSDs. Thats a nearly 50X improvement. Its not even a discussion really - all CS is pretty much in agreement that most improvement in performance has been related to memory, not CPU or GPU, though between those two, GPU beats CPU by a large margin.

It isnt "simple instruction sets" it is "reduced instruction sets" and tho faster they cannot handle "threads" like an Intel and they cannot multitask and use other channels in the same CPU. Even tho the risc-based chips have multiple cores, they cannot operate independently as can an Intel chip.

Apple owe their success to open source. The main reason behind every other reason (they have their merits too), that allowed them to innovate this much, is their foundation: BSD, Unix, Darwin, Mach, NeXSTEP. These open source or partly open source projects were/are lean and are written in highly optimized, low level code. This is why Microsoft's Windows will never run as fast as macOS on same-class ARM hardware (and it's been proven when MS tried and failed).

answer = they are kind of ASIC + on 5nm. ASICs are like Linux distros, a headache for developers and consumers alike. They need streamlining, of some sort of standardization, but are great for application-specific tasks. The M-5's designer, Dr. Daystrom, was asked what happened to the M-1 through M-4 computer. Daystrom said that these had problems, and were discontinued, culminating in the M-5.

Way back in the 1980s our own scientists said that they can compensate the limitations of the early ARM-RISC IC chips by using it in a customized "PARALLEL PROCESSING" computer architecture based motherboard. They did it by hand and it worked! But it was during the Cold War when this was achieved and everything was just simply covered up and carefully preserved, mothballed, stored carefully and the original scientists (all of whom are still alive) went on with their Baikal IC Chips, then came the collapse of the Soviet Union and the chief leading scientist of the Baikal microprocessor project (he is not involved in the project of the younger generation of scientists at that time of using ARM-RISC IC chips in a customized "PARALLEL PROCESSING" computer architecture based motherboard) was pirated by Intel and this Russian scientist practically used his military IC chip technology to boost the Intel Chip into becoming the number one IC chip in the desktop and laptop computers. During the early years of the 2000s the "TRANSMETA" IC chip was developed and it was again used in the same early versions of the customized "PARALLEL PROCESSING" computer architecture based motherboard and it still worked wonderfully.

This video is pure marketing with lots of glossy language and vague claims. Mobile equates to lower wattage and so reduced GHz. Few real time tasks are directly related to GHz and those that arn't have been highlighted in this video. Most relate to graphics performance, which are not performed in desktop processors. The M1 ARM processor is very good and presents a reduced heating performance. (although my iphone can still cook when apps are not closed!)  Suggesting this is the resurgence of RISC, using very selective graphics tasks will not equate to the demise of the existing desk-top multi-core/simd architecture, where ultra low wattage is not a requirement.

RISC dominated data and graphics processing right up until the 2000's.  At one point every major gaming console was using IBM's RISC processor.  In fact, the CISC chips only became ascendant as Microsoft  adopted the IBM PC architecture.  The creation of Linux really put a damper on the RISC architecture.  Intel CISC processors had become a commodity and Sun Microsystems and IBM had treated their RISC procs as high-end, high-cost offerings.  It's nice to see the RISC model having a comeback.
Very interesting presentation. I bought my first 486 100MHz Intel PC with 2MB of RAM in 1990 or about that time. A few years later I replaced that PC with a Intel Pentium 75MHz based PC with 4MB of RAM. Today, I have a Dell PC with a 3rd generation i5 Intel processor and 16GB of RAM, a dedicated AMD graphics card and 1TB mechanical hard drive. The performance was not great, very disappointing to say the least. Then a miracle took place. I cloned the Windows 10 installation from the mechanical hard drive to a Micron Crucial 3D nand SSD. The performance increase was dramatic proving that the bottleneck was not the aged i5 processor, but the mechanical hard drive.

A few factual nitpicks here- ARM was not the first RISC: Sun Microsystems, Hewlett Packard & Digital Equipment Corp all brought out RISC platforms around the same time as Acorn. They all cameout of MIPS and the Berkeley uni RISC project.  Secondly, The Apple A12 etc aren't really ARM any more, they are optimised for phone/tablet use, hence why they outperform ARM which remains a general purpose processor that can function in IoT, Automotive, Industrial etc embedded systems not just Android. Apple has developed a bespoke ARM which is optimised for iPhone/iPad not much else. Not sure if taking the same route with M1 for computational use is going to yield the expected result everywhere. Definitely appreciate that it is much less power-hungry but Intel is still on 10nm SOS. When they get to 5nm like M1 (and SOS will always mean they are a process node behind TSMC and their bulk CMOS) then there will be a like-for-like (almost said apples vs apples :) ) comparison.
Trouble is, latest M1 Macs can't run Autocad/Solidworks/etc.  My student son has a old Dell R520 i5 that was obsolete for me, and it still gobbles up Solidworks for him whereas his classmates can't run on their fancy new M1 Macs.  Running on Parallels or a virtual machine for M1 is grindingly slow. It will  be years before they build up M1 code for niche programs, especially when i86 runs it perfectly well.  Who cares, even on a laptop, if it drains the battery in a few hours.  The battery efficiency of M1 is no use if you can't run the program you need.

There something wrong when M1 so close of beating Intel and AMD chips in most tasks.
In my computer architecture class, a common question was, which is more recent, CISC or RISC, and almost everyone got that one wrong. People naturally assume whatevers more complicated must be more "advanced" or newer, when no, it turns out the innovation isn't making it more complicated, but doing more things with less instructions. Thats what the innovation is. That lesson ought to be applied to lots of things :)

Apple's final problems to solve are upgradability and serviceability. The Intel desktop computer is easily serviceable. Desktop components can be swapped out and upgraded on the fly, thus reducing repair cost. Open-ended software guarantees that third-party software writers can examine the instruction code and rewrite the code for greater efficiency. Yes, even if Apple computers achieve the position of the best and fastest computers in the world, that will not mean much if you are hamstrung by a closed architecture system and high repair cost. Yes, I like Apple's improved speed. I also like the fact that I can upgrade the components in my desktop without costing me an "ARM" and a leg.

How many times can you change "everything" ?
Apple is not actually using ARM designs except for the ARM Instruction Sets.  Apple licensed the rights to create ARM clones that can run the same instructions as ARM64 but everything else can be completely unique to Apple's designs. This is why Apple's mobile SoC processors are dominating over Snapdragon and other ARM mobile processors.  They can manage power at each section of the System on Chip (SoC) but also right down to individual transistors.

M1 is like asics that are far faster in certain tasks than a typical intel and amd chip. Because it doesn't support extended instructions like AVX2 or AVX 512 compared to amd or an intel chip. They can't do many things a desktop processor does. They are optimized for general use and only the general use. If you are a low end programmer you don't want an apple chip cause you can't compile extended instructions on m1. Likewise asics run so much faster because they only do one thing and one thing only just like gpus can perform simple tasks so much faster compared to a desktop processor. M1 hasn't changed anything. TSMC changes everything. And intel or amd can easily produce the same level of performance for much cheaper and efficient than apple does if they abandon avx instructions which take a lot of die space. M1 is a half decent cpu that is fast in certain workloads but it can't perform everything a desktop processor does. It's an arm based cpu and it should remain as arm based. Everybody ignores how hard it is to support every single instruction set while maintaining competitive performance. No apple does not beat intel or amd. It's far from that....

9:26 "Simplified CPUs such as ARM generally will do one simple instruction per clock cycle, while Desktop CPUs may use many cycles to complete one complex instuction" ??? Absolutely not. What is that even supposed to mean? x86 processors can do complex instuctions in a single cycle, while ARM would have to use multiple cycles to do the same. That's literally what 'reduced instruction set' means. The reason ARM chips are more power efficient ist because they are slower and smaller than x86 chips.

Try a Wolfram Mathematica benchmark on the Intel Mac Mini and the new M1 Mac Mini. Intel still wipes the floor with the M1. The M1 is 3 TIMES SLOWER in matrix multiplication, which is a very important operation. Apple Silicon does not have AVX (advanced vector extensions) nor the highly optimized Intel Math Kernel Libraries that Intel CPUs have. The same is true for AMD. Neither Apple nor AMD nor ARM have built decent math libraries for linear algebra. Apple Silicon is for toddlers with Fischer Price laptops (with the level of intelligence of i-Justine) as far as I am concerned.  ARM is great for low power compute, but ARM needs to create better optimized math libraries if they want ARM to be used for anything relating to high performance computing or scientific computing.

The main issue with ARM in the past, is that it required "way more memory" than the CISC CPUs, and memory was really expensive. CISC CPUs required less memory, so it made them better (and cheaper). But as technology got better, prices for memory went down, and opened the door to the possibility of using RISC CPUs (such as ARM) more freely, to the point that today, when memory "is not important", it can be implemented.  I never liked Apple in general. Besides the Ipod, I've always thought it was an overpricing company with not that much innovation. Until they came with the M1. The new M1 may be super powerful, but not that useful. And don't get me wrong. I think it won't be that useful because of the other side of the coin: The software. The problem with disruptive technologies is that the market needs a time to adapt to it. And that's why I think the M1 may be an "undermined" CPU. But I expect that by the time of the M2 or M3, the world will have adapted and we'll be dropping the CISC system (x86-64, AMD64).  Lastly, next disruptive change I guess will most likely be quantum computing CPUs.

In the last few years, we've seen mobile technology surpass desktop/laptop technology. So, putting "mobile-powered" chips into desktop class devices seemed crazy at first, but with M1, we've seen a remarkable level of power with no compromise to battery life. Something we've already witnessed for years with the iPhone and iPad's A-powered silicon chips. M1 has literally pushed the computer industry forward to depths and realms that we could've only dreamt of just a few years ago.

Pros to arm chips they are simpler and less power consuming. Cons they have less cores meaning overall less computing power. However how apple gets around this is by manipulating the software to prioritize loading of important background tasks like pre loading frequently used apps. They dedicate 2 cores to these tasks. I'd view it like this loading times, battery life, and  video software apps will get a significant boost. The issue comes when these chips are asked to preform specialized tasks like graphical performance and particle effects. For your average user it's gonna be great

Main difference between phones and computers isn't just processor.  Mobile app ecosystems, from the system OS to the apps it hosts, run primarily in the cloud by design. Desktop apps rely primarily on the internals of the host machine. Mobile apps are optimized for efficiency at the expense of features. Desktop apps are optimized for utility at the expense of energy, heat and storage space. Mobile ecosystems themselves are also sold with an entirely different business model in mind. They primarily serve as Big Brother devices in your pocket to mine you for metadata that can be sold to data brokers. Desktop computers, not so much.  So, the main difference between mobile and desktop platforms is design philosophy not hardware. Mobile devices are optimized for efficiency and mass market appeal in order to herd you into a particular ecosystem so you can be sold services and accessories. Desktop devices are primarily utilitarian and are optimized for power use.  It kind of irks me to misrepresent the difference between the two as being merely a hardware discussion. Far from it. The hardware is kind of irrelevant. The real discussion is what are these devices for. What is the business model behind them. How do people use them. What is the design philosophy behind them.

this video is mostly wrong. first a RISC process does not significantly improve over CISC, it only advantageous in some aspects. I mean we all used DEC and Sun MIPS R series in the 1990s. Given AMD and M1 use TSMC which would have at best 7-5nm technology, it means that the heat and power used per transistor is the same for Intel, AMD and M1 under same load. In addition, the very simple error made in video encoding is that video encoding should never be done on a multicore CPU like the threadripper or i9 series chips as encoding video is a single core CPU process, meaning the other cores are just standing idle, and the comparison video of video editing on the iphone is clearly wrong - as it is NOT encoding a video but simply cutting a MP4 video and re-mux it, my PC can do this in under 10secs. To actually re-encode a video means that every 4K frame needs to be re-rendered, which is impossible for a phone to do, and even with dedicated hardware, which a phone does not have, the amount of power required to re-encode a 4K video is based on the conservation of energy, ie. things dont automagically defy the laws of physics, to transform a set of data into another set of given magnitiude, ie. it comes with corresponding work energy required - yes, you are defying the laws of thermodynamics.  anyway, enough of this video, so many obvious errors.

It's nitpicking, but I disagree with one statement. Apple putting a mobile chip in their best selling computer (which happens to be a mobile device) hardly seems stupid considering laptops have used mobile versions of CPUs for a long time now..
This is the step we were all waiting for really. I know i am 9 months too late to comment, but the situation is the CPU industry (for desktop pcs) were stuck really since the MMX instruction set introduced. The next development was to introduce new cores and interoperability between these cores, but in general we've got the same thing just more on one die.  the introduction if core iX (3,5,7,9) isn't really a revolution but was more or less finetuning the existing kit.  What i mean is that in IT we see paradigm shifts on every aspect of our lives. HDD changing from spinning disks to chips (ssd), displays moving from CRT to flat panels, printers moving from typewriter things to insane fast laser printing, network connection to grow from serial connection to gigabit speed fiber and so on. And yet the CPU was more or less the same through out.  Of course there are things which can not change really (like how a speaker works..) but the CPU is not as simple as a pair coiled copper wire and a fixed magnet and a cone.   while i still think Apple is going nuts with the pricing, and going against the environment (right to repair, creating more packaging through selling basic stuff separately, thus creating more waste) - this move was long overdue and for that they deserve all the credits.  I just wish AMD would follow through and combine forces with Microsoft to bring the same revolution to the Windows market. (i am not wishing anything bad to apple - i still use their products, but we need this revolution on Windows too - and this time not just microsoft trying to do a half-ass*d copy of Apple but frankly shifting from x86 with a proper chip manufacturer)
I'm not a fan of apple, but they are doing great work. I'm also just glad to witness such advancements. God speed.
Bravo! And shake on Intel. Intel is going the way of the Big Blue.

Oh boy.... RISC vs CISC is a distinction that became irrelevant long ago, as RISC architectures added more instructions, and CISC architectures actually became more RISC-like under the hood. Modern CPUs, whether RISC or CISC, break down instructions into multiple steps, which are then sent to various parts of the CPU for execution. And here‚Äôs the thing: one under-the-hood implementation can be radically different from another implementation, _even if they use the same instruction set._  And that‚Äôs how Apple‚Äôs ARM chips can be so vastly superior to, say, Qualcomm‚Äôs, despite using the same instruction set: Apple‚Äôs under-the-hold implementation is evidently far superior. It‚Äôs not because it‚Äôs RISC, or even that it‚Äôs ARM. If that were true, all ARM processors would be similarly powerful, and they‚Äôre clearly not.

16:11 this is very misleading. You can‚Äôt compare software vs hardware h.264 or h.265 encoding.  Hardware is more for real-time streaming. File size is bigger and/or quality suffers. Software encoding will produce the smallest/highest quality video but takes way more time. Intel has a hardware h.264 encoder on their CPUs since their 2nd gen Core i3/5/7 processors (Sandy Bridge). It is also obscenely fast when compared to software encoding. Everything else about your video has been eye opening and very interesting, but to include that clip is extremely misleading.
Thank your videos. Please don't stop making videos.
A couple of points.  Another video I watched stated that Acorn computer tried to source CPUs from Intel back in the 1980s, but were too small at the time to get Intel to return their calls.  That is one reason why Acorn created the ARM instruction set in the first place.  A second point was the part of this video which compared a Fujitsu supercomputer to an IBM.  I don't know exactly which supercomputers you were referring to, but IBM's fastest supercomputers typically have IBM Power CPUs installed which are also RISC chips.  I suspect the difference would be even greater comparing the Fujitsu supercomputer to an Intel-based supercomputer if the IBM one did have Power CPUs.
Apple is still shit tho
@Cold Fusion: Though informative, the picture you paint a very unfair and oversimplified account of Intel: The real fly in ointment, is‚Ä¶ AMD (I am going to be burned by the uninformed). Let me explain‚Ä¶  Everyone that knew anything about CPU architectures, already knew before the turn of the millennium, that the 20+ year old (At that time already) x86 passed its shelf live, including Intel. Indeed, the P6 (Pentium Pro/Pentium 2 and later Pentium 3) was supposed to be the last x86 processors. Don‚Äôt believe me? After the failed P7 (Pentium 4), the Intel Core was a reiteration of the P6 and all Core processors since has been incremental updates of the P6.  So, what did Intel plan instead? Well, as your video pointed out, the x86 is a bloated CISC - Complex Instruction Set Computer, and ARM (Like IBM Power, Sun SPARC, MIPS etc) are Reduced Instruction Set Computers. But both CISC and RISC have and inherent problem (Which one of your graphs actually also show): Their performance tapers off over time (Albeit RISC tapering off at a higher level that CISC). The problem is that both RISC and CISC struggle very hard to scale linearly with parallel tasks: That is why all the top super computers of the last number of years make very extensive use of GPUs which, by its very nature, can scale much more linearly with parallel tasks (As albeit, cannot function without a CPU to control it).  What Intel wanted to do was replace x86 with a much, much better architecture than both RISC and CISC that would scale much more linearly over multiple tasks, for a CPU architecture. This architecture was known as Explicitly Parallel Instruction Computer, or EPIC. This was released under the Intel Itanium brand. This is where the problems however started very unfortunately because people were soo short-sighted.  The first Itanium was slow: This was because it intentionally contained a bloated CISC x86 for backward compatibility - Something Intel were forced to do because it, unlike Apple, are not vertically integrated (Like Android/Microsoft Windows) and was as a result, ridiculed by short-sighted media.  At the same time, AMD (The milly-vinlly of the industry), seizing the gap that the well thought out Intel‚Äôs future plan left with the Itanium, went and did the worst thing for the industry imaginable (And were praised by the same short-sighted media for doing so): They added 64-bit instructions to the, what should‚Äôve been, the defunct x86 instructions. By doing this, they forced the industry down an already over extended x86 path for another 20+ years (This was around the 2000‚Äôs). But everyone was buying into this hype because they could blow Intel out of the water with x86 which Intel did not want to support either.  This left Intel in a situation where it needed to refocus all its efforts on the deprecated x86 and support the newly AMD added 64bit x86 instructions (Which AMD falsely claimed was the first 64bit x86 - Indeed the Intel P5, the original Pentium, was already 64bit internally, just did not have 64bit instructions). This led the, very unfortunate, eventual demise of the Itanium (Which then never got traction as the industry just took the easy route with the crappy AMD 64bit x86 extensions).  And here is the kicker, which this article also failed to mention: For the same reason Intel had to refocus back to x86 and let Itanium slide, Intel also had to let their ARM processor design go. YES, INTEL INDEED HAD ARM PROCESSORS OF THEIR OWN, this was called the Intel xScale (Don‚Äôt believe me, read: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/XScale). Intel sold the xScale CPU to Marvel Technologies in 2006 (But is still one of the best ARM designs).   Now, Intel, right after selling its xScale ARM, why would Intel redevelop a ARM for Apple? It literally just lost its ARM design?   PS: And Intel had other RISC processors too, like the i860 and i960
I think Intel is a lot like the Swiss watch makers many decades ago facing the influx of quartz timepieces.  They had simply looked down on the new technology and stuck with their own old way.

The chip alone made me tempted to switch to IPhone.
I recently bought a ASUS ROG Zephyrus Ryzen 7 4800HS based laptop with a 1660Ti GPU and 16GB of DDR4 memory for video streaming/editing purposes. When I saw the benchmarks for the M1 MBP I had to get one for myself to see how it performed, so I picked up a base config model with 8GB of RAM. I figured the Zephyrus with its dedicated GPU and 16 thread processor would unquestionably be faster, but the M1 would be able to hold its own and come within maybe 10-15% of the PC's performance.¬† *Not even close!* When streaming, the Zephyrus would stay around 20% utilization (with fans as loud as a hair dryer after a few minutes). The M1 MBP stayed between 7-8%, all while remaining virtually silent. An hour long stream would leave me with about 45% battery capacity on the ASUS, and 85% on the Mac. Rendering video was a total blowout. Projects that took _6-7_ hours on the PC were completing in _2_ on the M1! I was so disappointed in the Zephyrus that I had to sell it.
The M1 chips from Apple aren‚Äôt the first versions of their own chip design, but it‚Äôs the 11th Generation of their own chip design.  Apple purchased the basis of the Arm code and they compiled it to their own specifics.

Including RAM in the SoC gives a huge performance benefit, but the drawbacks of the smallest RAM models, while often not noticed in performance thanks to efficient SoC and fast swap to SSD, are starting showing in shortened SSD life, as frequent swap is a real silent killer for them. And no, it doesn't just happen using very power hungry SW, but also using many programs at a time, or even keeping lots of web pages open. Apple sadly has little control on how RAM hungry web browsers have become.
Your arguments about M1 chip being the fastest is simply not true. Also bench mark testing shows that AMD chip outperformed ARM chip which uses about 15% more power than ARM. Your arm usage of 5W is when it is idle. Furthermore, ARM chip are limited in terms of what one can do with. It is the nature of RISC based architecture versus CISC based one. each one has it's own merit, but stating that ARM CPUs are better than X86 CPU in terms of power consumption and performance is simply misleading..

The PowerPC was a RISC system just like ARM. The problem was that IBM & Motorola were not able to maintain process improvement comparable to what Intel could afford. That is what Steve Jobs had Apple transition from the Power PC (RISC) to intel X86 (CISC). As for power, you need to read the article about the death of Moore's Law which appeared in Spectrum several years ago. Formerly, X8^ processors were doubling clock speed every 18 months or so. So, a bit of Apple History 6502 (CISC) -> 680X0 (CISC) -> Power PC (RISC) -> Intel (CISC) -> MX (RISC).

the truth is that this has more to do with Intel fucking up hard than anything else and some microsoft. intel had no real competitor for +10  years, and is even questionable if they truly ever had competitors to start with. they had the money, thus could invest more. there was no room for anyone else in the market.   then mobile phone market appeared, and during the last 10 years the players in mobile industry faced monstrous pressure to outdo each other while getting massive amounts of money. while that intel did a ~10%(if that) performance increase per year sitting on their throne.  then you add the very special fact that making a chip more energy efficient is very close to make the chip better in every aspect, something Intel itself knows since they ditched pentium 4 architeture and went ahead with their made for laptop pentium pro architecture 12 years ago, then... is pretty obvious what happened.  it has very little to do with arm or risc or x86. a lot of that baggage went away with x64 anyway and a bunch of rarely used instructions are implemented only in microcode  and some of it has to do with microsoft as well, a system designed for a single cpu/gpu soc runs much better than your pc which is made to run with whatever hodgepodge of hardware running low level driver code of whatever quality? wow call me surprised.   microsoft seems to be giving zero fucks how well windows machines runs for a while, direct X10 and 11 were inefficient bloated messes with MS having no interest in doing anything to it to the point it classified direct x as a "legacy" technology at some points. their efforts since XP seems to be pushing whatever angle they can get to leverage their user base than actually making a good OS. it was only when AMD made mantle, a reasonable low level way to interact with GPUs that was not garbage that MS went "wait a minute!", got mantle from amd, gave it a coat of paint and released it as direct X12.

Great video.  One thing that was elided that might be worthy of a similar video is the role of TSMC in the realization of the tech.  Their manufacturing prowess is apparently tremendous, though I've heard they're incredibly secretive.  Without their bleeding edge factories, Apple might have had a much harder time getting this to market this quickly and seemingly painlessly (can you imagine the potential infighting if Samsung remained their top chip supplier?).  Notably, TSMC also makes a majority or plurality of the non-Intel chips the world over, so they're the ones baking the silicon for many of our devices and all the IoT devices everywhere.
ARM still kinda failed in other than Apple, yet it's important for those ARM chip makers to learn from Apple M1 capability. may wait the time they can compete back with Apple.

CISC isn't bloated per say. CISC actually has a memory advantage, any given set of operations takes more memory to describe in RISC than CISC. Back in the day memory cost was significant, so much so any performance loss was irrelevant. Much of the power savings achieved by M1 comes at the expense of limited ram and limited expandability (think PCIE lanes,) fine for a phone or a tablet but lacking for laptops and desktops. Single threaded numbers for M1 are impressive but seriously lacking for multithreaded performance. AMD and Apple are lapping Intel, it's not as if there aren't competitive x86 processors.

Great video
In 1996, I built a computer, using a dual CPU motherboard. I put an Intel Processor on one socket, and an ARM CPU on the other. The differences between the two were unreal in terms of performance, power consumption, and generating heat. Most of the time, the Intel processor was so hot that one could fry an egg on top of it while the ARM chip stayed 'cool' when under the same load. However, and most notably, the performance (speed) of the ARM was many times faster than the Intel, opening applications like Word and Excel literally instantly. Now, that is now 25 years ago and it is overwhelming that Apple took so long to produce the M1.   Although the ARM technology was neglected for so long in the Laptop and Desktop market, the differences, and the possibilities, this technology promises, are beyond our current understanding. Let's embrace ARM as a worthy contender while we all know that 'Quantum CPU's' will not power our lap and desktops any time soon.
I don't have a single Apple product but appreciate the wrecking ball they've put into the Intel/AMD drama and possibly changing the trajectory of computing in a seismic way,  Ravi Peiris M.D.

Junk
I don't have an issue with anything that is said in this video but it has missed a key point.  It isn't just the RISC instruction set that is important.  When ARM licenses its technology to other OEMs, it is the core that is licensed (mostly) and the OEM then integrates their IP around that core making a device unique for a purpose.  This is exactly what Apple have done and is what gives them the edge.  Look at the video - there are a couple of instances where the video highlights sections of a motherboard and then fades that down to an image of the M1 chip.  This is the key.  Apple have integrated the most important functions (for them) around an ARM core making an entire system-on-a-chip which is fine-tuned for its purpose.  With Intel, on the other hand, you can't do this.  The CPU is what Intel decides to design - you get what you're given - the OEM's IP has to be built onto a motherboard outside of the CPU chip itself. The other subtlety is that companies like Intel are always projecting 10 years or so into the future in order to try to predict what workloads computers will be expected to handle.  This, in turn, impacts their design roadmap.  But what if Intel's predictions don't pan out or they are simply not consistent with where Apple want's its products to go?  What would Apple do?  Well, they would do exactly what they have just done.
STOP. The M1 CPU might be very good but that doesn't mean the M1 Mac is well designed. Quite the contrary! Comparing a M1 Mac vs an Intel Mac shows that in average the M1 Mac writes 20 times as MUCH data to its SSD in average. Problem? Yes! This could mean that your M1 Mac has a lifetime of between 11 months and 2 years only. An Intel Mac can boot from an external SSD, but the M1 cannot - so you can throw out your precious M1 after that period!!! (Remember that this "excellent design" has its SSD soldered onto the motherboard!). See: "M1 Mac SSD Wear Issue Tested and Explored. Yes, it's a problem" = https://youtu.be/e8aCgnb_RQs .  Next, the M1 CPU is good, but its not the best or fastest on the market, see Chris Titus test = https://youtu.be/bdQ7u0mR570 .  Also check-out Louis Rossmann's videos. He has made a living out of repairing Apple products and knows all about (1) Apple's anti-repair design and (2) their continued engineering mistakes. Watch e.g.: The horrible truth about Apple's repeated engineering failures = https://youtu.be/AUaJ8pDlxi8 .  Conclusion: if you buy Apple you are either (1) an employee (company pays) or (2) a true believer (blind fanboy) or (3) you have too much money to waste.

The key difference between the RISC of the 80s/90s is that they were built by system vendors who controlled every aspect of the design of their servers from chip to OS.   Intel chips and x86 has always thrived in a more OEM/DIY environment.    SUN, Digital Equipment Corp, Silicon Graphics and other companies all had their own custom versions of RISC processors optimized or tweaked for specific kinds of workloads in the larger market.  But all of these were primarily server systems and some workstations.  Similarly, Apple computers have never been something you can build yourself or via OEMs because they control the manufacturing of each computer.  By designing their own chips, they now have become exactly like the server system builders of old in controlling every aspect of the design of their computers to guarantee better performance.  However, Apple machines are primarily desktop and mobile systems not servers.     So x86 will still dominate the server and desktop market regardless.   The big reason for this goes back to the rise of x86 and Intel due IBM deciding that personal computers were never going to become big business, thus creating the IBM "PC Compatible" ecosystem of various vendors providing components to build PCs (OS, motherboards, sound cards, video cards, CPU, etc).  Thus leaving x86 and Windows to become the de-facto standard for PCs even though Intel and Microsoft don't design and build PC systems.
15:25 this chart, at least with how YOU presented it, is misleading. Yes, Apple improved the speed of their architecture by almost 300%, but Intel improved theirs by 41%, not 28%. But that's not even the main issue because while that improvement Apple made is impressive and important YOU seem to think Apple chips are actually faster - they're not. SPECint benchmark measures SINGLE CORE PERFORMANCE. That means that ONE SINGLE CORE of the Intel chip gets 59 points, while ONE CORE of the Apple A14 gets 63. But that Intel chip has 10 cores and additional 10 threads - that benchmark doesn't measure that however. For multicore use Intel, or AMD for that matter, would absolutely demolish the A14 but you make it look like a 125W chip is slower than 5W one which is just absurd and wholy incorrect. Maybe you shouldn't make videos about something you have no idea about.

Intel is fucked
Excellent video review *but* you are missing one point.  The M1 is not an ARM design or ARM chip.  It is a uniquely Apple designed silicon machine that happens to implement the ARM Instruction Set Architecture.   This is a subtle but very important point because otherwise consumers may be misled into believing that all ARM chips are somehow superior to Intel chips.   They aren't but the new Apple M1 design clearly is!  The same hold true for Fugaku.   That supercomputer uses a custom Fujitsu designed CPU that happens to implement the ARM instruction set architecture.  For all the disruption that has been instigated by apple in the computer industry one design RISC V is has the potential to eclipse them all.   I believe that RISC V will be the ultimate ARM killer of the future.

I have an i7-8750H in my gaming laptop and it often reaches 98 degrees Celsius. The ‚ÄòH‚Äô stands for HOT.
There‚Äôs some misconceptions here. One,for example: His example: a CISC CPU might take several clock cycles to complete a complex instruction, is misleading. On a RISC CPU you have to brakedown this instruction into several RISC instructions. Simple instructions (AND, OR, XOR) on CISC CPU complete in one cycle, as they do on a RISC CPU. Also, our x86_64 automatically executes some instructions parallel, like four consecutive add instructions. So you get four instructions during one clock tick. But it‚Äôs always the same, easy answers are never correct
Technically, you bought a phone with a large screen and keyboard.
I was literally hoping you‚Äôd include the N64, and you didn‚Äôt disappoint.  However, grant me my fanboy moment to mention that the N64 was based on a MIPS processor, not an ARM processor.  Both are RISC architectures, but from different companies.   By the way, Jurassic Park and the other Hollywood movies of its ilk were made on SGI machines, which are also MIPS based ;)  In fact, the infamous ‚Äúthis is Unix‚Äù quote from the girl in Jurassic Park was filmed while she was using an SGI machine. Apple's chips aren't ARM chips. There's a reason why it was referred to as Apple Silicon and not ARM. While Apple Silicon (before its implementation in Macs) was in its early stages, it used the ARM architecture, but Apple later stopped making chips according to the ARM instruction set, and that is when it became Apple Silicon, which is different than ARM

The fix is found by using the settings of the monitor itself. Setting it for ‚Äúcomputer use‚Äù.  #3. The fewer thunderbolt  connections on the back are too close to use your current cables ‚Äúwith an adapter‚Äù. Causing even fewer connections. Intel still sits on  its 11nm process while M1 according to the video runs on 5nm chips. I find it disturbing that the video focuses on RISC vs CISC while the different semiconductor processes are probably the main reason for Intel to fall behind.  Along with use cases oriented hardware features on the chips (see e.g. NVIDIA Tegra 2), instead of having more powerful general purpose instructions. Only 8 years ago, even at same clock rates, ARM CPUs were much slower than Intel - while Intel was CISC and ARM RISC. So, obviously the reasons for improvement come from other areas.

this is amazing but is it affordable to all?
M1 (Mac mini 16Gb/512Gb) is amazing small machine. Just created in Python + MySQL test, basically what it does, it compares 2 table data, one has 18.5K records (23 columns), another 10M records (11 columns) and updates record set with 18.5K (saves result). Meaning we have 18.5K x 10M record comparisons (each comparison 10 x 20 fields) and 18.5K MySQL updates. M1 Mac mini did this job in 27h (that is around 1.85M comparisons + MySQL updates per second) I got this result, using all the 8 cores, tried (for 30min only to get speed estimation only) it on 1 core (140h) and on 4 performance cores (36h). Also tried the same job on 2020 iMac 5K i7-10700K/64Gb RAM. Results was as follows: 1 core - 170h, 8 cores - 26.5h and 16 threads - 27h. iMac hit cpu 105W usages in 8 core test in first seconds and fans was blowing full speed. I run test for 30min to get good speed estimate. So M1 in real life multicore performance is on par with Intel i7-10700K performance wise, but with the 10th of energy consumed. Not to mention, M1 was completely silent all the 27h test was running.
From little Acorns to M1ghty Apple trees do grow !
I said this before and will say it again - RISC is smarter, RISC enforces scheduling in software and standardizes the hardware which is a better use of hardware resources. You cannot train ineffectively in an environment that will explicitly state its limitations. It just won't bog down. Smarter software beats analog hardware limits, there is no way to recouperate dedicated hardware scheduling resources when the resources don't hold any reservations - RISC does that. That is why it will never slow down since it isn't tied to hardware scheduling. X86 is like a mainframe server trying to balance requests in a DDOS attack while Arm only serves one dedicated client.

Although I understand you have biases... Apple has "ACTUALLY" moved the industry forward ( for better or worse ) for a long, long, time. Remember... when you a company like Samsung ( which innovative ) release a product or feature "before" Apple it doesn't mean Apple hasn't already done this... they simply take their time before releasing. Samsung's first fold was innovative... but it was also a pile of crap in many, many, ways... Touch ID using a Secure Enclave slowly reducing our dependence on passwords was done before Apple... but how many of these innovations are done by companies who HEAR a rumour of Apple doing something and try to beat them to market... with varying degrees of success.  Even in the processor world, Apple was first to ship removed the headphone jack ( making a huge push for wireless ), removed ethernet from their devices which pushed more widespread wireless adoption, removed the floppy drive.  Consumers may not see REMOVING features as innovation, but in practice, it drives the industry a particular way. Look at AirPods.   Look at Smart Watches.  Apple isn't first to RELEASE a product, but you can bet that they're usually one of the first to develop a technology... in secret, behind closed doors... waiting until the time is right to release.

The premise is slightly incorrect in that RISC processors require many more memory operations than a CISC cpu to carry out the same operation, and when x86 cpu were first created, memory chips were far more expensive than they are today, hence the CISC architecture!
The video from Johnathan processing footage is also misleading. iMovie on the phone is not the same software and does not do as much as the Final Cut Pro. Anyone making this video would know that and realize that this is borderline fraudulent and complete misrepresentation of the products shown.
the thing that the narrator fails to mention is that a complex CPU and a RISC CPU use about the same cycles to complete a complex task, which is what modern computers do... A complex CPU can take several clock cycles to complete the one complex instruction, where as the RISC CPU will also use several clock cycles of simple instructions to complete a complex task. Also, the efficiency and speed of a CPU are mostly limited by the purity of the materials used to make it and how hot it is allowed to operate.

some remarks on the comparisons: 2:50 this video compares Lightroom (on iPad) with Photoshop (on Surface) which are not comparable applications (from a "benchmarking" point of view) 15:50 the comparison on power consumption is a bit off, the M1 max power consumption is 40Watts, still 3x less than comparable Intel CPUs 16:40 this video compares also two different applications (maybe the iPhone app just crops the file and the desktop rerenders the whole video) I think this comparisons are misleading - sure they make the ARM more exciting, but its not fair to people working hard on other architectures/products.

14:22 - bit of a correction for you....the Galaxy S4 didn't use a 64 bit chip. The first ARM-based 64 bit SOCs were the Snapdragon 808 and 810, and phones with those chips didn't debut until 2015. The S4 came out in the first half of 2013, not late 2014.

The concept of unified memory architecture is not new, back in the 1980s it was utilized in LISP machines.  I still miss those machines because of how far ahead they were to standard programming mantra.  In fact JAVA's garbage collection was derived from how it was utilized in LISP.

"... disruptive innovations involve no new technologies; rather they consist of components built around proven technologies that are put together in novel architectures, offering the consumer a set of attributes never before available." This describes Steve Jobs to a tee. You still hear people today who say that "Jobs didn't invent anything, he copied other people's products." In some sense this is true, but it was Jobs who pulled together these disparate technologies to make products that consumers had never seen before. First the Mac, then iMac, then iPod, then the iPhone, then iPad. His last legacy will no doubt be the M1 because it was Jobs who in 2008 went out and bought Palo Alto Semi for a mere $278M, a steal in hindsight. No one knew at the time why Apple (read: Jobs) bought them. Now in the year 2020, 9 years after his death, we see what Jobs was up to. He continues to disrupt, even from the grave.

If you think about it, the real performance caps of chips long-term are related to physics, that is, power consumption and heat dispersion. If Apple can have the same performance from a 5 watt chip as Intel gets from a 125 watt chip, what prevents manufacturers from simply synchronizing a couple dozen Apple chips and getting performance an order of magnitude greater with the same physical constraints? Efficiency *is* performance.
