I feel like you were just drinking a little bit of the koolaid with this one. A lot of the the things you said here were just wrong.  Saying the apple silicon chips are better is very debatable yet, and very much depends on your workflow. I feel there's a lot you could have done a bit better here, you could have described what the advantage and disadvantage of the reduced instruction set are. That with a reduced instruction set you can run faster and more efficient, but that having more instructions allow you to do more specific things more quickly. It's like having a massive toolbox vs a small one. Both you might be able to get all the jobs done, but it's faster to find something in the smaller one, but it's faster to get the job done with the bigger one.  I also feel like you should have talked a bit about how intel has stagnated soo badly. That's probably the biggest reason why Apple was able to catch them so quickly. I mean AMD had made similar massive strides in recent years to very quickly surpass Intel. That's all because Intel has been essentially standing still for 5 years (because they didn't have any competition).   Saying that reduced instruction set processors are faster is just wrong, and the same is true for saying apples new chips are just the fastest out there. They definitely aren't, but they absolutely are for their power consumption. And because of this it is a huge market disrupter, and it is   I do agree with it being a market disrupter, and a huge one at that. It will be really cool to see where Apple goes with this, there's a lot of places they could go. Just immagine this sort of efficiency if they can adapt to a server environment. That would wipe the floor in such a space where operating costs are much much more of a concern than in the personal marketplace.

This presentation is glib, but poorly researched and inaccurate.   1. The Acorn Risc Machine was developed for the Acorn Archimedes computer - a desktop.  2. Referring to the ARM processor format as a "mobile chip" is deliberatley misleading. RISC processors were a SGI specialty.  3. Intel produced ARM processors, but sold the family to Marvell prior to the release of the iPhone.  4. The RISC processor design was nothing new when ARM was deeloped. RISC CPUs from MIPS and other families had been in high performance workstations for years 5. Characteriing CISC is full of inrequently-used instructions is misleading. In practice, modern x86 processors work much like RISC machines internally; ARM's modern improvements can be found elsewhere.  6. The majority of Apple's power consumption advantage is due to superior manufacturing methods - they're on a 5nm process, and smaller transistors means less power. AMD is still on 7nm for cost reasons, while Intel is still on 10nm. Were Intel producing on the same assembly line, they'd have much closer results - and Intel, via outsourcing, may do exactly that.  7. The high end desktop machines of the era were all RISC - Apple's PowerPC, SGI's MIPS, DEC's Alpha, IBM's POWER, and Sun's UltraSPARC desktop workstations all ran circles around Itnel's silicon. The speed advantage was mostly a result of budget - a well equipped SGI Indy cost over $70,000 in today's money, and a maxed out SPARC box was even worse.  8. Incidentally, Intel - not RISC - had superior power consumption for the era.  9. The iPod was not the first major ARM product line. DEC licensed it to produce the StrongARM product line in the 90s, and the iPod was one of many products to use it including the Game Boy Advance and many more.  10. When Intel rejected developing the processor for the iPhone, they were comparing their own products to existing options from MIPS, Marvell, and more. Apple designing low-power mobile processors would've been like Peterbilt or Mack developing a subcompact hatchback. 11. Many of Apple's early iPhone processors compared poorly; it was superior optimization that produced the performance. They also failed to support 3G, 4G, and LTE until long after their competitors.  12. The majority of Apple's iPhone revenue was from software, not hardware.  13. The graph you post is misleading; that's for one core, and the 10900k has ten of them. The performance from the A14 and M1 are a huge improement on anything from intel of comparable cost and power consumption, but under real-world loads like media production, the 10900k is still quite a lot faster. Furthermore, it's a high performance desktop chip; there's a far more efficient laptop version as well.  14. Intel's largest competitor AMD also outsources its' production - to TSMC, the same fab facility that produces the M1.  15. The M1 is outperformed by laptop processors from AMD by a substantial margin.  16. The M1 has additional redundant instructions (ironically enough) to improve X86 compatibility. Running high performance applications like Photoshop has a substantial penalty.   Characterizing ARM as a disruptive technology is disingenuous; twenty years ago, it was an expensive luxury technology.   Perhaps you should stick to subjects on which you are not obliged to spew marketing drivel.

What a shallow video!  You've completely missed the point about RISC architecture, which emerged in the 1980's, gave rise to the Workstation revolution, and gave users the power of a small mainframe on their desktop.  Sun Microsystems was a leader in this marketplace, along with several others.  RISC made efficient use of the silicon chip "real estate" by: 1) eliminating complex instructions that could be accomplished using existing simpler instructions. 2) making all instructions the same length to facilitate pipe-lining (i.e. assembly line execution where multiple instruction steps can be executing during the same clock cycle, such as operand pre-fetch, address indirection, etc), 3) Pairing the RISC chip with custom software compilers to optimize pipe-line processing (e.g. branch prediction, loop unrolling, etc).  This allowed RISC chips to do more, per clock cycle, than anything from Intel.  The Intel instruction set was designed in the 1970's during the era of expensive memory and thus was "byte oriented" with instructions having variable length, to conserve memory space.  You can't pipe-line Intel instructions easily because until you decode and execute the "Nth" instruction you can't tell where the "N+1th" begins in the data stream and so on.  Apple abandoned the PowerPC and went to Intel because IBM could not meet demand for PowerPC chips and that was a bad technological decision IMHO.  Thankfully they've come to their senses and found a solution to, once again, utilize the superior RISC technology in their products.
If ARM is the future of PCs then we need Microsoft to write both Windows and Office to run natively on ARM chips and not rely on running in some dodgy emulation mode. Goodbye x86 in both hardware and software.

It seems low foreheads do not appreciate the POWER of Apple and their fine products.
Low power consumption is idempotent with low computing power. Thus Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC) are NOT inherently more efficient when looking at the POWER which is a function of two values. The reason being that one single Complex instruction can replace 5000 primitive instructions. Meaning as per definition of RISC one clock cycle per instruction, would require 5000 clock cycles, to what would take 1 single clock cycle in modern contemporary CPUs.   Thus the effective level of performance in power draw and time spent makes RISC actually less efficient than its CISC hybrid counterpart in some cases.  Bottom line Advanced RISC Machines (ARM) is a complete oxymoron. How can you have an Advanced Reduced Instruction Set Computer Machine?  The issue with RISC in low power consumption applications makes it mandatory for all battery operated computing devices, thus wireless.  But for wired applications which are connected to AC line power, then the battery limitations become meaningless.  So there is a use case for RISC, and for CISC.  It is my prediction that ARM will be in bankruptcy within 5 years because of their proprietary IP and licensing shenanigans.  To be soon overtaken by real RISC that are open-source hardware.  Such as IBM'S PowerPC architecture which is open-source, MIPS which is open-source and RISC-V also open-source with no licensing shenanigans.  Thus the future of electronics will evolve thanks to open-source genius distributed equally the world over. And ARM becomes obsolete due to their proprietary licensing, painted into a dead end corner.  A metaphor could be comparing a rechargeable drill, to a AC powered drill.  Both have their use cases. But you won't find a CNC metal milling machine battery operated...

I just want to say that it is unfair to say that Intel CPUs are CISC and ARM are RISC, therefore better. It goes much deeper than that.  "Since the Pentium Pro, all Pentium branded CPUs have broken down complex instructions into RISC-like micro-operations, so you can see these processors as RISC CPUs with some extra front-end instruction decode logic that can feed multiple instructions into the pipeline for each instruction read from memory. This technique enabled Intel (and AMD, who did this first) to get the benefits of deep pipelines and large register files without having to break backward compatibility.  But all modern large microprocessors are really beyond the concerns that motivated RISC, being much more similar to the mainframe CPUs of the 1970s than the original MIPS or ARM designs. They have complex instruction reordering and register renaming that makes the user-facing instruction set almost irrelevant."  https://www.quora.com/Is-the-Intel-Pentium-really-a-hybrid-between-RISC-and-CISC
the available approach with nowadays technology is to take advantage of the way random memory works,  it's much easier to change the way of reaching memory and a new type of hashing algorithms...  in addition to quantum computer,  I am not sure if what have been writen is correct or not.  stimulating the way human's temporary memory works is the first step....  the computer architecture must be change: GPU shouldn't work independently this way the speed of processing images and dealing with it would increase dramatically....  to concise: the GPU + RAM + CPU architecture should change...  the new architecture of RAM is ready to mirror the screen (three main colors)....  the new theory should be about memory processing,  how to deal wth the memory to simulate the human memory....  consciousness is a long story,  not possible right now,  but preparing for that needs a good understanding of the mechanism of the human mind...  the first step should be a new approach (the random memory should be reflected directly)  for instance : the RAM and screen "kind of mirroring".... most of what's wrote about consciousness is wrong....  new computer architecture,  new approach to the way of dealing with GPU and RAM.....  the rest comes step by step.

Great video. Those of us who came up during the 80s and 90s (in the industry) always knew RISC was faster and more efficient. But the problem faced by RISC in general was that it was ahead of its time. Computing was so new to the average person that they didn't understand what they were buying. So IBM, Intel, etc., just won by name recognition. In the 90s there was a company called Nexgen which sat a CISC on top of a RISC. It was very fast for what it was, but it also ran very hot. And the overhead of, for lack of a better term, hardware emulation, it wasn't faster-enough. Now here we are, back at the beginning.

The thing that will limit the potential impact this could have for the industry is still going to be what it always has been... Apple's stubborn unwillingness to work with other firms to improve iOS compatibility with Linux or windows based software, as well as their price gouging and near zero upgrade capabilities... let alone Apple Support's terrible gaffs in customer support. Yes, the M1 is a huge achievement in the scope of performance per watt. Not denying that at all... but to put a spin on this that the M1 signals the death knell of x86 is a bit farfetched, even lingering on the line of being heavily biased. AMD's Zen architecture closed a bigger performance gap to Intel in just 3 years time. Framing the scope of this to the end that Intel is the only relevant horse in the race of x86 architecture and give barely a cursory mention of the improvements in the x86 space that AMD and other manufacturers is silly. x86 will still be a very viable option for sometime to come, Especially if Apple maintains their historical greed in refusing to allow upgrade capabilities, coding flexibility, and over pricing.

Those are two different arrangements which are hell of an unfair comparison @ 3:00 The whole video argument is nonsensical. The physical limitation of a phone is what makes phones slower. The industry focus on development of mobile chips over computer chips in recent years is what allows the phones to become faster, however a phone will never become faster than a same year computer because as physical limitations allows you, you can put more chips or more cooling etc. in general, just more of the same shit in a larger volume of space. This video shows that the OP has a lack of technical knowledge as perormance shown @ 3:59 must have been tested on very specific circumstances as factually 10900K well over doubles the performance of A14 on every credible benchmark. Not to mention that short term performance is not a feasable measurement as apple products are known to thermal throttle which means that although their chips are cabale of running at high performance, it can only sustain it for several minutes before software kicks in and restricts its clock speed to prevent overheating. This is not present in other known brand name products with clock speeds still comparable to those designed by apple. The reason that other phones dont use such high performance chips is not the ability to do it, its simply that the market does not want the extra expense which in practical terms will never be noticeable. Apple fans on the other hand, will pay their left arm and right leg for apple product. Apple may design something close to best or tweak their chips to have advantage in certain areas but the fact that apple do not physically produce their own chips is the reason they will never outpace the market as it entails the manufacturer of the chip to have internal knowledge of the chip in order to produce it.

If you actually look up the benchmarks you will see this is grossly incorrect, the cpu is at best comparable to a lower mid performance Ryzen, the only advantage it has over Intel chips is the GPU. If you are serious about the GPU you buy an AMD, people who use intel chips usually have a 3rd party GPU in their device. The CPU single core performance of any top Intel or AMD is comparable in single core performance and something like 2-10 times more powerful in multicore tests. Graphical performance issues are not a demonstration of a CPU's performance, but an amalgamation of a number of factors. Intel embedded GPU's are known to be the worst in the industry, a fair test would compare to AMD Ryzen CPU's with credible comparable GPUs.  The Surface X uses an Arm chip, and is probably the worst design choice in  Microsoft's recent history, and the following graphics suggest via the infographics that this is a demonstration of the performance of a high end Intel x86 Chip shown in the graph, so this is also extremely misleading, to show an Arm based device, then go on to not mention the platform while showing slides referencing intel and x86 processors. This is extremely deceptive. Yes Surface X sucks, yes Intel x86 GPU's are crap, but the CPU performance of a top of the line x86 with a 3rd party or AMD integrated GPU still crushes a 6 core A14 and outperforms an A14X when compared apples to apples.

Let's not forget that the M1 chip is killing it in relatively niche applications where hardware acceleration can make all the difference. An x86 CPU using all its brute force will never beat something like a GPU with hardware acceleration for H265 transcoding.  The key is this: Will software developers make the effort to switch to ARM instead of x86? Because right now Apple's M1 can beat the pants of x86 CPUs in applications which were optimized for their M1 ARM CPU, but falls apart when it has to emulate x86 instructions.  Ultimately I think that Apple's innovation will further fragment the market instead of pushing it forward. Now developers have to deal with two CPU technologies, which is generally unappealing. x86 isn't going to go away just because Apple released a shiny new notebook which impresses the movie editing enthusiasts.

Because either the CPU gets too hot or even the battery heats up, which is an old disease of Apple I-Phone! Now Apple goes there and selects an even faster M1 chip, it won't last long because the CPU gets too hot!  There is actually nothing new about this outdated M1 chip, which distributes the allocation units to several partitions and has the task of searching for and finding!  This of course creates a lot of heat, which has to be dissipated somewhere, for example a 2 mm rotating fan that should be installed under the CPU unit and thus cool everything and then also attach ventilation slots on the side where the hot air can escape!  And so the battery would also be protected from overheating!  This fan should only switch on when critical heat has been reached!  If this were not done, the iPhone could crash or freeze from overheating, nothing is functional anymore! I-Phone + Server + Supercomputer = Infinite performance and super-fast and without overheating! A few points if I may:  This video doesn't offer anything new that I haven't known for the past 25 years. It's a good video for high school students who know nothing of the 90's CPU architecture battles or Apple-fascists who love to hear how great is their tech-god. The battle of RISC and CISC played out in the '90s. But the instruction sets of both have evolved to the point that RISC is no longer "reduced". The instruction sets of CISC and RISC have evolved to become quite vast and complex, so a "Reduced-ICS" is a fallacy. But the reality is that RISC is about 30% more efficient for low power usage, and the reason why Intel failed miserably with their CISC processors in the mobile space. Only recently from around 2019 onward, RISC has shown to compete with high-powered desktops through multi-core CPUs. But that's thanks to AMD, not Apple. Apple has done shit in the contribution to the RISC CISC evolution. They still only license the technology from ARM. They didn't invent RISC and have only built on top of it. So giving credit to Apple for RISC is just Apple-fascist propaganda.  In the video, the benchmarks are misleading and clearly Apple-FUD.  AMD has far exceeded the capabilities of Intel's 10th gen processors for nearly two years now, so comparing the M1 to Intel is a waste of time. AMD's absence in the comparisons is obviously deliberate and suggests that the M1 cannot yet touch AMD's Epyc and Ryzen series.   The 4K encoding "demo" is also bullshit. That is far from an apples-to-apples comparison (excuse the pun!). I have 20 years of video experience and I can encode a 4K video with one configuration that would take 3 minutes and max-out the specs of an HEVC config that would take 3 days to encode the exact same video. But sure, for Apple fascists who continually drink Apple's Kool-Aid - such a demonstration is certainly convincing that their tech-god is "once again" changing the world. The reality is that the flagship mobile processors of today including the M1 cannot compete with current flagship desktop processors. Apple - Why not show a 4K HEVC benchmark with the same video and exact same configurations and present a proper comparison?  Year after year Apple has presented a new "world-changing" processor that is 6x faster in 'A' and 12x faster in 'B', and 100x faster in 'C'. In the end, their processors prove to be only 10-20% faster than their predecessors in practical benchmark applications. Even still, if the M1 processor is 25% faster than the fastest Intel 10th gen processor, this isn't groundbreaking - it's just an incrementally faster processor. If Intel or AMD adopted the same rhetoric then they have been changing the world every year for the past 25 years!  To wrap up my rant - I find it funny to see Apple say $hit like "The M1 is faster than 98% of PC's".  Any new flagship processor that Intel released in the past (and now AMD as the market leader) will be faster than 98% of any old computer! But I can acknowledge that this is great propaganda! If Apple is good at one thing, it's great marketing - especially to their loyal disciple-base. Keep drinking Kool-Aid, my friends!
Whoo...... You are teaching me more than my teacher  üòâüòú
Compare the instruction set and performance/power consumption of the Intel chips to the instruction set and performance/power consumption of Apple‚Äôs M1. Then do the same between the EVM and RChain‚Äôs rho-calculus-based execution. You‚Äôll find they follow the same pattern.

The bad thing about the X-86 was the memory addressing ... it was complicated by paging and had to multiplex the address lines because of limited IO to a chip, usually 64 pins.  To be compatible with all that PC software the stuck with that for a really long time.  Not sure they still have that or not, but it is simpler to just have direct addressing lines and faster too.  But, microprocessor design has come so far and is so amazingly complex these days seems like anything that makes it simpler or that hides the complexity is a good thing.

Great video, full of inaccuracies and half truths but great nonetheless. No one can be blamed for that though, even those who have the technical background to understand the full story can barely make heads or tails of this whole mess. There's no winner in the CISC vs RISC war, because they are not comparable, they are both good (at the things they are good at).  X86 (and x64 afterwards) is the way it is today mainly because of consumer's choice. It wasn't something Intel designed on their own, but an industry standard that grew organically out of the many competing chip makers. Of course its named after Intel chips, but that's just another story, which involves lawyers and brands and things I don't quite understand... I only know that the "pentium" brand was born out that kerfuffle as Intel failed to make x86 a brand.  The main driving force on the CISC front was/is... well... videogames. A CISC chip today is not just an instruction processor, it does so much more, so much that you need a full year at college just  to understand the basics of it all. But to try to explain it in as few words as possible, a CISC chip is smart, it's main job is not to just run a program but to figure out how to run the program in the best way possible. This is desirable for very complex programs, which use a lot of floating point operations or other high cost operations, and which are also usually released in a not very optimized way, aka videogames. On the downside, they are very inefficient for other applications.  RISC has been around since CISC also became a thing. If there's something nerds love is their internal civil wars. But there never was a true RISC standard as x86 was for CISC. There are a lot of RISC out there, almost as many as there are chip makers... Hell, we even got RISC for theoretical machines that were never built for market (Java for example).  The issue with RISC is that its performance is strongly dependant on the quality and optimization of the code. To put it in other words, whereas CISC is smart chips for dumb devs, RISC is dumb chips for smart devs. So how do you avoid this? You apply a strict control over the app marketplace and developing tools. Does that sound familiar? Downside is, you smother innovation. Not that apple cares about that... they'll just offset lack of innovation with marketing, as they usually do.  What about the benchmarks? Benchmarks lie, they have always lied. Truth is we have long ago reached the max performance we can physically get out of silicon, since then benchmarks have been about averages under very specific conditions, which can be misleading about the actual performance of a machine. Back in the real world, normies love their RISC running phones and gamers laugh at them, neither is either right or wrong, just different consumers with different wants and needs.  But, you could have a machine which has both CISC and RISC, could you not? Yeah... And it's not like it hasn't been tried... But... Most remarkably Intel did try to push a sort of hybrid technology back in the dawn of the 64 bits era, and they failed spectacularly. Because of this they lost the 64 bits race with AMD, as they pushed a pure CISC 64 bits chip which the market readily adopted, setting their specs as the de facto new standard (x64). Since then no one in the PC market has ever dared to question CISC supremacy.  Thing is, even if this is not a paradigm shifting new tech, which is definitely not, it's still a good thing that apple is pushing RISC towards new markets, maybe someone will put two and two together and finally figure out how to make CISC and RISC work together, that would definitely be the breakthrough we need. Meanwhile, most of the market will look at the M1 and say "cool bro, does it run crysis?"
The trite television descriptively suggest because passbook internally offer for a modern stretch. automatic, creepy washer

I managed to finished watching the video. It's nicely put together but there are something that's amiss. 1. The whole video makes CISC looks bad, and RISC good. Would be nice to explore some points about why CISC was the choice (memory) and how it mitigated some of its issue (SIMD which acts on multiple data in one instruction. E.g. MMX, SSE). RISC wasn't the choice simply because its design is to execute exactly 1 instruction at 1 clock (MIPS has some mitigations but let's make this simple at first) and back then CPU are running at 33MHz. CISC filled this with custom instructions that contrary to what might implied by (multiple clock cycle to complete, the fact is it takes variable clocks w.r.t. instruction), it takes less clock cycles in total to do the same thing in RISC design for some operations. CISC is harder to maintain especially x86 which has a long legacy, and overtime it make designing the silicon harder and doesn't scale like how ARM design is with the increase of CPU frequency.  2. Might be a bit misleading to the uninitiated folks (most of us, since these CISC vs RISC war happened back in 80s and 90s), RISC = ARM. ARM back then was just a small company with limited impact and frankly sub-par performance. Back then, MIPS (used in PS and PS2), Sun SPARC, AIM PowerPC and DEC Alpha (which released the world's first 64-bit CPU) were the representatives. ARM started booming after they license their technology instead of making their own silicon. ARMv4 was first and ARMv5 was truly widespread in PocketPC, and later versions (especially ARMv7) really makes a good impact.  3. Mobile computing does not start with Apple devices. The one which popularized it was Palm (gone now), and Windows CE / PocketPC edition later took over it. Apple was having Newton and it was the first product from Apple with ARM CPU. Not iPod because Newton was before the return of Steve Jobs (and he's the one who binned this project). Then the cellphone market rose and that truly put mobile computing into spotlight - especially the first iPhone, and then Android devices follow. Microsoft missed this totally even though it used to be the major market leader in that realm (with its dated ActiveSync system). Classic Microsoft killing off teams after they declared victory (Internet Explorer team after v6 is also a victim of this).  4. Intel actually did dip their toe into ARM early on (PocketPC era). The  XScale CPU was one of the quickest available (PXA27x) but Intel thought it's useless technology and sold it to Marvell, and that's 2006. Intel also tried to start "clean" but frankly chose a wrong design likely due to company bureaucracy trying to please multiple people at the same time. It's not RISC or CISC strictly, it's VLIW which requires optimization right from the compiler. Yea, the name is called Itanium. They botched so bad that even Microsoft dropped support for Itanium. It was the CPU that Intel would officially support 64-bit with, and deemed the consumer market won't need 64-bit (see a pattern? Yea Qualcomm did the same with their SoC in 2010 when ARM released 64-bit extension design). And that gave rise to AMD Athlon 64 series putting extension to x86-64 (amd64). Intel followed with Pentium 4 and the rest is history. If you check why IA-64 exists, it was because HP found that the 1-clock-per-instruction basic design of RISC CPU is limiting, kinda ironic.  Overall, I would say this is one of the examples that less-is-more in the long run.

Just that no one ever thought it's necessary to have 64-bit ARM CPU, hence Qualcomm didn't even have one until 2014.

You didn't explain why RISC has started winning finally.  And that is the transition to multicore architectures.  Now the number cores are increasing, the complex instructions are struggling due to the coordination required across cores.  RISC doesn't have so much coordination across cores so its much easier to add cores and have them run at their fun potential.

When Apple introduced the iPhone with a touchscreen of almost the size of the entire phone, with the idea that the phone was almost entirely controlled with the touchscreen, using your fingers, most of their competitors and critics laughed at them and were extremely skeptical. It took but just a few months before all the other smartphone manufacturers copied the idea, and just a year or two for it to become completely ubiquitous. Apple's idea of putting a device-sized touchscreen usable with your fingers on a smartphone pretty much killed the idea of having a physical keyboard on smartphones.

It might be Intel wasnt interested in low power CPU. Their big money was with desktop computers and servers CPU - big bucks. So why go into little piddly few dollar each micro. Plus they don't have expertise in this RISC and low power field.  Arm existed long before iPhone. It was used in the Apple Newton. Apple had paid ARM development during the Newton days.  Arm was used in all the "Dumb" phones - Nokia, Ericsson etc. So Arm wasn't exclusively for the iPhone. I even got shares in ARM when they went IPO, that's how good, I believed in them.  ARM was a development arm of Acorn computers. Their first computers was the BBC, which used the 6502. When Acorn wanted to moved onto their next machine they couldn't find any microprocessor that suited their new computer 68000,80186 etc. These microprocessors was far too expensive $100+ each (and this is 80s prices). Acorn love the simplicity of the 6502. So not finding a CPU that suits their need, they went down the RISC route with the 6502 in mind.  You need to remember the 68000 chip had about 68000 transistors - thus large silicon real estate compared to the first arm chip of 4000 transistors. More chips per silicon wafer = cheaper etc..  Intel design and manufacture their chips. So with them, it's a case of take it or leave it. With ARM you can design your own chip and can be manufactured by most silicon foundry. If you look now, Intel is struggling with their 14nm chip foundry compared to AMD 7mm(going to 5) who uses foundry that have the latest nm technology. Another word, Intel has an old factory turning out old technology whilst AMD just goes to a factory that does the latest. It's very cost intensive investment for chip foundry. Ok it isn't just 7nm technology that's killing Intel, it's AMD other technology too.  Now Apple can make their own chips which is way lot cheaper than Intel than can sell their own to them. They can choose the latest factory to make it.  Apple thus have more control in where the chip design is going. They can optimise their chip to their iPhone/Mac needs.

Not that anyone will read this, but this video is so full of inaccuracies that are astounding. First of all,  showing old macs that ran on motorola chips like the 68000 and saying that they ran on intel chips. Then showing 8-bit 6502  chip based computers calling them intel chips. Apple used to run on different chips then they told everyone that they would be much faster moving to intel chips.  Computers  have been using RISC chips computers for nearly 30 years so it is hardly some big new innovation. MIPS was one of the popular chips. RISC processors such as the Sparc came out for desktop computers in 1987.   Then using the graphics which is handed off to another processor to demonstrate the failings of a processor is just nonsense. Apple does a fine job with graphics because they don't have to support a wide array of hardware.    Not saying that the M1 isn't a nice chip. It is just not some new, innovative technology nor is Apple "changing the entire industry".    Do a little research please. It's not hard.

Yes, all very true, but you should consider that Intel was working towards FPGA acceleration and quantum computers. It's not like they choked out on desktop market; it's more like they don't care about it anymore. Also, if you think about where the 5 nm CPUs are being manufactured, a lot of it probably came out of Intel's R&D, manufacturing facilities and foundry partners.  Instead of buying a fancy Macbook with ARM CPU, you can always buy something like Pinebook Pro with a Linux onboard for 10x lower cost. Yes, that's $2K vs $200 - but at a certain price to your feeling of self-worth which comes with conspicuous consumption as well as general quality of screen, hardware, etc. Less expensive - it's not really Apple's motto :D Remember what Bill Gates said - "hardware will be free", but if you take a look at the Microsoft Surface - it's not following this philosophy; instead it has an Intel CPU and alcantara leather on top.  It's not a secret that Linux and open-source software users don't care much about underlying architecture - you can run your distro on x86, PowerPC (like Mac G5) or ARM; you can even build and run on more obscure architectures if you want (yes, instead of buying an overpriced Intel server, you might go with a used Sun/Oracle one, packing more RAM and cores - that's if you know what you're doing and you still want to bother with actual hardware).  The great idea behind open source software is that once you have the source code, you're not locked into buying specific hardware for doing simple everyday computing tasks. Unfortunately, you need more background in software engineering to be able to do this, it goes far more than just "buy at the store and use". Also, most of open-source software comes "as is" and is of low (almost amateur-like) quality, and professional-grade software is very often vendor locked-in.

This video is very well edited and quite interesting for a wider public, but it does not really explain why the Apple M1 is succeeding. It's clear that it has been made by people who are not from the industry.  The key here is NOT the ARM architecture actually, it's software, and always has been. The problem is that most software is running on x86, and emulating x86 on ARM gives awful performance results: see the surface Pro X with its Qualcomm Snapdragon processor (ARM architecture), which has terrible performance. Even though we all know that Qualcomm Snapdragon processors are competitive with Apple's chips.  Apple's key innovation is NOT Rosetta 2 itself, it actually lies inside the chip architecture. The M1 chip has some built-in hardware dedicated to converting x86 instructions to ARM instructions. That means, that the emulation is hardware accelerated. That's the difference with Microsoft's ARM attempt with the Surface Pro X, where emulation is only performed by software.  Finally, one last point is that there is already a huge software base for ARM applications (iPhone, iPad), which enables further software development.

This video, among several others, made me curious about whether RISC processors really could handle "heavy" computing workloads nowadays. I have no interest in owning an Apple product, so I bought a secondhand Samsung Galaxy Book S instead, which has a Qualcomm CPU and runs Windows On ARM. Since Microsoft just released a dev-channel update for Windows On ARM that enables x64 emulation, I installed that, and set about testing various programs. I've been rather shocked to discover this cheap little laptop can run 3D games like Civilization 5 *_without a dedicated graphics card, while emulating the x64 instruction set._* This is causing me to question whether the entire current paradigm of PC hardware has been misguided after all.

Bravo to Apple!  I used to work for a small cie working on a multicore asynchronous cpu, very low power usage, ARM did explore this avenue in their history.  Asynchronous means the chip does not entirely use the clock but depend only on the logic gate, the challenge was the silicon has variable propagation delay.  The chip I was working on does not have a hw cache subsystem, because this subsystem consumes lots of energy to maintain cache coherency. The problem is not with the fact that it takes multiple clock cycles to execute a complex instruction, it is to schedule instruction execution in the pipeline.
People who claim that x86 can't compete with ARM on efficiency are just as naive as those who said that ARM couldn't compete with x86 when scaled up. The big problem with x86, more so than unnecessary instructions and the CISC vs RISC nonsense (x86 is essentially both at this point, as it uses micro-ops to break larger instructions down into smaller ones), is that Intel has largely been the main player in the market. AMD is the only competition left (VIA still holds a license and still makes chips, but they're very nicher), and they have long struggled to stay relevant because they're a much smaller company with much fewer resources. And yet, looking at the history of x86, they've often been the company that innovates when Intel doesn't.  In the mid 2000's, AMD had their awesome K8 architecture and it gained a brief period of time in the spotlight. They moved the memory controller onto the CPU die, and brought the first x64 CPUs to market. Yet again, AMD was innovating but this time they were actually performing better than Intel. At the same time, Intel was headed down the wrong road with their forward-thinking but flawed Netburst architecture. Their lofty goals of super high (10 GHz) clock speeds were woefully far-reaching and it was a huge blunder. Intel quickly rebounded by ditching Netburst for the Core architecture which built upon the old Pentium II architecture but vastly improved it, and rather quickly, they were able to iterate upon that. With Core, Intel quickly regained the lead.  At the same time, AMD was struggling with fabricating chips. It was becoming a drain on their business. Even worse, they apparently had no clear competitor for the Core stuff. So AMD ended up spinning off their foundry business and getting out of manufacturing altogether. They couldn't keep up with Intel, and the resulting business, Global Foundries, would continue having trouble. Intel was bleeding edge. But, as part of the deal for the spin-off, AMD had agreed to a bunch of wafer deals with GloFo. Meaning, no matter how bad the process was, AMD was stuck using them. At the same time, the new Bulldozer architecture was turning out to be AMD's own Netburst. AMD, unlike Intel, didn't have the money to rebound in a year or two, or even three if they wanted to. They were stuck iterating on a flawed architecture for years.  So AMD had no competition in the high-end CPU space for a long time and Intel sat on their laurels. They continued to push process technologies and were absurdly ahead of AMD, until about 14nm. It was around this time when Intel started to have SERIOUS fab issues. Fast forward to today and 10nm is still broken and 7nm looks like a repeat, but worse, of 10nm. I seriously wonder if Intel doesn't just get out of the foundry business altogether.  The thing is, when your process technology is no longer cutting edge, then it's no longer an advantage to you, and if you keep dumping money into nodes that don't work, then you're just hurting your bottom line. Apple has no risk investing in new nodes because they can simply make agreements that are favorable to them, or they take their business elsewhere. Samsung and TSMC are now options for anyone wanting to build chips on cutting edge nodes.  From Sandy Bridge (2nd gen Core i) to Kaby Lake (7th gen), Intel was content to leaving users with at best 4-core chips. It wasn't until AMD finally started being competitive again with Zen, and offering more cores, that Intel started to react. Without a doubt, Intel's massively slow reaction is somewhat surprising. I guess that could be chalked up to hubris. But for whatever the reason, Intel seemed content to just keep iterating for a full 6 generations or so.  I apologize for the length of my comment. I've tried to edit it down as much as possible. Further thoughts will follow in subsequent comments.

They shifted, you might recall, to using the Intel chip, because it gave them a semblance of Windows compatibility.  And now they appear to be doing it again, switching to ARM. So I watched a lot of reviews talking about the game changing performance but no one really talks about the fact that it‚Äôs built on 5 nanometer. This reduced size results in smaller, faster and a lot more energy efficient silicon. Hence a large part of why AMD‚Äôs latest cpus (and their GPUs as well as nvidia‚Äôs latest) perform so much better and with much less power than their previous generations based on a larger process. If intel could fabricate their i86 cpu on 5 nm I wonder how fast and energy efficient it would be. Less power than M1 - doubt it, but speed - maybe much better.

Well this video would make more sense if they stopped saying ARM is a mobile architecture. It's just not the case. It's just an architecture that got many variant in Mobile phone. Then M1 isn't a Mobile chip. It's an Arm chip designed for Desktop and Laptop. Lastly, ARM are getting away from the MIPS concept as they are getting more complex. One of the original distinction of RISC was do it have a divide instruction, ARM now have one where original RISC computer didn't. (it did it with a mix of other simple instruction).  Also, the M1 have a very complex and large front end that is typical of CISC CPU.   So the revolution is not there. The revolution is that many company can now get an ARM license to produce ARM SoC where there are only Intel, AMD and Via that have x86 license. Nobody can join the x86 market and compete. With ARM getting there and having more and more actors, we will have way more competition and new idea in CPU design.   The key concept here is not that Apple is using ARM, it's Apple made very interesting decision when they were making their core and it's possible that it's what giving them such performance in the end. By example, they have soldered ram, they have integrated many instruction for javascript, they do not use SMT, they use a lot of accelerator, etc...   We will see, one of the main thing with ARM is how they integrated in their front end the support of x86 memory management to speed up by huge margin Rosetta 2. This, could mean in the future that other vendor will use similar technology to go beyond x86, or even ARM and have instruction set agnostic CPU...

i think something you get wrong is that RISC is not inherently BETTER than CISC. you mention apple macs were RISC but they moved to intel CISC chips. you know why? because the motorola RISC chip was getting killed by the intel chips. as "inefficient" as CISC was, it was beating the crap out of the RISC contenders of the time including MOTOROLA, SGI and DEC. in fact, you can look at the disruption/apple vs intel graphs and compare it to the sgi/dec/motorola vs intel in the 90s and see something almost exactly akin.  we've seen this before.  and even though you acknowledge that RISC chips were on desktops before - as with SGI and macs, you still insist on repeating the idea that RISC on desktop is somehow new this time.  also, it's probably disingenuous to call this a showdown between RISC and CISC. modern RISC chips have a lot of CISCy like features and modern CISC chips have a lot of RISCy like features. there has been a lot of cross pollination between architectures.  but yeah, the current state of apple's arm chips is big news but it just seems like you're trying to make it bigger and more revolutionary than it actually is - even though all by itself, it's plenty big news. this kind of power with the savings in energy have implications for not only portables but data centers where power consumption is a huge issue.

This is a complete bullshit. x86 CPU-s (both Intel and AMD) are RISC processors inside! Yes, they are eating CISC instructions, but the first step they make is to compile it to microops, which are the real instructions of their CPU. This conversion takes some transistors, but only a few percents. x86 eats more, because they have fancy things like huge cache, branch predictor, out of order execution, etc. to make ONE SINGLE THREAD fast. Similarly, ARM has CISC instructions like Neon and so.  The reason why Apple's M1 is good is mostly the extremely advanced lithography they use (TSMC 5nm). They are about 2 generations ahead of Intel's 14nm and one generation ahead of AMD (TSMC 7nm). The second, less important factor is that you usually compare the M1 Apple to the Intel Apple, which never had a decent cooling. As a conclusion: Apple made something big by putting a decent, upgraded mobile chip into a laptop and showing that it may be a more viable alternative than putting a downgraded desktop processor into the same machine. This may be a fatal hit on x86 and/or Intel, but this is because Intel's the lack of advance in years, not because of the instruction set.
Watch this video David it gives you a good idea what went on since the mid 80s its very good and spot on.
The report is imprecise, confuses the fundamentals and almost bursts with personal (mis-) interpretation of you and the video examples you present. The "feelings" of users are nothing worth against concrete measurements like benchmarks. Anyone who has a little knowledge of thermodynamics laughs half-dead caused by the information about the performance of computers you present. And the conclusions you draw in some cases? Pulled by the hair! For example: You are very confused by the topic of microprocessor instruction sets. It is not important for the performance of hardware what instruction set is used. The overall architecture of a complete system plays a role in the performance of a system in solving a specific problem. The ISA is more important for programming ... if you are a compiler engineer. Most, when not all differences are abstracted away if you are an end-user or programmer. Don't take me wrong, an ARM processor with hardware extensions (and with a corresponding instruction set) for making french-fries is by definition better in making french-fries as your ordinary Intel X86. That comparison is not only invalid but it shows how the use case dictates the form and shape of the tool, here a freely invented fries making micro-processor:o) At the end the technology boils down the the building blocks of digital technology: How good can I make my transistors? This questions decides about the efficiency of the chip. Not its architecture. There are differences between architectures, yes. But I wouldn't suggest to boast the differences in performance. These are rather marginal in all modern architectures. Just look at it this way: many roads lead to Rome.  Too bad i like your videos. This went wrong. Next time:)

Im a pc hardware guy and I have to say, i was blown away on how good the M1 chips are. I would be using Apple if their devices are repairable. But a few corrections, you stated that a a x86 chip takes multiple cycles to complete a instruction while a ARM chip uses just one. That is somewhat true, but its not entirely accurate, the most common x86 instructions take 1 cycle, infact modern processors execute multiple instructions per cycle, hundreds per clock, this is the same thing with ARM chips. The problem as you stated correctly is that there are instructions in the x86 instruction set that are practically never used. This takes space away from circutry that could be used to increase IPC even more. Think of it as a car that is made to go as fast as possible. That car with a x86 architehture would need 2 x 25" subwoofers and pro adio everywhere, fit 6 passengers, a fridge, 250l of storage space, Rgb lights, and whatever crap you can think of. You do use them sometimes but rarely. The same car with ARM needs a driver and to go as fast as possible. All that space needed for the x86 shit can be used to shove a massive engine in the car.

How does this change the entire industry ?  ARM processor manufacturers such as Qualcomm, MediaTek are still not very interested in building processors for the PC market, They have a couple of processors for the ChromeBook and Windows RT was dead before it even got started. Microsoft has no real reason to work with Qualcomm in building up a better ARM chip and ship Windows on it.  Apple has built a great ARM processor which can beat the x86 processors in computing but Apple will never sell their chips to anyone unless you buy a Mac along with it. However the majority of PC sales are Windows based machines and without a great ARM chip from Qualcomm or MediaTek, This will be restricted to Mac owners.  This chip enables Apple to keep more of the profit to themselves rather than giving some of it to Intel or AMD but does not change anything within the industry unless you consider only the Mac world as the entire industry

Because of the different format, geek bench is not a good test for x86 against m1.  It turns out that Apple‚Äôs M1 single-threaded benchmarks are even more misleading than we originally anticipated. According to a¬†source, the single-threaded tests that were thrown around in the last month or so, most notably Geekbench, and Cinebench don‚Äôt properly utilize x86 CPUs  https://wccftech.com/why-apple-m1-single-core-comparisons-are-fundamentally-flawed-with-benchmarks/  This totally explains fully why the 4 core 11th gen cpu from intel matches or beats the m1 in single core, and scores 6700 with 4 cores, against 7700 m1 macs with 8cores.  In current single core benchmarks, they are only using one thread of the x86 cpu, which means it is not recording 30% of its performance.  So in actuality, intel and amd have the highest single core, and multicore scores currently on the market.  Apple came close, but no cigar, if you take that fact into consideration.  The M1's are still fantastic buys, not because they have faster cores, they do not, but because of their machine learning, ai, special encoding, rendering, decoding, custom chips for video and photos, and their new architecture, that puts everything close on a 5nm chip, allowing for more transistors, and more performance per watt, like Huawei, then 7nm, and 10nm x86 chips, that need more power, more cooling, and more room.  True techie's will see past the hype, and limitations, and love all of the competition in the cpu space, each has pluses, and minuses, and we all benefit.  Just be careful not to get caught up in all the hype of the m1, or Huawei, Qualcomm,  Intel, AMD, and others, when they release new cpu's, and is mostly advertising and propaganda.

Million Dollar Potential in Ruvol  I have invented a Board Game [still unpublished and not yet out in the market] that is guaranteed to be far more challenging and exciting than CHESS.  I called it ‚ÄúRUVOL.‚Äù    Over time, Ruvol will surpass chess as the ‚ÄúNumber One Board Game in the World.‚Äù   Why am I so sure about this?  Because I am an avid chess player myself.    The weakness of chess is it always starts in fixed positions that the opening moves become ‚Äúmemorizable.‚Äù  In fact, not a few have so mastered the moves that they can play against their opponents ‚Äúblindfolded.‚Äù  It is for this very reason that the great Bobby Fischer introduced his so-called ‚ÄúFischer Random Chess,‚Äù where the starting position of the pieces is ‚Äúrandomized‚Äù to make the memorization of openings impracticable.  Fortunately, it is also for this reason that I invented Ruvol where ‚Äúevery game‚Äù has been calculated to be a challenging one to play.  HOW IS RUVOL PLAYED?  Ruvol is played somewhat like chess.  It is played by two players.  It uses a board that is rectangular in shape but containing more number of squares than chess.  It has equal number of pieces on each side of the board, where each type of piece moves in distinct ways.  However, if the way to win chess is to checkmate the opponent‚Äôs king, the way to win Ruvol is to be able to cross a designated line.    But there‚Äôs one big advantage Ruvol has over chess:  The Ruvol pieces are randomly placed at the start of ‚Äúevery game‚Äù which makes it impossible for any clever player to memorize the moves.    A MILLION DOLLAR POTENTIAL IN RUVOL!  The people who play chess will be the same people who will play Ruvol.  In my Google search, I learned there are around 800 million chess players in the world.  These 800 million players comprise the ‚ÄúTotal Potential Buyers‚Äù of Ruvol across the globe.  At an average profit of just US$3 per set, the ‚ÄúGlobal Income Potential‚Äù of Ruvol then is US$2.4 billion.  Assuming only 1% of it will buy each year, the annual global potential sale of Ruvol is US$24M.  I AM LOOKING FOR AN INVESTOR! Good video, however I think that the whole RISC vs. CISC subject is a red herring. We are far beyond the point where there is a clear distinction between the two: ARM instruction set has been expanding dramatically over the years, and modern Intel CPUs are actually "RISC" internally (the CPU doesn't run x86 instructions directly, instead they are converted into a simplified instruction set before execution). Moreover, these differences mattered 20+ years ago when the majority of transistors actually had to be dedicated to implementing the instruction set, however nowadays this is no longer the case - most of CPU transistors are various caches (and in the case of M1, also actual main RAM), and the actual instruction loading / ALU part is comparatively trivial.
So anyone owns Intel shares? Watch out.

ARM is not 100% RISC. At Pure RISC all instructions has same length and  clock cycle. ARM create multi RISC components that group instructions based on execution cycle so we see SOC not CPU. This is future. Take advantage of RISC simplesty and CISC performance. But virtualization is a challenge on this model.
It is a long awaited return to a RISC Architecture similar to that of the beloved PowerPC single chips. Maybe the Megahertz myth will come back too.

ARM really isn't RISC anymore by formal definitoons. It's more of a highly optimized, leaner CISC processor. It's definitely a reduced instruction set compared to x86, but it's no longer pure, unadulterated, simple RISC.
It‚Äôs worth pointing out that it‚Äôs not all about the CPU, per se. It‚Äôs the high level of integration and bandwidth of memory and I/O subsystems as well. On board Unified memory for the CPU, GPU and NPU, and SSD likewise. Such tight coupling of these components (which unfortunately means non upgradable components), eventually with the operating system as well (from the same manufacturer). You have to wonder how Samsung, Microsoft, Android etc are ever going to be able to compete. I‚Äôm mostly a Linux and Windows guy, with iOS for my mobile devices, but I‚Äôve seen this tight coupling of hardware and software coming for a long time. Cover me, I‚Äôm going in for an M1 Mac Mini... üò≥ü§ò

The M1 Macbook Air with capability of running App Store Apps is also a step in the right direction but from the other direction. Unfortunately we won't have access to every app store app, but developers have a way to easily distribute their software to the M1 platform through the App store. I can only hope that these innovations from the M1 can light a fire under competitors like Microsoft and Google to innovate better and more efficiently in the mobile computing space, and in turn give Apple real competition to force their hand at a true 2-in-1 laptop, with the consumers ultimately being the winner.

You missed out an important part of the story which was that it was Apple who went to Acorn and asked them to spin off ARM as a separate company because they wanted to use the ARM in their Newton. From Wikipedia "The company was founded in November 1990 as Advanced RISC Machines Ltd and structured as a joint venture between Acorn Computers, Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.) and VLSI Technology". To say that it was all Intel's own fault is over simplifying the story. Apple has been involved with ARM almost from the beginning, long before anyone else and was the 2nd company, after the creator Acorn Computers, to use the ARM chip. Your video suggests that Apple came to ARM late in the game. Far from it!!!

This is full of factual errors. Long time ago ( as in about 20 year ) there were 2 platforms RISC and CISC. ARM is a version of RISC and x86 used to be a version of CISC. Only today x86, just like ARM, executes RISC instructions internally and really the only difference is that software sends CISC instructions to a x86 CPU which are then translated/decoded to RISC for internal processing. Before someone goes all preachy proclaiming that the decoder is the problem it really isn't and it uses between 3-5% of extra power and that statement has been independently verified many times.  What Apple did with M1 is not at all brining a mobile CPU to a laptop/desktop. M1 is and evolution of current CPU design thinking and the true innovation here is removing the memory controller and using a "shared" memory pool for GPU and CPU. That's really not that uncommon or revolutionary. AMD has CPU/GPU on chip and sharing memory between CPU and GPU is common practice with integrated graphics cards. What Apple did is they used the best of everything and used what would normally be considered a low end technique to build a high end processing unit ( not sure it can be called a CPU anymore ). And yes the results are AMAZING. Also the reason why this is even possible and you can still run existing software is simply because Apple replaced the hardware decoder found in x86 with a software decoder. And the best part is that once software is reworked to natively use RISC and not need the decoder, you can expect at least 3-5% gain in speed and/or battery performance.  Also, you totally got the history of why CISC was prevalent wrong. It's all about cost of memory. CISC allowed for better reuse of memory and then RAM was very very expensive and there simply wasn't the technological means of having more, CISC was clearly the better technology. But that hasn't been the case for a long time now and today Apple has access to memory that runs at clock speeds similar to what a CPU runs at. That's also why now is the time to make a switch. It also happens to be the reason why Nvidia bought Arm. If M1 is the future of Macs and Intel is not the future of PCs then you clearly have a gap in the market. Nvidia wants to make sure they are part of the conversation especially if the future of GPUs is not a physical board that plug into another physical board.
'M1' ? Cmon, Apple - you should have delivered Skynet by now.
This so well made ! Like a netflix documentary üëè

The M1 is limited to 16 GB of RAM because it uses In-Package memory (the ram is part of the SoC). Clearly, 16 GB is not enough for a Mac Pro, so they will probably offer machines with (additional?) external RAM. The internal RAM essentially becomes another cache at that point (think L4).

Reality check: AMD leads, not Intel AMD also going to 5nm in their next line of products and also promising big performance gains. Apple gets their silicon from TSMC, as AMD does also. Geekbench is a useless benchmark for many reasons. The single core performance is meaningless because single core is only important for gaming, and these chips are a million miles away from being good enough for AAA titles at high resolutions and settings. In multi-core they're still a good way behind a budget gaming CPUs on 7nm so will be even further behind when AMD go to the same 5nm silicon Apple's clout allowed them to grab first. This will be the case going forwards where Apple's clout will get them the newest silicon but it will won't be enough to overhaul the gap, which will then be subsequently re-established when AMD move onto the same node.  While there are clear benefits of a system on a chip design and those benefits will outweigh the drawbacks for the majority, it does come at the expense of expandability, which will inhibit power users who might have otherwise been drawn in by the combination of portability, power and affordability.   Positives It is a move towards desktop performance in laptops and without breaking the bank.  It's definitely an improvement on lacklustre performance from Intel and this move definitely makes sense for Apple. Most people who want to use OS X will see exceptional real world performance gains in using M1 devices if they're unconcerned by the privacy concerns in Big Sur - which are not inherently related to the M1 but instead the OS they will have to be run on.

There's an irony in the used of the image of a Commodore Pet @1:51 whilst talking about desktop computers and x86 architecture. That computer used the MOS 6502 processor and, if anything, it was that which inspired the original developers of the ARM architecture who had used the same processor on the BBC micro designed by Acorn. The 6502 had a very stripped-down design, and whilst it was not exactly a RISC processor, it was markedly simple compared to the 8086 that appeared 3 years later. Following a visit to the USA developers, the Acorn team realised that it didn't take a huge team to design a stripped-down processor, and hence ARM was born.  One point that is also missed in the history part of this video is that when ARM was split off from Acorn, it was as a joint venture between Acorn, Apple and VLSI technologies. It was money raised by this that allowed the development of the architecture and the targeting of the low power market.  Apple were to sell their shares later when they needed the money for other investments. What helped make ARM so successful was not so much the inherent advantages of their particular RISC architecture, but the licensing model and their perceived neutrality in that they did not produce end-user gear. In essence, it was extremely cheap for mass market products. The same is not true of Intel processors, which are highly proprietary (save where licences are held by other fabricators - now, essentially, meaning AMD). Intel got rich being able to charge premium prices into what was largely a captive marked as long as they could stay just ahead of the compatible competition. Intel were never set up to make money the way that ARM did. The latter was, in terms of turnover and capital value, a minnow. Even now, based on what Nvidia are prepared to pay, Intel is still worth six times ARM. I don't think Intel could have survived on the thin margin business that ARM specialised in.  A further irony is that RISC chips are no longer that simple. There are many, specialist instruction extensions which are aimed at particular aspects of commonly used functions, often aimed at graphics. However, these haven't emerged from producing a grand, do it all generalised computer architecture, but specific needs that have been determined through experience.

I've been around RISC chips for decades and it comes down to something I learned out of grad school working on a POS banking app that used PDP-11's that they blew the hw budget on booze so no FP accelator ie couldn't do decminals fractions etc. So for most business apps you will need a CISC chip even it's a PCODE like the ALPHA or x86 as pure RISC can't cut it (hello packed decimal math in COBOL as customers don't like getting credited 999.66666666666). So for phones and overpriced laptops using code that leans toward Floating Point instructions, but not enterprize computing. Also ARM can't do real paralelle computing well. Trying comparing the apple M chip vs AMD's threadripper saying storing into 128TB Oracle database table.  I really don't see the M chip offering 128 threads.

Mac started with RISC processor the Power processor from IBM/Motorolla
There are a number of factual errors in this video, starting with the claims that the M1 is a mobile chip (it's not) and that the M1 is based on the ARM architecture. Again, it's not. There is a reason why the Apple A-series chips have been blowing the ARM-architecture chips in almost every other device (mostly Android) out of the water. From the Snapdragon to the Exynos, not a single ARM chip comes anywhere near the performance, with equivalent Ax chips at least 400% faster (and often more). The Apple Silicon chips are NOT based on the ARM reference architecture. Instead, they merely utilize the ARM reference instruction set (the list of commands the CPU performs). While ARM also published a reference hardware architecture, the hardware to implement those commands, that almost all other manufacturers use to design their chips, unlike those other manufacturers, Apple does NOT use the ARM reference architecture. Instead, the internal architecture of the Ax and Mx chips was entirely designed in-house by Apple. The statements made in this video get the facts 180¬∞ backward. Apple did not get an architectural license from ARM to design their own chip. This doesn't even makes sense! You don't buy a license to an architecture just to throw it away and develop your own! This video ignores this fact, comparing Apple Silicon chips to Intel, but neglecting to make the also important comparison to other ARM designs, leaving the impression that the benefits here comes solely from the ARM architecture vs Intel, RISC vs CISC, when, in fact, Intel still outperforms ALL other ARM architecture chips in terms of top speed, and the story here is just as much Apple Silicons proprietary architecture and chip design as much or more as it is from anything having to two with the benefits of RISC instruction sets over CISC.

ibm had the powerpc chip 20 years ago that did 16 bit, 32bit, 64bit and by flipping one bit in the chip could do 256 bit processing. the problem was that intel convinced everyone that clock speed was the only way to calculate processor efficiency. So, even though the power chip was better at work, hertz was propagandized as the only valid method to evaluate a cpu. We had a processor called the system as400 that actually could out perform the large corporate systems cheaper, but since it could cut into the revenue of the large main frames it was held back. Innovation is often stifled by desire of the bean counters for maximum profit today without regard for the future.

You talk a lot about the power efficiency advantages of RISC vs CISC, and while I don't want to discount there, there may be another explanation for it's massive performance advantage: having it's RAM on the same die as the CPU.  On traditional desktops, the high frequency (and long transmission lines) of separate RAM chips is a major source of errors, tricks, and importantly, delays, with the resulting cache misses. Having the RAM directly on the same die, with optimized transmission lines (based on nanometer scale optimizations and precision), maybe the real source of the large performance increase.  Having it as a RISC architecture may have facilitated this move, as it means you don't have to worry about thermals as much, and you can have a larger chip without a resulting larger heatsink, so the fact that it's ARM is still an advantage. But the change of on-die RAM shouldn't be understated.

ARM is a design specific by a British company, not a type of processor, the actual word would be "RISC", or "reduced instruction set computer", and x86 is a set of instructions invented by Intel, later modified by both Intel and AMD to form x86-64bit with many more complex instructions (and thereby capabilities/Functions), what you meant by "x86" is by definition called "CISC", or "complex instruction set computer", a name that indicate the difference between RISC and more advanced CISC processors. On to Apple then, fans of the trillion-dollar mass corporation that is "Apple .inc" like to mention whenever they think Apple have done something that by fact has already been done, but without the apple logo and the +150% markup in pricing, but the fact here is that Apple in efforts of cutting their own cost has designed an entire ARM based processor utilizing RISC designs that are only really good for running simple programs on, or "apps" as they are called.  Why is RISC not as good as CISC processors? It's down to the fact that a RISC based CPU has fewer instructions (which limits program complexity), the core architecture is simpler and less sophisticated than a CISC based one, and while a CISC based CPU can often do many instructions per cycle, a RISC based CPU can at most do 1-3 instructions per cycle, (cycle=clock=1Hz*MHz or higher). There's a reason why Apple is the first with this, and it's not for good reasons nor is it "changing the entire industry".

Nice work on working on ARM, Apple. But the reality is the M1 chip has the same TDP as AMD's 4800u. Each M1 core is about 25% faster than each 4800u core, but when you consider hyper-threading, each logical 4800u has half the TDP of each M1 core. Not to downplay what Apple has achieved, but some articles flying around the internet seem to be putting it up as the greatest chip ever built when in reality it has worse performance per watt figures than AMD's last generation architecture (zen 2),  even when on an advanced node (5nm).

There are so many misleading statements in this video it hurts.  There seems to be a trend here that focuses on single-core performance, and simultaneously ignores mutli-core performance.  M1 is not a faster CPU than a 10900K, and in fact the 10900k runs circles around the M1 in multicore performance, even after you take the core count difference into account.  The guy talking about how the M1 benchmarks on Xcode were about the same as a 3950x has no idea what he is talking about, Xcode or MacOS were never optimized to run on a 3950X.  In fact, the 3950X stomps the M1 in almost every multi-core benchmark, while holding it's own in single-core performance.  Go look at benchmarks comparing the 3950X and M1 on adobe premier or something similar that is optimized for both systems, it will tell you a completely different story.    The M1 is a very impressive chip.  It is revolutionary for a lot of reasons, and it is indicative of the future trend of mobile chips, but lets not deceive people by making half-statements as if they are matter of fact.  We still have the chips we do from Intel and AMD because they serve purposes and can do things that M1 can't, and still outperform M1 in real-world, and benchmark testing.

Nowadays an important factor in performance is how fast information travels within a chip. E.g. this is the main problem for GPUs. With x86 extra transistors taking precious space on chip, its overall performance will fall behind ARM. Though, of course ARM processors performance cap won't be growing at its current pace a few years down the line.

Aaaaaaaaaahhhhh .
A CPU is still limited to using 8 bits at a time. If you are using 16, 32 or 64 bit operations, the operation must be broken down to 8 bit pieces before the CPU, each processed and then recombined after the CPU to get the result. RISC doesn't have any delay before or after the processor avoiding those bottlenecks. Many mainframe architectures like IBM AS/400 do this as well which makes them extremely fast, reliable and lower power consumption.

"No energy system can produce sum useful energy in excess of the total energy put into constructing it. This universal truth applies to all energy systems [including digital systems]. Energy, like time, only flows in one direction, from past to future."
If there was ever a time for IBM with its various partners, to come up with a new POWER chip, now is that time. Apple did the smart thing once it realized that ARM could reach parity with x86. In a mobile device, battery life is king. For 98% of mobile users, if it doesn't run for 24 hours without a charge, there is something wrong with it and the mfg should expect a warranty claim. Apple simply realized this and realized that the reverse is also true. Laptop users have their devices plugged in most of the time and with that fact in mind, you can take a lightweight ARM, beef it way up to handle desktop loads and it will go toe to toe with Intel.  And then the user unplugs the laptop, the CPU quietly goes into low power mode, behaves like a mobile chip and you get awesome battery life.   IBM could correct some of the goofy quirks with the POWER line, and make a real run at the x86 space. POWER already owns high performance computing, and with Samsung making 7nm POWER chips, there is no reason they couldn't be scaled to fit in desktops, laptops, etc. The biggest thing is going to be selling the software to turn people away from Intel. A few BSD and linux distributions already support POWER architecture which means that high performance systems in the enterprise are already perfect targets for new software that can take advantage of POWER. IBM would need to consider a push into offering software as a service and trying to compete with Microsoft with its Azure and O356 offerings, but the trick here is making the software cheap/free and getting your hardware out there. While IBM may have sold off Notes/Domino to HCL a year ago, there are a couple options that could provide an opportunity. Groupwise has basically languished and passed through a few hands in the last few years.  As an old admin, I'd much rather administer a Groupwise installation than Exchange. Exchange is a fucking kluge and has been for years. Groupwise admin through eDirectory is so much easier. And guess what OS happens to natively support POWER architecture? SUSE does. SAP HANA?  POWER does it better than x86. It wouldn't take much to port Groupwise over, especially as it already happily runs on SLES. Or just buy Domino/Notes back from HCL. In the meantime, port something like Libreoffice into a cloud-accessible form, and get Adobe and Autodesk on-board.  POWER does virtualization in the hardware and has for years, rather than be yet another added instruction with x86-64.   But it comes down to IBM wanting to get back into 'big iron' so to speak. They have all that experience with big mainframes and System Z stretching back decades. It doesn't take much to scale that down or decide you're going to make a push into smaller enterprise stuff.

Impressive evolution of processing efficiency by an Apple acquisition. If Apple opened up their walled garden and invested some of that pile of cash on next generation enterprise computing, server technology, and systems management they could kill off MS and Intel fairly quickly or spur them towards another technology leap.   Power efficiency is a big win for more than mobile computing. Computers are so widespread now they are a significant driver for the worlds electrical power generation needs in spite of a time of higher environmental awareness about where all that power is going to come from. Less power consumption is always good. It also means less waste heat to need cooling which is another sizable power consumer especially in large offices, data centers, and future vehicles on Earth and in space. Apple could potentially make a valid value argument in spite of their notoriously higher prices if you look at it with the cost of ownership over the products lifetime.

0:44 Recently?   There is nothing recent about being impossible to repair.  Since 2007, iPhones have never had easily-replaceable batteries.  The batteries have been glued into the device on nearly all Apple products for a decade now.  In 2008, they would refuse to repair the A1226/A1260 macbooks if the screen didn't turn on, but the issue that usually caused this was dead gpus, resulting in nothing being displayed on the screen, which was Apple's loophole to not give customers the repair.  Apple has been using pentalope screws since 2009, soldering in ram on macbook airs since 2010, and soldering ram in on pros since 2013.
The Kirin chip has similar or better performance that may broaden competition
