This is not really new - its been known for a long time that RISC outperforms CISC.  To the point that Intel chips are a CISC wrapper around a RISC core.  But that wrapper itself can be somewhat important in certain applications.  If you need one of those rarely-used instructions that doesn't exist on your RISC chip, you have to emulate it and an "instruction" that might take 12 cycles on a CISC chip ends up taking 100s of cycles to emulate via software.  But of course they're called "rarely-used" for a reason.  Most people don't care.  So OK lets ignore that for now and look at the second big problem with ditching Intel, and why Apple's change won't really be all that "disruptive" overall - compatibility.  I don't know what all Apple's included in their compatibility layer.  I've heard the programs that work tend to work pretty well, but I've also heard that many programs simply don't work.  You always have a trade-off in computing.  Certainly tech in general always progresses but its unlikely that Apple is _that_ much ahead of everyone else without giving something up, and compatibility has always been something they were pretty "flexible" with.  Intel (and Microsoft) have always put compatibility right at the top of the charts, as has IBM and Sun/Oracle and all of the other major computer companies.  Apple is different though.  Apple doesn't tend to sell multi-million dollar server systems that host infrastructure-critical banking platforms and the like.  If Intel gives up compatibility they have close to 500 of the Fortune 500 companies breathing down their necks.  If Apple gives up compatibility they have a handful of cranky people screaming at their minimum wage Apple Store workers and they really don't care.  Now maybe they've made some true innovations that the rest of the computing industry has managed to overlook, but from everything I've seen so far the biggest "innovation" is just telling people to go buy M1-enabled upgrades for all of their software.  And that's not even new to them - its basically what they did when they switched from PowerPC to x86.  Sure they included an emulation mode then too, and it also worked OK but kind of spotty.  And nobody really cared because Apple customers have long been used to re-buying crap every other year so what's one more thing?
So Apple took an ARM chip, modified it and rebranded is as the M1... Big whoop. Keep in mind that the "fastest CPU" claim is for single core performance only. Less expensive? LOL not really... A student can easily get away with using s $300 PC as opposed to a $1200 MAC.

AMD Ryzen 9 5900X Is still king though.  Intel may be falling behind but AMD has taken the lead with desktop processors.  The Ryzen 9 5900x is 30% faster in Cinebench 15 64-bit single-core and 264% faster in multicore, compared to M1.  Overall the AMD is FAR superior in Desktop application. yes yes I know the M1 is a laptop CPU. But this video claims the M1 compares to top end desktop CPUs. AMD is the leader there now, NOT intel. But im not surprised Apple chose to compare itself to Intel.  Overall the Ryzen 9 5900x is obliterating ALL of the competition.  Compared to the M1 272.5% faster (about 3.5 times) in synthetic tests Higher maximum frequency (4800 vs 3200 MHz) AVX (Advanced Vector Extensions - a set of SIMD instructions working with 128- and 256-bit registers) AVX2 (Advanced Vector Extensions 2 - an extension to AVX, the set of SIMD instructions working with 128- and 256-bit registers) AES (Advanced Encryption Standard instructions set - hardware acceleration of AES encryption and decryption. Speeds up encryption software, e.g. Veracrypt) x86-64 (a general name for 64-bit extension of x86 instruction set. There are AMD64 and Intel 64 versions that differ very little) Virtualization (Hardware acceleration of virtual machines) Unlocked AES-NI save  Again, if you want a high end laptop go with the M1. I doubt a RISC cpu will ever overpower a CISC cpu. In fact this would violate all known laws of computer architecture itself. RISC cpus are designed with power efficiency in mind, not performance. The ARM architecture is not exactly RISC because it does contain some complex instructions. I'd call it at best a SCISC (semi complex instruction set computer). It also seems at least in smartphones that the ARM cpu technique is to have more but less powerful cores, in which some only work when necessary. This of course, only works in highly parallel scenarios, which is not always the case in desktop computing.  And I have yet to see an ARM cpu overpower an i7 or i9 (or AMD equivalent) CPU. Until we got the actual side by side comparison, It's very scammy to say ARM more performant than x86_64. How do those CPUs handle heavy video editing? CPU Rendering? Cryptography (ARM cpus already do this)? And Macs have always been underperformant and pretty weak because their hardware has limited clocking dude to the fact the slim casing increases overheating by a lot. Macs in general are shinny but weak for demanding tasks, which might or might not be a problem for the average user. I'd love to see ARM win over x86_64, but I'll wait for the results.  And of course I doubt Rosetta will ever achieve good performance with demanding apps. If it does, then Apple will indeed raise some points in my consideration :)

2:57 That's a technically unfair comparison. Didn't expect any from "youtubers".  Adobe Photoshop is not rebuilt for ARM64 on the Surface Pro X, but they were demonstrating the emulation of x86 apps on Windows 10 ARM. Where as, knowing apple's walled garden app store, that version of Photoshop was clearly recompiled for ARM, hence the smooth performance. What Windows demonstrated is actually much more, that users can bring their older apps to Windows 10 ARM, despite their architecture.

As always Apple took the credit from someone else, it's RISC they didn't develop that, they just placed and played to use it efficiently with their OS, that's all.
The RISC vs CISC separation no longer exists nowadays. Using raw instructions for execution is no longer efficient enough, and thus both x86 and ARM chips decode instructions to micro-operations and execute them instead. (Yes, ARM does it too.)
An interesting video, sadly not very accurate.  The video doesnt differentiate between Instruction Set and Core Architecture. The ISA describes the interface the software is using, not how the hardware is working. The last Intel CPU with CISC cores were the original Pentium. Starting with the Pentium Pro the CPUs switched to RISC cores and kept only the old ISA for compatibility. That comes with some overhead for the decoders which had to translate CISC instructions for the RISC cores. That's why ARM and other RISC ISAs are better suited for ultra low power tasks. For general purpose tasks it doesn't make much of a difference nowadays because Intel and AMD optimized their decoders a lot.  The M1 has a very well designed core achitecture that can compete with Intel and AMD. What makes M1 so energy efficient is not the ISA. The cores might be a bit more efficient than the x86 competition, but not as much as you might think. Apple is using a better manufacturing process, has significant lower IO-Bandwith (which consumes a lot of energy in modern systems), uses quite a few special purpose blocks and integrates all important blocks on die or at least on package. That allows for shorter paths which means lower voltages and latencies with potential for higher clock-rates. For mobile devices that are only available with a fixed set of configurations that's ok, but you should be aware of the constraints that come with it. You don't have PCIe, RAM or a m.2 slots. So no more RAM or SSD space, no 10Gbit network. If a new video codec comes out, you loose hardware-acceleration if you want to use it. All that is (at least in principle) possible with all Intel Core or AMD Ryzen chips no matter if they're targeted for mobile, desktop or server systems. For a fair comparison we need to wait either for Apple to design a desktop chip or for AMD/Intel to design comparible pure mobile designs.
Honestly it's jusy tsmc and risc, nothing amazing here
They are still bad at some things. Shifting multitasking between many applications, all at the same time? Still cant beat multi cores.

This might be revolutionary. Like Apple ways or not, they're where they are for this kind of reason. I wonder how it will inspire other manufacturers.
Upon learning about the M1 chip I thought "Oh wait, Apple did something that wasn't just some kind of iPants for only $1399.99?!" Now that it seems the idea was decades in the making, envisioned by Steve Jobbs himself, everything makes sense again.
Apple: "You know, we should 'go back to' RISC chips.   They might even make our chunky OS run as smooth as linux does on intel chips."   PPC was RISC.   This is hardly any paradigm shift.   And they're certainly not changing the industry.  Their architecture is closed.   Apple may be changing the appleverse, but that will remain the domain of those with large amounts of disposable income who don't mind devices engineered to likely fail in a couple of years.  They just expect you to buy the new model then anyway.
Even with the M1 there's still an elephant in the room: what of the higher end machines like the iMac Pro and the Mac Pro? Well, you can be certain Apple have you covered. They would not have pushed the button on this transition if they weren't damn certain they could deliver these higher-end machines AND have them outperform current models. One advantage Apple has in this regard is that the chip designers work hand-in-hand with the OS software team which enables each group to tweak their designs to optimise the entire system holistically. As Alan Kay said many years ago, if you want to write truly great software, you have to build your own hardware.  I strongly suspect Apple already have floorplans for the M2, M3 and M4 ready for testing. Reading the tea leaves, here's where I think it could be going: a future high-end M-series SoC will probably have 16 CPU cores, 16 GPU cores and 32 NE cores with up to 512GB of high-bandwith low-latency RAM strapped to the side. A Mac Pro could have four of these on board and possibly even the ability to add additional daughter cards each with up to 4 SoCs‚Äîif Fugaku is anything to go by, this kind of scalability is certainly possible.  A truly scary prospect is, what if future M-series SoCs were taped out on gallium nitride rather than silicon? GaN moves electrons about hundreds of times faster than silicon, allowing for clock frequencies in the THz range, potentially increasing performance by three orders of magnitude simply by virtue of a change in materials science.  The next few years are going to be very interesting.
propaganda...
What do you think Apple's high-end desktop chips will look like?   A lot of the performance and efficiency of this M1 chip comes from the on-package memory. Having ultra fast, low power memory on-package not only means data can be accessed much faster but it also requires a lot less power to do this compared to normal DIMMs of DDR4, the only issue is it's relatively expensive, especially when you need a lot. I think the entire Apple performance philosophy will rely on this design, so I could see there being a 32GB, 64GB and 128GB version of the CPUs for the high end desktops. Although at $200 per 8GB that would mean a 128GB chip would cost $3200 in RAM alone and that's using the much cheaper DDR4L when I believe they might (should) move to HBM.   There is a chance they will still max out at 16GB or maybe up to 32GB of on-package memory, then rely on having a secondary slower 'normal' RAM option, maybe DDR5 depending when these come out, that can be configured to huge capacities at slightly more palatable prices.  But my money would be on Apple producing a monster chip (similar in design to the Fujitsu A64FX chip) with something like 128GB of ultra fast HBM, 8 layers giving around 4TB/s of bandwidth, to be used as the unified memory for the whole chip which is then directly connected to a PCIE 5 'hyper-drive' SSD over 16 or more lanes. These could actually be very fast, offering up to 128GB/s on PCIE-5 (over 16 lanes). Also PCIE-6 isn't that far off, probably 2023 which doubles this again to 256GB/s. These speeds are actually faster than 8 channels of fast DDR4 and you can make these drives much larger and cheaper! We really could see the death of normal DDR memory on DIMM with a move to ultra fast on-die / on-package system memory plus ultra fast SSDs. Latency might be an issue but a small price to pay for the overall massive performance boost we would see from a shift to system designs like this.   As ever the main enemy on monster chips is heat but ARM architectures have a massive advantage here over x86 plus switching to HBM rather than DDR will help a fair bit too.  I could see the top end Mac Pro Chip in 2021 looking something like this:  32 core CPU (all high performance Firestorm cores) 128 core GPU 128 core Neural Engine 128GB HBM  Built on TSMC's 5nm+ (it's too early for 4nm or 3nm)  Price: ~$15-20k
Imagine that M1 in the hands of Razor or Asus or Dell.

You totally missed out on three additional key points about the new M1 processors:¬†   1.  The inclusion of M1 replacing Intel has allowed Apple to drop the prices of all its model across the board because they nolonger have to pay any hefty license and branding tech royalties to Intel.  This means Apples new product line is now more in line cost-wise to the consumer as an otherwise comparably equipped PC AND Apple its absorbing more profits at the same time by drinking their own cool aide... That move simultaneously makes their brand more competitive on the upfront cost for those who mainly only care about sticker shock.  But its a move that also makes deeper thinking people realize there is actually nothing truly "comparable" in the PC flavor because Apple's new hardware has outclassed the competition not just in one category but nearly every category at once by this move.   2.  Moving away from Intel to "in-house" is all a major bonus to the security and dependability of their platform.  Not only is Apple completely in control of design and enhancements, they now hold all the keys to data security being they control the flow of data throughout the entire machine now with no outside vendor's hardware now of any significant note that can compromise or surprise Apple with unknown security flaws.  Apple Is now the master of not just their constellation of hardware, but the entire universe it fits in.  Any future cute "hacks" aimed at undermining CPU security will be easier and faster for Apple to deal with because they control everything end to end and don't depend on waiting for another vender to fix things.  Apple will thus having brought all problems and new designs in-house greatly speed responses and fixes thus to uncovered silicon exploits  of their new platform going forward.  3.  This is far more than just a RISC or ARM processor.  This is essentially almost an entire system on a chip (SOC).  .....These chips have something extra-spcial in them going forward which is accelerator cores purpose-built for machine learning.  Yes, you heard me right.. Apple has accelerated special purpose processing cores which will further enhance and accelerate Mac and iOS platform apps with unrivaled power in the world of artificial intelligence and AI.  As we move towards the singularity, this one event stands out  as a point of acceleration towards that theoretical point in time.¬† ¬† 4.  The reduction in power usage in just converting their own massive iTunes and iCloud related datacenter serves from Intel to Apple Silicon will save Apple alone millions annually in power usage.. but will also I predict lead to #5.¬†  5. The huge advantages going forward in massive performance enhancements and power use reduction will incentivize Apple to make a serious push now into the server hardware market, just as a side-effect of modernizing their own server farms to take advantage of these massive gains in power and performance.  New massively powerful multiprocessor-multicore Apple silicon servers will.push Apple Servers into a more competitive posture for gaining market share where they have never seriously gained much at all.  They would be wise to use this moment to go after servers aggressively.

Oh god, the inaccuracies.....  Where do I begin?  No mention of the fact that "the arm processor" isn't even a thing.  ARM themselves haven't  manufactured a single CPU for many years now.  reduceperformanceoffered a multi-core option in the form of Core (1) that Apple made the switch.  Fast-forward to today - ARM devices are in nearly every consumer electronics device EXCEPT x86 laptops.  The jump in adoption was only accelerated by Atmel abandoning support for their 8-bit family of ACICs.  Ironically, the Apple x86 portables have 1 or 2 ARM subsystems (the LED strip, running a  modified WatchOS and the T2 which allows Apple to bypass Intel's horrible "security" tech.)  Not all ARMs are "phone CPUs", nor are Apple's ARM silicon offerings.  In fact, Nearly every electronic device sold today has one or multiple task-specific ARM processors for various functions.  Technologies like HDMi, 4k, and many more would not exist if Intel were in charge.  THE ONLY consumer electronics that run non-ARM silicon are Windows laptops.  I'm glad Apple has moved on.  Intel is one of the laziest tech companies on earth.  Good riddance.
The problem is, that Intels X86 architecture contains a long period of computer evolution. Keeping always upgrade compatibility makes it more and more looking like an medivial town. Resulting in large chip size and high energy consumption. I began 1988 to program something on an M68000 Amiga in assembly. After 1998 I changed to Intel X32 PC with my assembly project. After 2005 I incorporated the AMD X64 architecture. Because CPU's seems to become always bigger, I started after 2015 to invent a new Intel X86-128 architecture. It is shown in my YouTube channel. This new X128 architecture sets the addressing formalism to a new construction with one byte per addressing item. Leading to 32 register with 8 size variants. This results in the opportunity that the X128 CPU can have versions with 32, 64, 128, 256, 512 bits registers for general purpose registers. called LAX, LDX,...,L31. For the X87 and the XMM unit addressing sizes from 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64 and 128 bytes per register/memory position is possible. The X128 CPU architecture must not be used only as 128 Bit CPU. A 32 Bit version for small Coffee machine controllers can be realized as well. The Intel X86-128 architecture is highly scalable from microcontrollers up to scientific super computers. The opcodes are the same as on current X86 processors. The X87 architecture can be expanded to handle floating point numbers with up to 320 decimal digits matching in 1024 bit floating point registers. The X87 and XMM unit must be deeply reformulated to get in usability packages high performance for different application situations with strongly reduced energy consumption, by discarding all medivial old constructions of X86. All old stuff which may be still necessary should be moved to software emulation in the operating system. Making the new X86-128 processor small and energy efficient. The X86 architecture has a beautiful assembly language. ARM don't have it. I fight for a new Intel X86 architecture, to let this better assembly language and my work survive.

Credit to freddyt55555:  "Claims:   Up to 3.5X faster CPU performance  Up to 3.9X faster video processing  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction MacBook Air systems with Apple M1 chip and 8-core GPU, as well as production 1.2GHz quad-core Intel Core i7-based MacBook Air systems...  Conclusion:  M1 has faster CPU performance and "video processing" performance than Intel's craptastic ULV Ice Lake processors.  Claim:  Up to 7.1X faster image processing  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction Mac mini systems with Apple M1 chip, and production 3.6GHz quad-core Intel Core i3-based Mac mini systems  Conclusion:  M1 has faster iGPU than the lowest-spec'd Mac Mini running the Intel Coffee Lake quad-core i3-8100 CPU with Intel UHD graphics  Claim:  Our high‚Äëperformance core is the world‚Äôs fastest CPU core when it comes to low‚Äëpower silicon  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction 13‚Äëinch MacBook Pro systems with Apple M1 chip and 16GB of RAM measuring peak single-thread performance of workloads taken from select industry-standard benchmarks, commercial applications, and open source applications. Comparison made against the highest-performing CPUs for notebooks commercially available at the time of testing. Performance tests are conducted using specific computer systems and reflect the approximate performance of MacBook Pro.  Conclusion:  One of the 4 big cores in the M1 was able to perform better in single-thread mode at peak (not necessarily sustained) than other notebook CPUs, although some of these, most notably 8-core models, would probably crush the M1 in multi-thread performance.  Claims:  Up to 2X faster CPU performance  Matches peak PC performance using 25% of the power  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction 13‚Äëinch MacBook Pro systems with Apple M1 chip and 16GB of RAM. Multithreaded performance measured using select industry‚Äëstandard benchmarks. Comparison made against latest‚Äëgeneration high‚Äëperformance notebooks commercially available at the time of testing. Performance tests are conducted using specific computer systems and reflect the approximate performance of MacBook Pro.  Conclusion:  The M1 is faster and more efficient that other notebook CPUs at cherry-picked benchmarks, but not necessarily in "commercial applications, and open source applications" like in the single-thread comparison. Hmm. Why not?  Claim:  3X CPU performance per watt  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction 13‚Äëinch MacBook Pro systems with Apple M1 chip and 16GB of RAM, as well as previous‚Äëgeneration Mac notebooks. Performance measured using select industry‚Äëstandard benchmarks. Performance tests are conducted using specific computer systems and reflect the approximate performance of MacBook Pro.  Conclusion:  The M1 has better performance per watt than previous Mac notebooks. In this metric, I would hope an ARM based processor would have better numbers than Intel's old heaters. The question is how far back is this "previous-generation" Macs? Why is this metric not compared against "latest‚Äëgeneration high‚Äëperformance notebooks commercially available at the time of testing"?  There are bunch more footnotes that I don't care to look at, but you can see how Apple is comparing the M1 using different metrics against different types of devices."

If there was, and is, no real practical need for the additional instruction sets of CISC, why are they there? I mean can RISC play a piracy-protected 4K Ultra Blu-Ray disc, or does it support a secure memory enclave like Intel SGX? Can it protect your identity, or securely encrypt files or even network connections? These are real questions to be answered before touting RISC as the CISC killer. Because frankly, it sounds like RISC can do few things, and does them well, and efficiently, and fast even, but CISC (x86) is more of a versatile jack-of-all-trades. Each with their own niche markets.

Here is the funny thing that people compare a single vendor hardware and software versus a generic hardware and software ecosystem. The beauty of x86 is its versatility and performance per clock. ARM is great but  require very detailed software effort and needs to be carefully integrated. ios/mac os/android work because of the very tight integration that is put in place for each system. You cant just pick a phone and install a windows on it or swap its RAM from different vendors. ARM is not pure RISC in any of its modern 32/64 bit versions. Its very much a hybrid RISC-CISC approach. Similarly x86 are also hybrids using micro instructions to achieve more capable CISC instructions. The real challenger coming up fast is the OPEN RISC-V. It might be the true competition to both ARM and x86 very soon. The real challenge will be to run un-optimized software that are not built for using special hardware with same performance.

You left out that Apple had an early involvement with ARM. In 1990 Apple wantet to create a personal digital assistant, capable of reading handwriting. Therefore they needed a powerful processor, that didn't consume too much energy. They found the ARM processor and wanted to develop it into the machine they needed. So they founded ARM together with VLSI and Acorn and created the ARM6 processor, which then was used in the Apple Newton Message Pad, that flopped badly. Later Apple nearly went bankrupt and Steve Jobs could save the company by selling their ARM shares. I think, it's only natural for Apple now going with ARM, as it's basically their very own design.

I am not convinced that there is a fundamental inefficiency in Intel or AMD processors, aside from whether a processor core is designed for high-end performance or power efficiency. The main issue is that Intel and AMD cores carry a heavy burden for the SIMD capabilities. My question is: what needs the AVX/SIMD instructions that cannot run on GPU? if nothing important, then CPU cores need to revert to core logic, and SIMD needs to move the GPU units. Processor/socket level products should then have the correct blend of APU/GPU capability to each market segment

TSMC's 5nm process is the key to Apple's M1. TSMC is 2 generations (nodes) ahead of Intel.  The time is long past for Intel to continue to insist on producing their own state of the art processors. Intel's production can not keep up with their own designs.  In my opinion, Intel should scrap their 7nm fabs and have TSMC produce their state of the art products. TSMC is producing Apple's latest chips on their 5nm process. The latest Qualcomm Snapdragon 875 is built on TSMC's 5nm process.  Intel was more than 2 years late getting the yield up in their 10nm fabs. Intel is now at least one year late in getting their 7nm fab running.  Intel can claim that TSMC's size is calculated differently than Intel's. Even if we accept that Intel's 10nm is TSMC's 7nm, TSMC is still ahead of Intel. TSMC's Fab 18 has been producing 5nm commercial products since early in 2020. The next phase of Fab 18 is under construction. It is designed for 3nm. If Intel remains on their current protectory, TSMC will start producing 3nm processors  in 2021 and Intel will still be sorting out 7nm. Intel will still be 2 nodes behind TSMC. Samsung is only slightly behind TSMC.   The top 3 semiconductor manufacturing companies have not changed in the 2000s. It is still TSMC, Samsung and Intel. The problem for Intel is that the order has changed. in 2000, all three companies were neck and neck on the technology of their products. In 2020, TSMC and Samsung are the leaders and Intel is falling further behind.
its not changed nothing just bring more competition  and now they dont use intel cpu-s and intel sleeps for years doing nothing

You failed to mention how Apple took their arm based processors in a different direction than arm itself had gone for. Instead of increasing the core counts, they used fewer cores but with far more transistors per core than say Samsung. This payed off big time, made them the only player in the Tablet market and let their iPhones runnin a circle around every other arm powered phone while setting them up to scale up these powerful cores and tackle intel directly. I remember a few years ago about how everyone was laughing at iPhones with measly 2 cores while Samsung was gonna have 8. But then reality hit and these 2 cores could easily compete with two to four times as many traditional arm cortex cores.

M1 is just apples next approach to take control over the user. M1 never reaches desktop performance. The problem with ARM ist that it will never really reach CISC performance. It is physically impossible. Taking this iPhone example. Yes it has hardware accelleration for that use case. CISC is exactly that but for general usecases. Not just for video encoding. In everything else the A14 and the M1 would fail by a very very big margin. And somehow the information presented here are not matching reality.  Apple M1 in Cinebench R23 (MC) -> 7760 points Intel Core i9-9900K in Cinebench R23 (MC) -> 12450 points  And there are a lot more examples.

Ah, melodramatic reaction. This is nothing new. Servers have been using RISC processors for ages, with great benefits to efficiency and performance in specific tasks. Based on some of these RISC architectures, desktops were also sold in past, usually running proprietary Unix operating systems. Everyone who manages RISC servers knew that it was just a matter of time when someone starts using RISC in personal PCs en masse again. And almost everyone would, based on what's happening with smartphone CPUs, guess that it will be ARM. I am actually very surprised that Apple did not do this 10 years ago, what have they been waiting for? It is certain that nVidia and AMD have internal groups researching RISC for years, and have been acquiring related business.
R.I.P. Apple.

You state that x86 has "multiple cycles per instruction" but that is provably untrue. AMDs latest x86 chips have 8-10 instructions per cycle and Apples (older, no stats for newer) A75 reached 10.7-12.4 instructions per cycle. The instruction size of a typical ARM binary is 4.0 and for x86 it varies between 3.1-3.4 on average. Also, ARM chips operating at higher clock speeds have drastically worse power efficiency than x86 chips (there's graphs showing performance per watt locked at 2GHZ comparing A9 and i7).   The primary reason x86 uses more power for low performance at the low end is because of microarchitecture, micro-ops translation, large L2 cache, an aggressive prefetcher and large branch prediction. At the high end, these features provide higher performance-per-watt than ARM could provide in the general use case. Any improvements the new Mac show from their RISC processor is due to very clever compilation; it could be the case that RISC has more intelligent compilation optimizations but I'm not familiar with this, CISC does suffer quite significantly from compilers not using the best solution (you can watch many youtube videos about algorithm speedup using CPU features that are not used by default).   There is no particular reason CISC should use more power than RISC in any case, the difference that is observed is primarily due to additional features that are present in CISC-based CPUs that are unrelated to the instruction set.  For a comprehensive analysis: https://research.cs.wisc.edu/vertical/papers/2013/hpca13-isa-power-struggles.pdf

The fact that apple have always insisted on maintaining an (arguably) obsessive level of control over both the hardware and software components of every device that wears the apple brand has, historically, led to a situation where apple computers, while (arguably) providing a simpler, cleaner and more elegant user experience, have never been able to match the diversity and scope of software available for 'PC's' and the Windows operating system. For decades, apple's largely hollow response was that software emulation would allow the mac to run Windows software as well, and offer the best of both worlds. For decades this has been a largely fanciful claim suitable for marketing to novices while justifiably scoffed at by serious PC proponents. With the introduction of a chipset so many orders of magnitude beyond it's PC competition, it looks like that claim is no longer just hyperbolic hype...  Let the disruption begin.

Not mentioned in the video. Intel actually owned a stake in arm and for years working on an intel version of the Arm chip called xscale. Apple wanted the xscale cpu in the iphone at a specific price. Intel refused because they did not feel they would make up a profit on large volume at the negotiated price. The irony is that intel had the chip ready to go.  Mistake #2 right after rejecting this offer, they chose to add insult to injury by selling the Stake in Arm and the xscale design to MRVL for a measly 600m because the CEO wanted to beat wallstreet numbers for his bonus.

I enjoy your videos, but this time you got it wrong about why this system is so much faster -  it‚Äôs because of better operating system software design that is more closely integrated with an improved hardware design focusing on removing bottlenecks between the VRAM, the storage memory, and CPU caches, and the system memory ie  much better memory management, with a removal of bottlenecks. Risc is only part of the story......the smaller die size and risc design are primarily associated with the low power requirements, not so much the performance improvements.

17:30 exactly, has HW acceleration, which means dedicated chip area for that particular task and dedicated instructions for that particular task. It's smoke and mirrors, and goes _against_ the ARM philosophy. Those instructions are _only_ being used for that particular task, and optimized only for that task. The desktop version seems to be not using any HW acceleration *despite* the AMD GPU being more than capable to do that.  That "benchmark" is in essence bullshit.  Apple did not invent magic here, they just added HW accelerators for certain things.

Good report. but a nit pick: Digital Equipment Corp was the leader in ARM chips in early 1990s with its Strong Arm.  (devices such as Newton and other PDAs made use of it).  As Digital failed it donated the StrongARM IP and teams to Intel.  As Digital failed, HP/Compaq donated the Alpha Engineers to Intel. Digital rngineers from both Alpha and StrongARM  projects formed PA Semi which Aple then bought. The Alpha was the first "mainframe" 64 bit RISC available 1992.  The last Alpha (EV7) in early 2000s included memory technology/controler that would inspire AMD, and which was  donated to Intel which used parts to make its Quickpath/CSI contrtollers first seen in Nehalem x86s. So the folks at PA Semi (now Apple) have a lot of experience/knowledge with high performance.  Yet, Digital never gets mention for having originated much of this.

Hi!!! Love the video but there‚Äôs an error: the first Apple designed ARM chip was the A4 in the first generation iPad. The next year, the A4 moved to the iPhone 4. The A5 in iPad 2 was then used in the iPhone 4S before the third generation iPad used the A5X chip the same year the iPhone 5 received the A6.

Its worth noting that Apple wasnt solely responsible for evaporating Intel's lead. AMD  has been competing heavily in Intel's own specific areas for years.
RISC: Will encourage more software developers to develop more code.   -- More software focus -- Uses only Hardwired control unit -- Transistors are used for more registers -- Fixed sized instructions -- Can perform only Register to Register Arithmetic operations -- Requires more number of registers -- Code size is large -- A instruction execute in single clock cycle -- A instruction fit in one word  CISC: Will encourage the push of the Hardware and optimizing of the hardware performance.  -- More hardware focus -- Uses both hardwired and micro programmed control unit --Transistors are used for storing complex Instructions -- Variable sized instructions -- Can perform REG to REG or REG to MEM or MEM to MEM -- Requires less number of registers -- Code size is small -- Instruction take more than one clock cycle -- Instruction are larger than size of one word

This video seems well researched but the lack of technical knowledge really shows when it tries to show examples or get down to specifics: the iphone exports video faster than the mac because it's using dedicated hardware encoding and not because the CPU chip is faster, and the RISC and CISC ISAs have borrowed so much from each other over the years that the modern day versions of these architectures are more similar than they are different. As somebody who literally broke barriers live streaming 4K60 from Coachella, for Samsung and YouTube, I can say that video export demonstration is meaningless as presented here. He confirmed the hi-spec settings on the phone which naturally uses hardware encoding as part of its design (it is a device designed to take 4k, hdr video through a camera), but he did not confirm GPU accelerated encoding on the desktop export. With reasonably quick storage and any GPU acceleration, I would expect the desktop export to move substantially faster just like on the phone. His comment about the CPU fans and CPU load also indicates it was not GPU encoding. Any video workstation that would be exporting HEVC in this day will be GPU accelerated. Even without an Nvidia GPU and nvnc Intel still has QS and can do HEVC since SkyLake (8k since after Apollo Lake.)  I'm not trying to take anything from the chip overall, just saying that was a piss-poor way to try and prove it's dominance.

In the '90s, lots of UK schools used Acorn A3000s and some bigger machines. They ran programmes that were superior to anything that PCs had to offer. Specifically 'Artisan' was a click and draw suite that is, to this day, still smoother and more responsive than 'Paint' on PC. I really hope that some of this Apple magic gives the RISC developers from back then some kudos. They really knew their business, but were overshadowed by IBM/Intel marketing and industry adoption. If Acorn had really competed properly back then, I don't think anybody would have bothered with IBM compats. While Acorn had a friendly and very snappy feeling interface, most IBM machines still needed users to type 'PARK' before powering off their DOS machines. (to park the HDD heads lol). The M1 SOC may be interesting but a big part of the performance comes from x86 to ARM instructions translation used by Rosetta 2.0, which is completely different from Microsoft's x86/64 Emulation on their SQ1 SOC.  I'm super interested in this tech because Microsoft actually did something like this with Project Astoria which translate Android/ARM to WoA. But it was abruptly discontinued probably due to Google's interference.  Apple has gone 1 step further and that to me explains the negligible performance gap when running translated x86 programs on ARM RISC.  What really convinced me that M1 performance is legit is not video editing. You can build ASIC that do this into the SOC and that's why mobile phone can transcode video well. What sold it for me is the file compression & decompression tests ran by some benchmarks.  That said, Intel has been really slacking for a decade now, so it's their own fault. My next PC will be an AMD. My first AMD built ever.

This is such a stupid question to even pose. Fact is, Apple's entire ecosystem, very much including it's "computers", basically is a mobile environment. Always has been... a true fact, I can do more with my smartphone (N20U) than an Apple computer. Apple's OSX is a locked down crapshoot of which doesn't even BEGIN to compare with the x86/64 architecture of a Windows environment. It has no expandability, no software library / catalog comparatively... I mean, we are literally talking some 800,000,000:1 on that one. It has zero open doors to programmers or modders, one cannot develop on top of or even laterally. It's basically a cheap phone / tablet environment, and it has been since the Mac Plus 1MB. It's why the folks who love it even do love it, because its "simple". . . Not necessarily to use, as anyone used to using computers will find it limiting and frustrating. With options missing, abilities gone, and devoid of much purpose at all. But for the most basic of home use, it can work... like a WebTV, or really really cheap tools. You won't find pro's, or even enthusiasts using them, but there's still a very basic market there, and those basic folks are rather large in number, and can buy up quite a bit. But ultimately, the reason an ARM chip works so well for Apple, is that they are the exact realm it was meant for. They never needed x86/64 power, nor had they EVER used it. They handicapped every intel chip that ever hit a board of theirs, making a compelling argument of "why pay apple prices for hardware that's literally 20-40x faster in a Windows environment"? And now you don't have to... they realized that their basic calculator environment merely needed an epoxy blob to run it, and that's what they used!  Their loyal derps will still pay top dollar for inclusion to the club more or less, but at least Apple saves on the back end now! FAR more profit baby!!!  This will have a literal ZERO impact on the market as a whole though, as it really has nothing to do with it. Everyone knows what ARM and RISC can do, and everyone knows that in actual real computing, with actual real hardware, that has to do more than an extremely small batch of things, well... they know that it cannot ever have a reasonable place in that world. Apple gets by because their use case is literally none... you get a macbook to do what? Check FB, Twitter, IG? Do some web surfing, etc... Yeah, you can do that with a USB compute stick, also either ARM or a cheap Celeron that makes no heat, doesn't need cooled, etc. If all you need to do is cater to your tiny, insubstantial software library, housed in your own "app store", providing basic things that are the equivalent to old flash games if gaming, basic word processing, spreadsheets, office this and that.... Maybe some photo editing... yeah, a tablet or phone does that. And once more to reiterate, that's all an apple anything is, despite the form factor. This should just make that all the more evident.  If you want a brutally honest eval of what this M1 is, then go look at ETAPrime's emulation coverage of it... It is ranked "pretty good", same as most $40 Chinese handhelds these days, and does just about as much. Maxing out at Dreamcast, with limited success there. PS1 being it's highest and strongest level. So it falls in with other basic ARM chips when it comes to non Apple written, very very very very basic, software. It's a phone...

OK, let's break this down:  Claims:  Up to 3.5X faster CPU performance  Up to 3.9X faster video processing  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction MacBook Air systems with Apple M1 chip and 8-core GPU, as well as production 1.2GHz quad-core Intel Core i7-based MacBook Air systems...  Conclusion:  M1 has faster CPU performance and "video processing" performance than Intel's craptastic ULV Ice Lake processors.  Claim:  Up to 7.1X faster image processing  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction Mac mini systems with Apple M1 chip, and production 3.6GHz quad-core Intel Core i3-based Mac mini systems  Conclusion:  M1 has faster iGPU than the lowest-spec'd Mac Mini running the Intel Coffee Lake quad-core i3-8100 CPU with Intel UHD graphics  Claim:  Our high‚Äëperformance core is the world‚Äôs fastest CPU core when it comes to low‚Äëpower silicon  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction 13‚Äëinch MacBook Pro systems with Apple M1 chip and 16GB of RAM measuring peak single-thread performance of workloads taken from select industry-standard benchmarks, commercial applications, and open source applications. Comparison made against the highest-performing CPUs for notebooks commercially available at the time of testing. Performance tests are conducted using specific computer systems and reflect the approximate performance of MacBook Pro.  Conclusion:  One of the 4 big cores in the M1 was able to perform better in single-thread mode at peak (not necessarily sustained) than other notebook CPUs, although some of these, most notably 8-core models, would probably crush the M1 in multi-thread performance.  Claims:  Up to 2X faster CPU performance  Matches peak PC performance using 25% of the power  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction 13‚Äëinch MacBook Pro systems with Apple M1 chip and 16GB of RAM. Multithreaded performance measured using select industry‚Äëstandard benchmarks. Comparison made against latest‚Äëgeneration high‚Äëperformance notebooks commercially available at the time of testing. Performance tests are conducted using specific computer systems and reflect the approximate performance of MacBook Pro.  Conclusion:  The M1 is faster and more efficient that other notebook CPUs at cherry-picked benchmarks, but not necessarily in "commercial applications, and open source applications" like in the single-thread comparison. Hmm. Why not?  Claim:  3X CPU performance per watt  Footnote:  Testing conducted by Apple in October 2020 using preproduction 13‚Äëinch MacBook Pro systems with Apple M1 chip and 16GB of RAM, as well as previous‚Äëgeneration Mac notebooks. Performance measured using select industry‚Äëstandard benchmarks. Performance tests are conducted using specific computer systems and reflect the approximate performance of MacBook Pro.  Conclusion:  The M1 has better performance per watt than previous Mac notebooks. In this metric, I would hope an ARM based processor would have better numbers than Intel's old heaters. The question is how far back is this "previous-generation" Macs? Why is this metric not compared against "latest‚Äëgeneration high‚Äëperformance notebooks commercially available at the time of testing"?  There are bunch more footnotes that I don't care to look at, but you can see how Apple is comparing the M1 using different metrics against different types of devices.

Re. CISC vs. RISC It's not so simple anymore, CISC vs. RISC used to be a thing, but it hasn't been a thing for a long long time now.  Starting with the original Pentium (1993, P5 micro-architecture [uarc from here on]) Intel started to decouple the internal architecture (uarc) from the ISA (Instruction Set Architecture), i.e. the Pentium had a stage in it that decoded the x87 instructions (operations) into the micro-operations (uops from here on) used internally.  In the Pentium the decode stage is estimated to be around 30% of the transistors on the chip, so while it was pretty expensive, it was worth it performance wise. But by the time of the Pentium Pro (1995, P6 uarc), the decode stage is estimated to be around 10% of the transistor budget, and it further decouple the ISA from the uarc, in essence the Pentium Pro was essentially a RISC chip pretending to be a CISC chip, as it decoded the x86 CISC instructions into its internal RISC-like uops. As the Pentium Pro became the Pentium III (1999) the decode stage became a smaller and smaller portion of the transistor budget, essentially it became cheaper and cheaper for a RISC chip to pretend to be a CISC chip.  So at the time of Apple's transition from 68k to Power PC (PPC) chips (starting 1994), Apple were moving from CISC chips to RISC chips, while Intel were making their CISC chips more RISC like internally. But by the time of the G5 (2002, PPC 970) IBM themselves started to decode the PPC ISA operations into uops internally. This was an acknowledgement that there're benefits to both the CISC and RISC philosophies, that a pure RISC design required much better code and compilers to fully utilise, that adding additional instructions to the PPC ISA and decoding them into uops yields benefits over a purely RISC design.  So now that all modern processors are a hybrid RISC/CISC design (i.e. they use a decode stage to convert a variety of instructions into internal uops; yes ARM designs do the same thing, about the only one that doesn't these days is MIPS), what's the difference between x64 processors and Apple's ARM designs? The biggest difference is how wide the processors can be.  Processors tend to be either long and narrow (as in the Pentium 4 with the Netburst uarc), or shallow and wide (or both if you can afford it to be). What that means is that processors tend to have either have a long chain of stages where work is passed along one after another (akin to a train that travels at 500km/h), or it can have multiple paths through which work can travel through (so maybe like a 5 lane highway where cars travel at 100km/h). Why one or the other and not both? Because energy is not free, you have to decide between the two as it's too expensive to do both.  In terms of work done, you can see where a train that travels at 500km/h can get 10 passengers from A to B in N time, while on the highway that will take 5N time to do the same work. Say there's a relay race happening between A and B, what happens if a baton is left at A? The train would need to go all the way back to A, meaning that all the baton carriers would need to go back to A, while on the highway only one lane's worth of baton carriers would need to go back to A.  Because modern x64 processors have to retain backwards compatibility with the initial x64 ISA design (where AMD did their best to widen the design from the x86 ISA Intel initially designed), it's constantly hitting a limit with regards to how wide it can be. Intel and AMD can widen the uarc designs a bit more every time they push the frequency up, but the ISA itself limits how wide it can fully be. Apple's ARM designs don't have that limitation, Apple's previous generation A13 and the current generation A14/M1 processors have an 8-wide decode block, while Intel and AMD are at 4-wide (Samsung's M3 is 6-wide, and ARM's X1 will be 5-wide).  So in summary, the reason that Apple's ARM processors are faster than Intel's processors isn't because of CISC vs. RISC, but because they can make a wider processor than Intel. That's s why the 3.2GHz M1 is faster than Intel's 5GHz processors, and just slightly slower than AMD's 5GHz processors.

Many people believe the PowerPC to have been inferior to the Intel x86 and that is why Apple switched.  The switch was because Apple's primary supplier of PowerPC chips was Motorola and Motorola was failing to deliver on low power versions of the PowerPC just as the Mac laptops were becoming a major part of Apple's revenue.  Motorola was floundering in other ways and eventually completely spun off it's semiconductor business to focus on mobile phones leaving  Apple with IBM as the only source of PowerPCs and IBM was focused entirely on making big mainframe super computers using the PowerPC as their backbone and having no desire to get into a commodity processor market.  Apple simply had no source for low power devices and IBM's PowerPC devices were power hogs even for desktops . Though Apple was part of the consortium which developed the PowerPC, they were not a semiconductor manufacturer and thus could not make their own devices.  This left Apple between a rock and a hard place.  The Intel x86 was inferior to almost every CPU architecture that had been developed in over a decade, but because of the success of IBM compatible PCs, Intel had the financial resources to plow into basic semiconductor technology which allowed their processors to run faster than anyone else's such that even though Intel X86 processors took more cycles to do the same functions as these other newer architectures, they were, through brute force ,able to run their processor at higher clock speeds than other companies and thus appear to be better than their architecture alone would allow. Apple also knew that even if they found a better processor and somehow convinced the manufacturer to produce devices at a price point, power level and production numbers to meet their needs, it would be very difficult for Apple to convince software developers to support them especially given that they had just struggle to keep developers on board in the switch from the 68000 series CPUs to the PowerPC.  Apple changing to Intel was never because Intel was the best processor architecture, it was because it  provided Apple it's only chance to survive.  Apple at the time simply did not have the market clout to move the industry to a new processor technology.  There are many reasons why Apple can make a move away from Intel today that was not possible when they first made the switch to Intel.  Today few developers are concerned with the underlying CPU architecture.  Modern OS's, Compilers, and development tools make supporting different CPUs far easier than in the past with almost no performance hit.  The fact that Apple can license ARM, do their own processor development and do this without having to have their own semiconductor fab is something that should make Intel do some soul searching on keeping the bloated x86 architecture as their flagship.  Backwards compatibility is no longer the issue it was in the past. If Apple succeeds with the M1, there is no reason other PC makers may follow in Apple's path. Performance in both execution and power consumption now drives hardware choices.  ARM is not the fastest RISC architecture, but is designed very elegantly and is easy to implement in whatever technology you happen to have access to.  It is also easy to license and has large independent support for both software and hardware.

MISC goes one step further .. Everyone knows who Charles Moore is .. Many do not know of his efforts with MISC and the implementation of Forth .. Forth was a language that at its core made use of ~23 MISC commands .. The first "Interpretive Processor was a MISC / Forth Engine" .. The code would run one or two passes to create "Machine Language Commands" .. 4 to 6 MISC Instructions could run PER CLOCK CYCLE .. This processor is still the fastest processing unit in existence because of MISC .. I 2004 a Govt Project created the 1024 core Swarm Processor .. To date no other processor could run the speed of this processor using very compact code of 30k-100k .. The power of processing was 2.5 orders of magnitude faster than the fastest X86 and while RISC still limps along MISC still runs circles around them both ..

Alright, let's not brush off hardware acceleration so easily. As you probably already know since you're working with video a lot, there's a ton of details there: - codec could be on silicon on the iPhone, while on PC it's just on software. Try some non-hardware-implemented codecs in the iPhone and you'll see it struggle (if you even have the choice to do so). - PCs DO implement some codecs in hardware (they have been doing it for a long time), just not all of them. There is research on implementing codecs in GPUs, but a raw silicon implementation is always faster. - Quality settings can have a big impact on encoding speed. Smartphone apps will tipically hide this from you and pick a fast setting that does not yield high quality results. In desktop software you get all the knobs to fine tune and default quality is very different to fast quality.

There is a lot of information flying around youtube and the internet regarding RISC vs CISC architecture and design benefits which is just wrong. I realize the audience here is not technical, but even the simplified version delivered in this video is just not correct. Unfortunately, the author of this video has managed to have picked up on this false information and propagated the error. There used to be a time when technical content was researched from near original sources and then vetted by peers and then passed on to the masses. I find so much value in youtube and the community and the ability to share information easily. In this case, the topic requires a content provider to be somewhat knowledgeable of chip design or at least to take the time to do his research. This is not just a rant against this video but content generators as a whole just trying to cash in on the latest thing while providing the least amount of effort.

This video and most comments greatly oversimplify where the performance comes from.  The RISC/CISC battle from the 90s.  Back then, the X86 did most of the important instructions in 1 to 3 clock cycles -RISC often took 5-20 cycles to do the same operation, but it was easy to make RISC chips run at nearly twice the clock speed.  The deciding factors for why X86 won the desktop were the ease of programming the CISC instructions and the cost of the larger amount of higher speed memory to get the equivalent performance out of RISC.  It helped that Intel chip manufacturing was best in the world and Microsoft dwarfed all other software providers (neither were shy about monopolistic behavior). Smartphones put a premium on performance/power and fueled development with hundreds of billions a year in revenue.  ARM has certainly been improving but the improvement in software and programming tools is a completely new game   To get an appreciation, take a look at Windows on ARM -if you only looked at Windows on ARM you would conclude that Intel only needs to worry about AMD, not ARM, and for the most part, the performance challenge was due to AMD using better manufacturing from TSMC. The M1 success is beyond ARM.  It includes a unified memory system and has the software to exploit it.  It is no surprise that Apple made the jump to their own chip.  It is astonishing that they made the jump with as much performance and as much backward compatibility as they did.  This reveals Apple to be a far greater software power than anyone imagined.
I bet Apple is already looking beyond ARM.
Next thing you know, Nvidia comes out with a similar design for a GPU and then sky-rocket the GPU performance and efficiency.

The key I think is ultimately the manufacturing process improvement. RISC was superior architecture, but there was not a sufficiently big enough market to sustain the continuous process improvement necessary to compete with the WinTel juggernaut that has the annual PC sales to pay for R&D.  But the smartphone market changed that economics completely.  Intel was so dumb to miss the cue on the iPhone, that it doesn‚Äôt realize it will eventually threaten its PC and server business, too.
Yes the architecture trend is moving & ARM is the current trend.  In  the desktop use case at M1, the key action here is the approach of Rosseta 2. When Microsoft give ARM a shot, they build it on emulation approach, while Apple use translation approach with Rosseta 2.  This kind a mindset is a clear historical path of "thinking structure" difference between Microsoft & Apple.  Seems like Microsoft still try  to keep CISC mindset while try to understand RISC as the main driver for their business logic going forward.    What I see here, major business logic for desktop has been established based on CISC logic, move to RISC wil change all the business logic & revenue structure for company like Microsoft.  Company with CISC logic like Microsoft, Intel generate their revenue thru the complexity of the architecture that create dependency, licensing, etc. While the RISC logic is on the opposite side because they can not generate complexity that can be converted to money, that's why Apple is relly on the ecosystem control to make money.   As now Apple has pull the trigger so I think we now moving to the era of RISC, Mobile & Eco Friendly approach tech. All simple & maybe formed at Single on Chip

Eh, I wouldn't say Apple has changed the entire industry. They just did something that the PC market hasn't been able to accomplish. It's not that Apple Silicon is revolutionary. They are technically not any more or less powerful than comparable products from Intel or AMD. What they have been able to do is master the interoperability of their systems as a whole. It's something they have been doing for years with iPhone. It's why on paper the iPhone tends to be less impressive in terms of hardware than Android flagship phones but in real-world tests tend to come out equal or on top. When you control every piece of a computer's (or smart phone's) hardware down to the single transistor level, you can greatly improve it's efficiency and interoperability. The rest of the PC market runs on universal standards that do not allow for system wide efficiency on the level of what Apple has been able to achieve with Apple Silicon. Those standards aren't going to change because Apple started building processors for laptops and desktops. Apple might get a boost in market share, and maybe a fairly decent one if developers are able to fully take advantage of Apple's architecture. Time will tell if that comes to fruition but most signs point to developers having no major issues working with Apple Silicon. As for the rest of the industry, nothing will change. Not for better or for worse.

When the original ARM2 came out in 1983, it was ridiculously fast compared to x86. 8Mhz ARM2 was about 4-5 MIPS, about the same as 16Mhz 386 which didn't come out until 1985. So the ARM architecture probably always had that performance potential, but for obvious reasons, it was used manly in application where low-power was paramount. This has nothing to do with ARM and everything to do with connecting RAM straight to the chip. Increase RAM bus speed, reduce access cycle latency. The closer the faster. This is much the same design philosophy as AMD is using with their Threadripper chips.

Apple were the first company to use RISC PowerPC processors back in the day, so this is nothing new.
MIPS, SPARK, and PowerPC are going, are we a joke to you? The thing ARM did that no one else did at the time was to license core designs, and the instruction set itself, so 3rd party manufacturers could make their own chips with more or less cache, with faster or slower clocks, and even their own compatible cores from scratch to fit their purpose, which is what made ARM a winner. The Android mobile OS follow pretty much the same model, and that's why there's around 1 bajillion models of Android phones out there.

Everything Apple has done really starts to make sense with these M1 chips. People complained (me among them) when Apple began moving RAM to be soldered on to the motherboards and not user upgradeable. But now we see that upgrading RAM is going to be a thing of the past. Even these 8gb models are running circles around x86 computers with 128gb. A lot of that is the way Apple's M1 does unified memory. So really the only thing you'd want to upgrade now is your storage. And yes, that has to be done at the time of purchase. But we're about to enter a world where the things we think are "normal" about computers is going to become very not normal. Everyone keeps saying this is a once in a 10 year change, and I couldn't disagree more. This is a once in a 40 year change. This is THE biggest thing to happen to computers since Windows 95.

good presentation, but it surely is not so simple as CISC/RISC, the power management features for mobile low-power battery operation and the open-source Linux compiler support, and 5 nanometer scale are probably more important.  The 5 nanometer scale and 16 billion transistors are truly revolutionary, on-chip speeds are always 10x-100x faster than off-chip. Is the A1 the first 5 nanometer high volume CPU? Many other large players in the CPU space, Nvidia, Texas Instruments and Qualcomm and AMD. Well, this video missed out the real reason why these M1 Macs are so fast!. It is NOT just the M1 chip itself, but the OS (Big Sur on Arm binaries optimized for the caches and UMA), its native compilers and mostly Rosetta2 emulator implementation to exploit the big caches. So it is hardware + OS + software!. Something Apples does better than any other companies out there. Tech reasons here: 1) Hardware - The M1 chip design. It has huge caches onboard. It uses DDR4X Ram on the CCN. This with L3 cache front ends speeds up memory access several times a traditional design. ie Ram controller off DMI link (without caching). UMA on the GPU side is brilliant. With such high-speed RAM, you dont need GDDR6. And do not suffer the copy-penalty since the video buffer is common on the Numa memory!. 2) The OS and Rosetta2 emulator. There are clever tricks to optimise the software design the take advantage of the caching capabilities of the M1 chip. In video, since UMA solves the PCie copy penalty, you save lots of critical delays and overall reduces the CCN latencies.   Only Zen3 from AMD can almost match the M1 in multi core. So if Zen3 gets the same tricks (16MB shared L3 cache), UMA and DDR4X Ram on Infinity Fabric, it will exceed M1 by 30% to 50%. You are going to see AMD and Apple leapfrogging each other in the coming years.   But do not count out Nvidia, now that they have acquired ARM. They could well, follow the same formula and match and/or exceed BOTH the above companies using a "SuperARM" type design. The future is very bright with such competition going on.

They will just do what they did with iPhone. Apple will take control and then limit other companies ability to replicate the architecture, forcing consumers into buying it, then gradually increase the prices and, because today's consumer think "faster is better", and have limited themselves by investing heavily in apps, will keep paying that price. The simplest way to stop companies doing this is to stop buying their products and keep using the older version(s). iPhone 24 for $2,300? No thanks. Got an iPhone 16 here that runs everything I need.  There is also the common misconception that a new version of any software application makes the older versions obsolete. I work in the CG industry and get sick of hearing about "dead" applications.  Autodesk SoftImage was one of them.  They stopped development on it in 2016 and everyone acted as though the software simply stopped working and went off and invested in Max 2017+ Meanwhile, some (clever) people realised that SoftImage was good at the time, and on newer machines it just got faster ... Max kept increasing the size of its application, with little no no actual benefit to the users that formed the majority of their client-base, and performance _decreased_ even though their PC's got faster. If they has simply stayed with SoftImage (or even Max 2012!!!) they would have seen huge performance increases, no increase in storage requirements, greater "support" in the form of user-created plugins (most have to be re-written for each new version of an app) and in-house scripting, etc. A "house" that uses older applications will, 99% of the time, be able to work faster and more smoothly than any using "up to date" applications, and without the almost constant "upgrade" costs..  As an example, I am able to do my work, without problems, using the following applications: SoftImage 2012, Max 2010 (sometimes even Max 2008), Photoshop CS6, etc  No doubt there will be comments such as "You should use Blender, it's free" from people who didn't stop to think that what they are actually saying is "Hey, why not stop using that system that you are completely familiar with and spend the time and effort to learn a new piece of software that literally cost the same amount of money that you are currently spending [zero], and all the while not being able to produce output at anywhere near your current rate, with almost no supporting custom tools, and perhaps only the ability to recreate 80% of what your current system can achieve, and do it all because I think Blender is cool and someone will give me a "like" in YouTube, making my day complete. Also, if you disagree with me then you're a loser." Well, sorry, but if I actually cared what other people think, I would be out there in line to buy some branded trainers, wireless earphones and a hat with the label still stuck to it.

I think, from a marketing perspective, Apple have been really clever to introduce their first Apple silicon Macs with basically no other changes than the new chipset. The design is the same, the RAM is the same, the displays are the same, the battery size likewise. Even the 720p webcam is unchanged. A decision made, I think, so that all the eggs would be in the chip basket. It sort of drives home the message of how disruptive the M1 is without having to compete with other improvements/changes made to the products. From a consumer perspective it is not the awesome thing to do, but as a marketing move it's brilliant.

I gotta be that nitpicker that points out there's nothing actually wrong with modern x86 CPUs, because modern x86 CPUs *ARE* RISC processors with the ability to decode legacy x86 instructions on the fly to run them in their RISC cores. When they're not being used, those old instructions aren't causing performance or efficiency losses. If Intel had agreed to go it with Apple, or licensed out their ISA the way ARM does, we'd have x86 mobile devices and custom x86 Apple SOCs full of the same custom accelerators. This is what's done with the chips in the Xbox and Playstation SOCs and why they can squeeze a lot out of them, but from the only x86 licensee. But it doesn't really matter at this point. If RISC-V was around at the time Apple might have gone with them. Thanks to Intel's arrogance, custom SOCs on their technology are almost forbidden and they haven't added anything meaningful on chip since Quicksync, and that probably gave Apple the inspiration to build SoCs. Apple was the only one using Quicksync until recently. Intel ran their business so badly that they deserve the reputation that their ISA can't be saved.

This is not the first time ARM has been used in PCs.  Don‚Äôt forget, ARM was originally designed at Acorn for their new line of Archimedes computers in the late 1980s.  Even then, the performance of ARM was amazing.  Unfortunately at that time the marketing clout was with huge companies like Motorola, IBM, Microsoft etc.  Well huge compared to Acorn.  Imagine where we would be if Acorn/ARM had gone mainstream then?  Apple also has the huge advantage of controlling the whole ecosystem which affords extensive optimisation.  Even if you put Windows on ARM, the disjointed market (great for prices) would mean they would struggle to match Apple Macs.

Great video, personally just went from an Intel i7 (7 years old now) to an AMD 5950 (The latest AMD chip) in my new computer, looks like my next "PC" will be running an M7
It's not as simple as ARM better because simple. ARM have modules that have special uses, like compression/decompression, encoding and so on. If you want application to run fast, you need to either code down to the metal or use these modules. X86 is just raw power, with very little space for specialized accelerators. Creating fast working software on ARM that is complex requires a lot more work to execute, requiring a lot of resources. In modern world most programmers go for ready solutions, frankensteining elements that never intended to do these tasks. Apple doesn't help with their limitations, walled garden and repair hostility that is one step short of suing them for opening magic boxes. You might be happy, if you follow narrow path of Apple software and never wander off, just like ARM - limited instruction set - limited software. Good example are browser and sites, there is so much computing and data transfer due to bad coding, lots of legacy and legacy on top of legacy, you can make it from scratch to look the same, but any major change will require you to work from scratch again and again, instead of reorganizing thing on css. PS that phone vs PC export thing, details that count, if transcoding of closed garden apple video format, to most common YouTube export got predicted, there is module for it, quality will be lower, but power is greatly reduced. Try to do it once YT eventually changes format or Apple stop updating the thing, you are on ice.

It's great to see high-end processor performance improving again, after years of painfully slow growth.  Also remember that RISC-V is on the same path, now showing up in many embedded systems and announcing increasingly powerful cores.  In five to ten years we might see RISC-V processors in server rooms, and perhaps even on desktops.
Microsoft could have had this way earlier, but the bad x86 emulation ruined it again. As far as I know Rosetta 2 isnt emulation but a binary translator. The benefit about this approach is that you dont need to emulate all avaiable instructions of e.g. x86 to run an application, it will just translate the binary code that is actually used which makes it faster. You even could cache some of these translations and speed it up more.  I dont have a clue why microsoft went with a x86 emulation, every body knows emulating x86 on ARM doenst work so goood because of the core different these architectures work.  Simple example not specific to any ARM or x86 CPU but a easy one to understand: If you want to calculate 6*3, one CPU can do just this in one instructions and the other calculates 6+6+6 in multiple instructions. Each run per Clock Cycle.  But if you want to emulate the 6+6+6 approach on the chip that actually does 6*3 you need 3 instrcution calls to get the emulated result. This is bad! So you can say for the same result the emulated CPU needs 3 times longer than the native one.  A binary translater will look this up and sees "Oh hey this is a 6+6+6 calculation what is my matching instruction for this, oh yeah its 6*3". Boom immediately faster, you will only have a overhead because e.g. Rosetta is running all the time and steals performance.
Hope every arm chip wont be locked like phones where it can only run one OS

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reduced_instruction_set_computer#History_and_development https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berkeley_RISC No, it wasn't ARM that first conceived the RISC. It was UC Berkeley's team who set the standard for modern-day RISC architectures. SPARC, MIPS and ARM and even PowerPC descended from Berkeley's RISC. Efforts were made to utilize small instruction sets and different approaches of the number of registers available to the programmer, but Berkeley merged and defined the 1st solid concept on RISC.

While this video is a great insight, I think you're overplaying the role of ARM architecture itself in all this a bit. And here are some reasons why: - The RISC vs. CISC debate got mostly academic in the 2000s, as x86 chips got massively redesigned to break down complex instructions into simpler internal ones before execution, while ARM chips started getting more and more "bloat" for various reasons because the original RISC idea was not as compelling anymore. - Apple just dominates the high performance mobile CPU market. If you look at Geekbench scores, the fastest Android phones on the market, powered by Snapdragon 865, get just a bit over half the single-core performance and around 3/4 multi-core performance (with 50% more cores inside) of the latest iPhones. All that while requiring 50% bigger battery than said iPhone to offer similar battery life (although admittedly software comes into play with that, too). It's not that ARM is that much greater than x86 - Apple is that much greater than other chip designers. - I'm pretty sure you could in theory make an x86 chip with similar performance. Intel once tried with their Atom line of CPUs. Yes, there were x86-based smartphones. Yes, they weren't really competitive, but they were competent enough to be perfectly usable. Perhaps if Apple's R&D people started from something like that, they would end up with an x86 variant of the M1 by now. But the ARM ISA is much easier to license than (modern) x86, which Intel and AMD intentionally mostly keep to themselves as a duopoly. Thus ARM is the natural choice of ISA for any newcomer to the processor scene.
For this specific task the phone may be faster. But this is a GPU Task anyway. If you have complex physics and so on, arm architectures are usually a lot slower.

Hey ‚Äî some misleading information in this one.  ARM did not invent RISC, nor was it the first to commercialize the design, though it was very early.  RISC was invented at Berkeley and Stanford, and it was that research that inspired ARM.  MIPS (spun off from Stanford) and SPARC (spun off from Berkeley) were the first implementations.  ARM still deserves a ton of credit, and they've obviously grown to be a huge market force today, which is more than you can say for MIPS or SPARC.    It's also the case that modern x86 processors are essentially RISC internally, with a translation layer in front to convert the CISC instruction set.  Though that does add complexity and take up space on the die, it's a bit of an oversimplification to say that they are power hungry because they are CISC.  It's more accurate to say that they are an aging design saddled with backward compatibility issues that have begun to catch up with them now that heat rejection is more of a limiting factor than anything else, and the CISC translation layer is a part of that.
I take back everything I said about Tim Cook not being able to innovate.

Intel is FFFUUUUCCCCKKKKKKKEEEEDDDDDDD
The power efficiency thing, or inefficiency as it were, is actually more to do with the fact that Intel have a hardware decoder built into each of their CPUs that translates their complex instructions into simple instructions (Cisc to Risc on the fly in hardware).  This takes up a lot of space and power and it is likely where most the bodies are buried on the whole "power efficiency" issue.

I think you missed a quite fun fact which is extremely relative to the topic of this video: ARM was initially an Acorn project, but then apple is interested in ARM cpu for their Newton project. Apple and Acorn then created a separate joint venture to better full-filly this purpose: ARM company. At that time, Apple and Acorn each held 43% of the company. So one can say, apple co-created ARM.

I disagree, AMD CISC is better than Apples RISC ARM.  Its not so simple, you used Intel for comparison and i guess it makes sense since Apple switched from Intel to M1. However, Apple is using TSMCs latest 5nm process node, while intel is stuck on 14nm for last 5 years.  AMD is currently at TSMCs 7nm and its 15w chips trades blows with the 5nm M1. When TSMC gives same silicon to AMD that they gave to Apple, AMD chips will most likely perform 10-15% better on same power.   But i do give Apple props, the big-little design (4 big, 4 small cores) is what is actually making the chip so "efficient" - when you're using the Mac lightly it consumes almost no energy. And this is great for battery life. But again, this is not a feature of "RISC" or ARM, it is doable on CISC as well.  Bottom line, M1 chip is impressive, not because it is using ARM, but because Intel (the main laptop market CPU company) has stagnated last 5 years. I think we will see a market segmentation - low power laptops for plebs will become more ARM based, normal-high power laptops for work/gaming will stick with CISC.
