When I was 18 year old learning instruction set and pipelining, I made a RISC pipeline and a CISC pipeline for a complex instruction set. I just found RISC pipeline was more complex but still faster with a 8 band pipeline. I actually thought I made a mistake that time... But now I realise, it was a wasted opportunity to get into ARM company for work...
I am not really a fan of such overstatements. If there is a product in that category that changed the tech landscape it is the Microsoft Surface line and it did so 8 years ago. Tablets with physical keyboard are nothing new. ARM based notebooks are in existence for an entire year now (Microsoft SQ1). Apple has that boring habit to join the party when all tech is already there. Current chip manufacturing processes made high power low energy chips possible and all current flagship chips are capable of powering notebooks and PCs. For years now we have the most powerful supercomputers designed on ARM. In my opinion Apple as trillion dollar company has a huge Research and development problem and being that influential is actually impeding technological progress. Apple is a busyness venture of the 21th century with the tech understanding of the 20th century.

You fell into the RISC marketing delusion. RISC is very much a marketing term and not a computer science name since the original designed coined by Paterson (Berkeley RISC machine) never reached market and the closest sibling is MIPS which is on life support. Let's be honest, modern ARM is not RISC as it sports complex instructions, most of which take several cycles to execute. Moreover, the modern superscalar OoO cores (Cortex-A series) make heavy use of micro-sequencing. Patterson‚Äôs definition of RISC focused on the reductions which isn't the case with modern ARM.

At their peak, things like to reverse into the opposite of what you thought you were getting. The CPU went from a complex, high-power, generalist architecture, with many suppliers.  To a more simple, low-power, specialist architecture, monopolized by a single supplier. The switch to mobile a necessary coping strategy for the breakdown of Moore's Law.

Great video but a lot of people have misconceptions about arm and x86 and that arm is just enharently more efficient, it can be but architectural designs rather than instruction sets have much more of an impact - like the fact that most consumer arm soc‚Äôs are on a ‚Äúbig little design‚Äù a design built entirely around efficiency, intel intends to use the same design to compete with arm for its mobile processors, and will also add more accelerators (as they have already had some on their chips for years now). Also intel is 2 nodes behind, this is another huge disadvantage for efficiency - arguably larger than anything else mentioned and an equally large hinderance to performance. Intel has their own fab to build Apple just uses TSMC‚Äôs fab along with AMD - TSMC currently has the smallest nodes in the industry so it‚Äôs a huge advantage. If AMD dropped down to 5nm as well it‚Äôs current processors on their current architecture would be twice as efficient - this wouldn‚Äôt be far off from Apple - and if they integrated a similar big little design I‚Äôd imagine it would be pretty competitive. But AMD is just beginning to switch it‚Äôs attention to the laptop space, so this could take time.
What an incredible video, I have learned so many things from it. Keep up the good work.
This change won't happen in Windows/Linux side anytime soon, mainly for two reasons :- 1. Unlike Apple that saves huge cost by making their own chips for their systems, Qualcomm doesn't have such large incentive to produce anything drastically superior than their smartphone chips. Samsung still needs a lot to catch up to with its chips. 2. PC OEMs won't completely get rid off their Intel and AMD laptops. They will rather provide alternative ARM laptops to consumers who want them. This, in turn, will lead to a very similar situation with the smartwatch market where Qualcomm won't make better chips because of smaller market share and the whole industry lags behind generations because of that.  In conclusion, I think we will see see the impact of this on windows side at a much slower rate than what is hyped.

Arm is certainly the future. The biggest thing holding it back from disrupting the desktop market in the past was a lack of software support and poor emulation. Arm was inevitably going to eat into the desktop space because of RISC's unique ability to be super-efficient and so it took the mobile space (Where battery life is critical), then it took the supercomputing space, and soon after, began eating the server space (Where power usage and temperature/cooling are critical).  I'm still blown away but just how powerfull my ¬£50 Raspberry Pi 4b is when overclocked, and that it is the size of my hand. Outperforming both laptops and desktops that are 6x the price.  That being said credit has to go to ARM for their style of licensing architectures rather than selling the final product, which really pushed industries towards Arm over the traditional x86_64 market of only AMD and Intel selling their finalized products.  But as many people point out in the comments, we would not have been here today if it wasn't for Intel's complacency and downright incompetence.  Even with AMD's massive innovation to X86_64 CPUs in recent years, the fact a 3950x workstation desktop can be beaten by an Arm laptop really shows that CISC as a design is inherently flawed and that RISC was always going to be the future.   And to go back to my first point, it was the lack of software support holding it back from desktops, but with Apple making this move, everything changes, we should see rapid software development for Arm desktops applications very soon. As someone with a distaste for Apple, I have to say this was a move I love.  Great content, keep it up :)

do you believe that intel is falling far behind AMD as well
My laptop suddenly started to feel old and sluggish. Intel is dead. x86 is dying. Hopefully AMD  and others will catch up in the ARMs race, because I really don't want to bite in to the Apple business.  It used to be that already the basic applications took all the power the computers had in their reserves. CPU manufacturers couldn't just jump ship and start doing ARM, because some of the software people used the most would've required emulating x86 instruction set and that would been a temporary step back in the responsiveness of the most common apps. Now during the past decade the CPUs have finally reached a point where the most common applications take only fraction of the computers resourses. That's when it would've been time to make the transition into the better ARM architecture, because emulating x86 instruction set to run legacy software wouldn't have seemed any slower for the user anymore. Apple did this transition while Intel and AMD were too busy captaining the sinking ship. And now we're all fucked. The company that's basically making fun of their idiot customers by overpricing everything now holding the scepter in CPU manufacturing.

Lots of good points in this video about RISC vs CISC, but the advantage goes beyond that.   In the days of DEC VAX CISC chips, in order to test every instruction, every data type, every addressing mode, running at 1 million instructions a second it took a solid month of testing for one pass.   This would slow down the qualification of new designs.   RISC chips could do the same testing in a day or less.   Of course clocks are faster now, but engineering turn-around means a lot.  Secondly, the generation of the proper op codes for a CISC CPU by compilers are sometimes "clumsy".  Having simpler instructions may mean that you generate more instructions, but they have less "overhead".   This was best demonstrated in the ultra-wide instruction set of the Intel Itanium, where trying to keep the pipeline filled was really hard.  Yes, a lot of the operations at the bottom of the stack are "reduced", but you still have the micro-code getting in the way in many cases, which generate more and more specialized instructions that then have to be carried along for backwards compatibility in the future.  One other thing to think about is that in many different computing loads a huge amount of the processing is done inside the kernel and the libraries that come with the system, and are therefore compiled to the native instruction set.   Only a relatively few instructions inside the actual application itself would have to be translated, and there are some translation systems that, once the instructions are translated the first time, the instructions are run "native" from then on.   Some applications are written to run in a virtual machine to be portable, and those you might not see any degradation in speed.  The use of the M1 technology will be interesting in HPC, where heat and power issues are huge.    Titan uses 8.2MW  Let's be generous and say that the MI could cut that by only 1/2 for the same computational power (memory and communications also use power).   But you really have to look at it twice, the power saved in running the chip and the power saved for the air conditioning.  HPC applications are typically not "off the shelf" and are compiled for the native architecture.  Finally,  I would not cut Intel out of the picture yet.  Despite their mistake on the Apple phone Intel is pretty smart (I am not an Intel employee and use all sorts of architectures) and I note that Intel is a partner in the RISC-V technologies.

For anyone else wondering about the nitty gritty of how M1 achieved such a leap in desktop performance, here's what I've found: consider that it's an SoC.  As in, everything is integrated. Most critically, RAM. An M1 comes with 8GB or 16GB (or 32GB?) of RAM (same silicon I think,  not even multi-chip module style?), which greatly reduces the performance cost of memory accesses, if you don't mind losing expandability. Which is enough RAM for most use cases, and a pagefile on an SSD will also mitigate this limitation, but it's something to be aware of.

I‚Äôd add a few notes to the history lesson in this video. 1.  Apple was a founding partner of ARM.  The early success of ARM was largely due to Apple using ARM in Apple‚Äôs Newton product in the early 90‚Äôs. 2.  PowerPC was always a fundamentally better design than Intel‚Äôs x86.  The failure was due to the lack of success from the PPC consortium.  Apple ended up being the only customer... during the low point of the Mac platform.  Given Apple‚Äôs low market share, neither Motorola nor IBM could justify the cost of making Mac only chips.  IBM continued developing high end POWER series chip for the HPC server market, but these chips would never be suitable for a laptop, so Apple was forced to move to Intel. 3.   ARM chips are indeed very efficient, but in general, they are not very powerful.  The best you can get generically for a Windows PC is Qualcomm‚Äôs SQ2.  That is neither a threat to Apple nor Intel.  Apple‚Äôs chips are phenomenal because Apple has the best chip design team in the industry.  Nobody else is even close.  When you combine that with an efficient ARM ISA and the best manufacturing process on the planet, you have a winning combination.
Intel's market is receding...

It's not the instructions that are simple in RISC, it's the instruction set. The set of instructions is reduced and a lot of cruft is removed. Individual instructions can often actually be more complicated than CISC instructions.

There was never any relative of a any kind of x86 in any Commodore PET mate. They used the MOS 6502. In those days there were three main competing chips: Zilog Z80, MOS 6502, and Intel 8080. The 8080 is the ancestor of the x86 and the Z80 was a copy of Intel's chip, but the 6502 was a totally unrelated beast.

to be very clear, the Apple M1 doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúkeep up‚Äù with most other desktop PCs. IT WHOOPS THEY ASSES in terms of both performance AND efficiency. ONLY the highest end AMD chips beat it. AND THIS IS APPLE‚ÄôS FIRST ATTEMPT ü§Ø
Apple played even more fundamental role in the development of ARM. In 1990 a joint venture between Acorn, Apple and VLSI gave birth to Advanced RISC Machine Ltd (later renamed to ARM Holdings). The first Apple product featuring an ARM processor wasn't the iPod as claimed in this video, but Apple Newton in 1993 - more than 8 years before the iPod actually.

[...] People who are really serious about software should make their own hardware. [...] (c) Alan Kay  -  the biggest merit of Apple is - arguably sometimes misguided - but at least fundamental drive towards cutting of some bloat from entire technology stack. They more or less try to keep house in order and avoid builidng on layers and layers of abstraction. Intel chips are mostly unused by modern software, just like AMD.  Apple has dedicated hardware accelerators for common operation and way to enforce its widespread adaptation by developers, coming from strictly controlled mobile market. Intel and AMD have first part, but lack second. Oh, and Apple outbid everybody else, NVidia included in TSMC. Also - there's ANOTHER matter.  Question is, can Apple keep up the pace and keep up with expectations. Intel, while justly being laughing stock for 14nm+++++ had proven they can gimmick additional gains from old dog.  Once they sort out manufacturing difficulties and go to their version of 7 or 5 nm .... they are still GIANT with enormous revenue and market share.  They might not come back to their glory days in 100%, but we might yet see Empire Striking Back, especially if they find way to sort out software.  So far, new M1 MacBooks are bricked by OS update xD

Do take into consideration that the advantages of RISC get less obvious as the processors get more complex. RISC is not going to suddenly push out the classic x86 processors simply because of this. It is inaccurate to portray RISC as an inherently better format. There is a reason they haven't completely dominated the desktop market beforehand. I wish we would stop calling Arm "more efficient" and start calling it "lower power".  ARM has far better sleep states and transitions, and far simpler instructions than x86.  Traditionally for the same amount of work Intel (and AMD) have been able to get the job done faster and with less power used.  Granted, they ramp up to ~150W, but they get it done so incredibly fast that it still uses far less overall power than the same 15W ARM chip.  The difference is that when doing normal light workloads you actually are idling the CPU most of the time.  And idle per idle x86 is expensive on power usage, where ARM can sip power.  That is obviously changing. Modern ARM/RISC are getting more complex... nearly defeating the point of calling it "reduced instruction set".  However, it keeps that legacy of amazing low power states, which means that if you are not doing anything, it simply does not use any power.  So if you push these new Apple chips hard, it should get similar battery life to a traditional x86 chip (maybe a bit better due to more modern video decoding hardware, and smaller die sizes), but they should bench within a stones throw of eachother.  But if you are browsing the web, reading email, working on documents, etc, then the ARM chip will be idle 90% of the time allowing for amazing battery life increases.  But there is another HUGE bonus that Apple has with their ARM chips, and it is not the CPU... it is literally everything around the CPU.  Their GPU architecture is awesomely optimized for normal workloads.  On top of that, they have super tight integration to the RAM and storage which allows for even more power savings.  These are where the real power savings are hiding rather than just the CPU improvements. I am a "wintel" user, and that will not be changing any time soon, but what Apple is doing is absolutely impressive.  The thing that is going to bury Intel is not the awesome advances by AMD and nVidia (though that does not help).  What is going to kill Intel is apple.  Obviously Intel has been king for years and has a warchest of money and IP which will keep them going for years... but if they do not innovate quick, then they are going to be damaged for a decade.

IMO the core principle is that energy efficiency is key to disruption, and Apple gets it.  Sure, everyone figured that out for portable devices (otherwise they can't exist), but here is what efficiency gets you even when there is an electrical outlet... Current supercomputers are using as much juice as small cities, so only centralized governments and giant corporations can hope to run them.  Cut that energy use from 125W/chip to 5W/chip as the M1 does, and 1MW is cut to 40kW, and the air conditioning is cut from >2MW to ~100kW.  Now, even smaller colleges can participate, and server farms can be run off of wind and solar + battery, with minimal need for grid connection.  This drastically expands who can participate.

This is not fair, the video should be named "how ARM changed the industry" , not Apple. In fact the ARm jump  from smartphones to  computers was first adopted   by Linux, in  a silent revolution with  generalized ARM usage in billions of small devices whose owners don't even know they have a embedded Linux on many of  their devices. You did know that all Intel CPU‚Äôs that they have made since 2000 have a RISC chip internal core! For compatibility, Intel treats x86 and x64 instructions like byte code (interpreter instructions), converts that code to micro code (RISC code) and then executes that. Your whole argument about RISC versus CISC was fought 30 years ago and all computer manufacturers use some version of RISC. A little more research on your part would help.

this is so overblown.  in 2006 they were still on PowerPC (with bulk revenue coming from that),  then in 2007 the iPhone (ARM) started to blow up and soon most revenue was from Arm based products. Their most important products each year WERE NEVER ON INTEL.  Not for one single year, ever.
1:45 _"ARM is a simpler design than x86 making it more efficient"_ That's debateable and depends on how you define efficient. x86 does have inherent overheads due to the complexity of the ISA decoders and that's where ARM gains its advantage in low power scenarios. This advantage however diminishes as you go into higher powered scenarios and efficiency is then more closely linked to the process node employed and right now the M1 has a big node advantage being on 5nm.  A lot of the amazing performance is limited to select benchmarks and is not across the board. https://openbenchmarking.org/result/2011202-PTS-MERGE68890&sor Here's a good reference with lots of different benchmarks to ponder if it really is living up to the hype.  What the M1 represents is it's now a viable laptop/desktop alternative, but that doesn't mean it crushes x86 across the board. It also signals that it's time for x86 to drop all legacy instructions going forward.  It should also be noted that the M1 isn't just a set of CPU cores with a GPU built in, it has a whole bunch of accelerators attached to it and that makes a difference, neither Intel nor AMD include a Neural engine on their CPU's meaning it's less about the ARM cores and more about the supporting architecture.

A big omission: The company ARM stood for "Advanced RISC Machines" and was a joint venture between Acorn and Apple, founded Nov 27th 1990. The ARM chip was built for the Apple Newton.

Power efficiency isn't just relevant to the mobile market. Power consumption becomes heat. The performance of desktop CPUs has been bottlenecked by thermal management for a long time now. A more energy efficient processor architecture is an important step to get past that limitation.

use some x86 instruction take multiple cycles to execute to show x86 is slower is so wrong, equivalent arm implement could needs multiple instructions. x86 is not slower than arm,x86 needs comlex logic to decode,so More transistor need, thus More power consumption. x86 is like:if a instructions  can  increase speed, then add it.(MMX, AVX arm only have pathetic 128bit NEON) arm is like:4 instructions can implement this function, is not nessary to add  new instruction. (I feel x86 assembly is More human friendly, arm assembly is hard to write, maybe because the compiler technology become mature, instruction design philosophy transformer form human wrote instruction program to compiler translated instruction program) and morden CPU are so advance   theoretically performance should be same.so what's caused proformamce difference? clock speed, cache sizes, branch prediction, RAM cold fetch time. x86 is faster , but  RISC is the future.
Well explain üëçüëçüëçüëç
By the time Apple started using PowerPC, let alone when they stopped, Intel and AMD CPUs had already switched to translating CISC into RISC ¬µOps, in the case of AMD literally originally based on their 29000 called own RISC ISA. The reason Apple went Intel was simple, because of economics of scale bigger numbers of products sold made it possible for Intel, especially their own Fabs, to invest more money in R&D and sell equivalently capable CPUs for less. And now with smartphones and tablets adding to the already decently sized embedded niche ARM had before, and Intel stuck with their own Fabs at a time of lagging behind, economics of scale add to the advantage of having a custom design for what you want to achieve, in addition to the advantage of not having to translate, but there has never been a CISC chip with more than a low hundrets of MHz, because that doesn't actually work. And all the non-Intel using companies naturally used RISC, all be it different ISAs, because once you do choose that you don't need emulated compatibility to an old ISA, you would naturally choose to natively use the actually sensible design. There is nothing about RISC that is less able to do this or that, or technical reasons, why they were used in higher end or by professional users. The reasons are all about company policies. Intel was chosen, wrongly so, to supply the original IBM machine, and all PCs using Intel or AMD since then, use x86, because they descend from an unbroken line of piece by piece iteratively improved IBM PC clones, that couldn't switch away from x86 without breaking compatibility, or systems that switched to IBM PC hardware, like Apple, because as it had most of the PC market and others were to small to compete.

Hi ColdFusion, always love your videos! However, as a lowly undergrad system guy, I do want to make a few points if you want to expand your researches on them:  1. The RISC architecture does strive to reach a CPI (Clock per Instruction) of 1. In theory, it is possible. But in reality, no. The CPU can fetch things in its registers (internal CPU memory) relatively quickly. Each of these instructions (not really called "fetch") would take 1 clock cycle. But going further away, not even to the RAM, would prove problematic. CPU stalls are usually needed even for fetching data from the cache. Then we have to talk about cache misses. When the CPU needs data from memory, it will try to find said data in the cache first. If it can't find the data, a "cache miss" occurs. The CPU will then need to go into memory, retrieve that data for BOTH the CPU AND the cache. This would take multiple clock cycles to complete. Sometimes, too many (depending on your caching method). Thus, even when they are advertised as "single instruction per cycle", don't believe that it is. The instruction set allows for it. But the laws of physics don't. Memory is simply physically further away from the CPU. It will take an engineering breakthrough to make memory access time as fast as register access time, not a CS breakthrough.   2. Many universities in the U.S. are teaching RISC-V or a simulated architecture based on RISC-V instead of x86. You can be sure that there will be quite a lot more effort put into researching for RISC-V. But the reason why x86 remained relevant and still is relevant is because of its philosophy. I totally agree that x86 is a bloated mess that needs to be purged. But personally, I don't fully agree with ARM's philosophy either. See, when you have fewer instructions, you have to simulate instructions you don't have with your existing instructions. This would  actually be ideal. But one thing you need to know is that many of x86 instructions are hardware-optimized - meaning that they have hardware built-in to support them. And in many cases, one instruction that takes multiple cycles may be faster that multiple instructions where each needs only one cycle. This fact combined with my previous point is the reason why there's still some appeal to x86.  That's about the extent of my knowledge. But I will say that I haven't met a single person (a student, instructor or someone from the industry) who enjoys working with the x86 ISA. It's a bloated mess. It bleeds my eyes when I look at the manual. But technology is going at a snail pace and never as fast as you portray it.
Technological advances like these have had the biggest impact on humanity in the past. This is how we progress as a species.  But, as long as Apple is keeping its technological progress from everyone else (you know, to make shit loads of money), it is no use for those who cannot afford it. Which I might as well add, is most of us.  Apple is tightening its grip on repair policies, and while making it even more difficult for existing users to leave the Apple ecosystem.  I hope Apple realises soon that they already have accumulated such amount of wealth that some might say its unfair. And maybe they can think about everyone else for a change.  But that isn't going to happen, M1 is just another business move for Apple, rather than technological.
I think it's about time for a video on the growth powerhouse Taiwan Semiconductor.  I am interested in what you could dig up about them.

It comes as no surprise to me that Apple is transcending the need for Intel chips. The trajectory they were on was very clear and the biggest road block was getting the sort of software traditionally reserved for desktop running on ARM. Once they'd overcome that they'd be able to completely thread the eye of the needle. With Apple now setting the benchmark the pressure is on Qualcomm to rise to the challenge and come up with ARM chips to power devices such as next generation laptops and surface tablets. Once Windows computers start running on ARM Intel will be worried because of how deeply invested they are in the x-86 desktop market. AMD have diversified a lot and their deals to supply chips for Sony and Microsoft's next generation game consoles gives them some breathing room to adapt to the changing landscape.

Intel tried to replace their aging x86 architecture with IA-64 but at that point, there were too many systems running on x86 so when AMD made a successful 64-bit extension of x86, Intel had no choice but to return to the x86 architecture. Also, I really don't like the way that people keep comparing ARM with x86 directly in benchmarks... Being completely different ISAs, there will places where each excel and blow the other out of the water so it really doesn't make sense to do one task and conclude that one architecture or one processor is superior to the other.

ColdFusion I really like your content, but the explanation about risc vs cisc where it comes to cyles and multiple cycles is a bit off. All the modern ARM arch are pipeline multicycle and I think even microcontrollers now days are like that. CISC processors run what the industry calls "microcode", it is kind of a hardware translation of CISC into RISC to try reduce the "size of the path" of a instruction

Early RISC systems were slower than CISC due to RAM access bottlenecks. You needed to fetch a few short RISC instructions from RAM to do the same job as one long CISC instruction. Even though one RISC instruction was shorter, you needed more of them. RISC still had an advantage by not needing an instruction decode cycle. One definition of RISC is a CPU that has no microcode to decode instructions.
Intel is far from dead, they have invested a ton of money into new tech that will have them back on top In 2022.

How did Apple do what? Built a 5nm ARM chip that uses 12 watts? Simple. They paid TSMC to use their best process node... money. I bet they would have done a better laptop if they owned AMD and used the Ryzen 5000 series and built a custom SKU with that architecture.  Now, try to game AAA (not league of legends) on this ARM chip, or try to do molecular dynamics with it, try to do virtual machines with it, try anything that will not use the acceleration, either efficiency goes down or performance is not there. Then try to repair this laptop after warranty ends. This is basically an undervolted 15W ARM "Ryzen" where the performance of 4 cores has been sacrificed for battery life during media and browsing and acceleration for a few things builtin. I see you are mistaking the CPU capabilities for the OS more than anything, if the OS does not use acceleration for something this cpu offers then performance is crap. The OS has been tailored to work well on the CPU, albeit not in all workflows (because it is reduced instruction set and requires workflows that can be easily compiled for it). The OS is the real star here. I can run android in desktop mode on laptop for a week if not more, but only if i decode video in an accelerated way and the browser does as well, and Apple is selling you that feeling of a 'poor man desktop for a rich man'. In the end it is good for most users, but it is nothing revolutionary, just evolutionary and certainly not 'a desktop'. You are already using a mobile phone for days with a mere 2500mAh battery, and this is just a mobile phone chip that is a few times faster but the battery is also many times bigger, but it is still a mobile phone chip with all the restrictions that come with it. The strength of CISC is exactly the 'complex' part of it, so that anything can run fast no matter how compiled of how well compile-able. For having RISC do well as CISC we need our ecosystem rebuilt from grounds up, and this can barely work on a closed system as Apple's. If you try the same on widescale you get into the mess that is Windows for ARM with no apps and Linux kernels built for ARM that either have patch problems with some apps or have missing apps. Why? Programmers are lazy and want to work less to achieve their goals.  The real reason Apple went with this is to be able to close their system even more, they could have used a customized low power Ryzen, but they felt they do not want to depend on other companies, having felt the Intel problem recently.  P.S. check the benchmarks of the latest low power mobile 8/16 core Ryzens and the media/browsing battery life before replying, and take into account that Apple is on 5nm while AMD still on 7 and using a generic non optimized for the hardware OS (Windows). Then you will understand that this chip is not the awe, but the console approach to the laptop is.  What we really need is an ARM CISC processor (from scratch not x86), so that we developers can code happily without having to know the innards of the CPU to run it well and have the architecture open unlike x86 that is held by Intel and AMD. I for one do not want to "code for consoles" when coding for a PC, it is wasted optimization time for what? Somebody that does not want to charge a laptop every day? If Apple devs want to do that fine, but not something I want as a description of my job or I need as a user. On the job side it takes away creativity time for tedious work, and as a user I can only see this useful to a very small niche, since x86 laptops already work for a full day for basic use. It is not the time to compare Apple to Intel, Intel has been dead for years, we need to compare to AMD that has revolutionized the laptop market recently while still being behind Apple in the process node (actually two nodes behind), and some 100 billion $ behind as well.

This video implies that the M1 chip is faster because it's ARM. However there are plenty of non-Apple ARM desktop and server chips, which are no where near as powerful or revolutionary. The key part is that the Apple ARM chips are both efficient and fast.  Second, this video also implies that x86 chips aren't RISC chips. This was true in the past. Today Intel and AMD x86 chips have been RISC chips under the hood for well over a decade. What also blurs the lines, is that plenty of ARM chips have lots of specialised instructions. Like a classic CISC design.

Honestly, I don't understand why anyone would be upset about this. This is probably the most exciting thing to happen to computers in well over a decade or longer. That type of power and efficiency only means the upcoming processors will be leagues ahead of what we have today or could have had with x86. We were all blown away by AMD's progress and by the looks of it, this new ARM architecture will make that look like peanuts by comparison. If this is indeed what Apple used its billions that it charged for their overpriced hardware, I say it was money well spent. And it's sure as hell more than what Intel has done with its industry lead and revenue.  The big question is, will traditionally x86 manufacturers get on this bandwagon, or will they eventually fall behind and die? It's just crazy to think that we have reached a point where mobile devices (phones) have the same or greater processing power than full-fledged workstations. When things catch on in the software realm, who knows what kind of amazing things it'll open the door to.  As someone who is critical of Apple, I gotta give them props on this one. They earned it.

It¬¥s an excepcional chip, but those syntetic benchmarks or those very few tasks where it can shine over some very powerfull desktop parts, are not representantive of the general performance difference and raw brutte force and power of high TDP chips. I've been an engineer in the semiconductor industry for 30 years, I can tell you that I'm not sure who exactly is excited about Apple's Supposed "changing of an industry". Arm architecture is not a sufficient replacement for any device that isn't using Applet Based programs. Aka, "programs that can fit almost completely in SOC cache." Arm architecture's biggest limitation is it's I/O, which is OPPOSITE the direction x86 architecture is going. Expect Apple to make the best cellphone chips that can run Desktop LIKE apps. But when actual deep branching is required it is simply no replacement for a complex instruction set.  What Apple Excel's at, is putting purpose built accelerators on chip to attempt compensating in areas where arm is inheriently weak. The issue here, is It would be even easier for the more complex architectures to do the same thing, and glean greater performance. These chips will undoubtedly be "performance per watt" champions, but that only really matters in things like cellphones and tablets and perhaps low end laptops where battery life is more important than performance.
I am looking forward to the new AMC Zen 4's and 3nm tech.   And Apple won't release their M1 for use in one card computers - like a Raspberry pi or for IOT applications.  So - I'm not a fan.
I think I speak for most of us enthusiasts when I say, we just want Apple to compete on a level playing field with all the other companies in the market. Instead they are trying to compensate with marketing tactics and a "walled garden" kind of approach, and I really wish they didn't.

Glad this video begins explaining precisely why I hate apple! Big fan of Louis Rossman!
We need to be clear here: ARM isn't magically better than x86; ARM just happens to be better where extremely low power usage and heat generation are important. Apple has not done anything revolutionary. All they've done is drastically change the tuning of the ARM cores to heavily favor performance over power efficiency. Guess what? If you do this, you get more performance at the expense of power usage. Modern ARM cores also have hybrid core setups where there can be a combination of high-speed low-efficiency cores and high-efficiency low-speed cores, as seen in every "octa-core" phone on the market today. If AMD were to take a Ryzen chip and tack on similar efficiency cores to modern ARMs, they would achieve a similar result to the ARM M1 chips: extreme efficiency during near-idle use and extreme power when in heavy use.  Let's be real, though: Apple's M1 chip doesn't perform quite up to the hype. GeekBench shows the M1 is faster than tons of stuff, but it's a synthetic benchmark that's relatively useless. HandBrake tests show the reality: an M1 is faster than an i5 and slower than an i9. Wow! You built a machine with i7-equivalent performance and efficiency cores, what a revolution.  _yawn_  Oh, and let's remember that these are being benchmarked against previous-gen MacBooks in most places, and those are 2-3 Intel chip generations behind, making the benchmarks of the M1 even less impressive.
